IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: A major mediator of the gene-environment interactions in development of diabetes, obesity and metabolic syndrome is the gut microbiome and its impact on the circulating metabolome. To begin to dissect the role of the microbiome in gene-environment interactions in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes and obesity, we have developed a novel model taking advantage of three strains of laboratory mice which vary in their level of insulin resistance and development of obesity and diabetes in response to high fat diet challenge. The major goal of this project is to identify microbiota and metabolites which are altered by the changing microbiome and contribute to insulin resistance and metabolic dysregulation across these models in response to different diets and exercise; identify the highly regulated unknown metabolites that are linked to insulin resistance; and determine how both the known and the newly-identified unknown metabolites linked to insulin resistance alter insulin signaling in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF) have chronic respiratory infections. Oral diseases like tooth decay and gingivitis are potential sources of pathogenic bacteria that could spread from the mouth to the lungs, further compromising respiratory health. The proposed study will identify risk factors for oral diseases in adolescents and young adults with CF, evaluate associations between oral diseases and measures of respiratory health, and explore microbiologic links between oral and respiratory health using cutting-edge microbiome methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Inflammatory bowel disease is a chronic relapsing and remitting condition affecting the gastrointestinal tract, which is often disabling and encumbers normal activities of daily life. The chronic and relapsing nature of IBD, in conjunction with the lack of curative therapies for many patients, enhances risk for inflammation-associated comorbidities, including intestinal fibrosis. This project seeks to understand the role of bacterial metallophores on IBD disease development and severity, which may support the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the prevention of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance  Johns Hopkins has an extraordinary institutional commitment to the health of the public. Through close collaboration across multiple disciplines, the Cancer Center is focused on the entire spectrum of cancer care from risk identification, screening and prevention to early detection and cancer treatment. This patient centered care addresses the effects of cancer on financial stability, family and social interactions and quality of life, encompassing the overall impact of cancer on the lives of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH) is an important enzyme for metabolic and cardiovascular health. The proposed studies will explore a novel mechanism involving gut bacteria for sEH regulation and evaluate the performance of a new method to assess sEH activity, recently developed by the investigator team. Successful completion of the proposed studies would facilitate studies of sEH regulation in humans and lead to new therapeutic targets or strategies in the treatment of diabetes or cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to identify novel targets involved in protection against alcoholic fatty liver disease (AFLD) by elucidating a novel role of redox-modulated hepatic O-GlcNAc signaling in AFLD pathogenesis. Our preliminary studies show that chronic-binge ethanol feeding induces differential changes in liver global O- GlcNAcylation (a prevalent form of post-translational modification) in a mouse model of chronic oxidative stress, which may serve as a protective mechanism against alcohol-induced liver injury. We propose to examine ethanol-associated changes in hepatic O-GlcNAcylation signaling and elucidate key signaling events that are mechanistically linked to hepatoprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The goal of this research is to develop a novel photoacoustic imaging approach that will allow non- invasive, simultaneous three-dimensional visualization of all the embryos in a mouse utero and track their birth/adulthood longitudinally to study the association between maternal alcohol exposure induced fetal hemodynamic changes and the outcome of fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) after birth. The functional focus of this proposal is on fetal cerebral artery mitochondria. Our work will provide better understanding of the pathophysiology of FASD and offer new therapeutic target(s) against this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The NIGMS Human Genetic Cell Repository U42 Application FOA No.: RFA-GM-19-002 Project Narrative The NIGMS Human Genetic Cell Repository (HGCR) stimulates and facilitates biomedical research, teaching, and the diagnosis and prevention of human genetic diseases by providing well-characterized and high-quality cell lines, DNA, and iPSCs for use in biomedical research. The NIGMS HGCR currently contains approximately 11,800 unique cell lines, 6,400 DNA samples, and 54 human iPSC lines representing a variety of disease states, chromosomal abnormalities, apparently healthy individuals and many distinct human populations. The NIGMS HGCR also develops and offers a wide range of cutting-edge special genetic services and biomaterials in response to the research community’s needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infection by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii is widespread and it contributes to illness due to congenital infection and people with weakened immune systems. Although treatment is available to control infection, it is not able to eliminate the chronic stages, leaving individuals at risk of serious disease when infections reactivate. The goal of our studies is to develop new small molecule inhibitors that can eliminate the chronic stages and thus cure infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss due to genetic and environment factors is America's leading disability and imposes a grave social and economic burden. Defects in the actin-based hair bundle, the sound sensors in the ear, are a common cause for hearing impairment. The proposed work will identify novel secreted factors and cytoskeletal regulators with crucial functions in controlling the normal structure of the hair bundle. Ultimately, this new knowledge will facilitate the design of rational therapies to stimulate hair bundle repair following injury, to treat specific forms of hereditary human deafness and to regenerate functional auditory hair cells through stem cell technologies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Genetic diversity is central to the biology of human health and disease but is often overlooked when developing tractable disease models. Thus, to accelerate our understanding of the relationship between genetic variation and phenotypic heterogeneity—and to explore building more accurate and representative cell-based models with which to interrogate this relationship— we propose to hold a multi-disciplinary scientific conference that connects junior and senior researchers from the genetics and genomics, cell biology, and bioinformatics fields and focuses on pluripotent stem cells as an important model for human disease, human genetic diversity, and as a potential future tool for personalized regenerative medicine. The conference will promote networking and multi-disciplinary collaboration, and will inform and train junior investigators in state-of-the-art genetic and bioinformatic approaches for conducting rigorous studies that utilize and leverage human and murine pluripotent stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Metabolism is a renewed target in cancer, and perhaps no cancer is better suited for metabolic therapies than ccRCC, which is refractory to traditional chemo and radiotherapies, and develops resistance to the targeted agents that are current frontline therapies. Here we propose to investigate a molecular mechanism of the hallmark sign of ccRCC, lipid accumulation, as a biomarker and novel target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE: Alzheimer's disease and related dementias globally of a significant pathogenic contributor to Alzheimer's disease, acts remain a leading cause of mortality and morbidity and neurovascular dysregulation has emerged as a critical factor that increases the risk developing cognitive impairment. The present application seeks to examine how on perivascular macrophages amyloid-beta, andleads to neurovascular dysfunction.The application will widen our knowledge basis for the cellular mechanisms of harmful neurovascular effects of amyloid-beta.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal is designed to position the candidate to be a leading independent investigator focused on the development and evaluation of systems-based approaches for effectively delivering complementary and integrative health (CIH) interventions (e.g., non-pharmacologic mind-body interventions such as mindfulness meditation) for common chronic conditions. The proposal focuses on chronic pain and co-occurring posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a population of patients who often seek treatment in primary care, where effective CIH interventions may not be available due to limited resources or patient access (e.g., community care in rural settings). The current proposal utilizes user-centered design strategies to incorporate CIH interventions into proven stepped care approaches designed for primary care settings, and then pragmatically tests the novel approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A vaccine against hepatitis C virus (HCV) is needed, but we have been unable to design a vaccine that stimulates protective, broadly neutralizing antibodies against HCV. By molecularly and structurally characterizing interactions between HCV envelope proteins and monoclonal antibodies capable of blocking diverse HCV variants, we will facilitate rational design of a vaccine against HCV. These studies could also have broad application for design of vaccines against other highly variable human viruses.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE There is little known about natural immunity to sapovirus. The main goal of this project is to characterize mucosal humoral immunity to sapovirus in early childhood using longitudinal samples collected from a birth cohort in León, Nicaragua. Our unique interdisciplinary collaboration affords us the ability to link biological samples and data from children in a high-burden setting to innovative analytic approaches to better understand sapovirus immunology and inform the development of sapovirus vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) includes many forms of inherited peripheral neuropathy that collectively affect ~1:2500 people, and since there are no approved treatments, CMT represents a large unmet clinical need. We recently found that a cellular stress response contributes to the severity of some forms of CMT, providing a potential therapeutic target. This proposed research will explore how the cellular stress response exacerbates neuropathy and may provide additional, more focused, options for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Pathological pain is a major international public health priority and there is an acute need for effective and non- addictive treatments; progress toward this goal depends critically on a comprehensive understanding of its underlying molecular mechanisms. The focus of my proposal is to identify key epigenetic mechanisms that control transcript identity in nociceptors of dorsal root ganglia; nociceptors are neurons that undergo abnormal changes in activity following nerve damage and these changes are associated with the pathophysiology of neuropathic pain. The long-term goal is to inform development of new therapies to mitigate neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Bordetella pertussis resides within airways attached, often in large numbers, to cilia of columnar epithelia and awash in the mucus and sol that overly respiratory epithelia. Attempt to study its attachment and interactions with host cells have been in the context of cells and bacteria all submerged in a very rich growth media, and often result in the death of the host cells. Here we utilize a realistic air-liquid interface in vitro system in which bacteria must cross mucus and sol layers to reach fully differentiated complex epithelial tissue, in which they demonstrate behaviors substantially different from the submerged culture system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The early phase of the HIV lifecycle is a fertile area for antiretroviral drug development as demonstrated by the reverse transcriptase and integrase inhibitors that have changed the lives of millions. We have assembled a team of established and early-stage HIV researchers with multidisciplinary expertise to address critical gaps in our understanding of how early steps in the HIV lifecycle dictate productive infection. This increased understanding should facilitate the identification of new targets and antiretrovirals to improve the lives of people living with HIV/AIDS around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE MS is a neuro-inflammatory autoimmune disease in which T cell driven inflammation leads to demyelination and damage of axons. The overall goal for is proposal is to develop a clinically relevant Adeno-associated virus (AAV) immunotherapy that will restore tolerance in an autoimmune setting such as Multiple Sclerosis (MS). We will show that our protocol will induce and expand antigen (Ag)-specific regulatory T-cells (Tregs) in vivo and independent of MHC or epitope restrictions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Current prevention protocols for people at risk for infective endocarditis (IE) focus on antibiotic prophylaxis prior to invasive dental office procedures for only 10% of people at risk for this life- threatening disease. Although a high percentage of cases of IE are caused by bacterial species from the mouth, there are only informal guidelines on prevention for the remaining 90% of people at risk. This study will determine if improved oral hygiene and reduction of gingival inflammation decrease the incidence and duration of bacteremia of IE-causing oral species, which would refocus longstanding guidelines on prevention for all people at risk for IE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood pressure (BP) variability has emerged as a potential novel risk factor for dementia, yet its clinical translation has been hampered by the lack of standards for assessing BP variability and our poor understanding of the underlying mechanisms. This project will provide novel and comprehensive epidemiological evidence on and new mechanistic insights into the relationship between BP variability and dementia. We expect these findings will identify BP variability as a novel marker for dementia prediction and prevention, and this may ultimately guide a neuroprotective strategy where BP management focuses on BP variability as well as BP level in clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The genetic program by which one multipotent cell gives rise to multiple cell types—skin, brain, liver, etc.—is largely unknown. To identify the molecular mechanisms by which genes are precisely controlled to successfully differentiate into specific cell types, we will leverage 3-dimensional genome technologies that can probe which loci are closely interacting in nuclei. A combination of hybrid mouse models, advanced experimental techniques, and new algorithms will likely reveal a new paradigm of dynamic gene regulation during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Orientia tsutsugamushi is an understudied bacterial pathogen and global health threat that causes the potentially deadly infection, scrub typhus, which afflicts at least one million people each year. This project will address a major technical gap in the field by developing tools for genetically manipulating O. tsutsugamushi. These tools will ultimately enable us and other researchers to better understand how this microbe causes disease and may identify novel targets for treating scrub typhus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to develop novel, non-invasive, clinically relevant magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technologies to visualize therapeutic cell distribution and homing following systemic administration. If successful, the proposed work will provide scientists and clinicians with powerful and clinically translatable imaging tools to assess cell homing, survival and therapeutic efficacy and the means to accelerate therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Enhancer RNAs (eRNAs) are a new class of noncoding RNAs that play important roles in long-range chromatin interactions and gene regulation. In this project, we will map eRNAs and enhancer-promoter interactions using an unbiased approach, on a genome-wide scale, in the hypoperfused adult hippocampus leading up to vascular dementia. This work will lay the foundation for in-depth studies to understand eRNA functions and potentially identify novel therapeutic opportunities against hippocampal damage and vascular dementia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Evidence suggests that, if the low balance confidence of those with chronic stroke is not addressed, the benefits of improved walking ability on daily activity won’t be realized. This proposal seeks to identify distinct types of balance confidence within a commonly used questionnaire, and then determine how those categories of balance confidence relate to walking activity in those with chronic stroke. This is an analysis of existing data that will inform the specific ways we can improve balance, raise balance confidence, and enable more walking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Blood transfusion is the most commonly performed hospital procedure worldwide. Despite standard, FDA- mandated expiration dates, red blood cell units deteriorate at varying rates, increasing the risk of adverse transfusion outcomes for vulnerable populations. We are developing a point-of-care, contact-free assay to evaluate stored blood quality prior to transfusion, which will transform clinical practice by implementing a precision medicine approach to transfusion efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced solid cancers, such as rare ovarian cancer sub-types, are treated with cisplatin-based regimens, but the response is poor and not durable, and most patients die. These cancers still harbor the normally apoptotic wild-type p53 gene but display substantial resistance due to defective p53 phosphorylation, and we strongly believe that restoring this post-translational phosphorylation will reactivate wild-type p53 and permit rational therapies to emerge. Our proposed novel studies, therefore, will investigate whether transcriptional targeting of MDM4 will expose the p53 phospho-site to an active endogenous kinase and restore p53 phosphorylation, enhance p53 activity, contribute to synergy with cisplatin and, thereby, induce strong antitumor activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scrub typhus is an emerging acute febrile illness with high fatality, with an estimated one billion people at risk of infection and more than one million cases reported annually. This project is aimed at generating genome-wide mutant library in Orientia and characterizing host immune responses in animal models by using trackable mutants.

PHR: Narrative Bacteria in the genus Rickettsia include tick-borne human pathogens that can only grow inside of eukaryotic host cells. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will advance the science of precision delivery of care for community-dwelling people living with chronic lung disease. We will refine and pilot clinical prediction models that rely on electronic health record data to identify those who may benefit from frailty- or depression-focused interventions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative National treatment guidelines recommend the DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) eating pattern as first-line treatment option for adults with hypertension; however, adherence to the DASH eating pattern is exceptionally low and foods that align with the DASH eating pattern are inaccessible for many within this population. Our current proposal will test the feasibility of using commercially available grocery delivery services, simultaneous to a robust behavioral intervention, to improve food access and adherence to the DASH eating pattern among adults with hypertension and low access to high quality food. If feasible, this approach can be scaled and used to improve access to an evidence-based hypertension treatment across the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative. Inequitable clinical outcomes have been well documented for minoritized patients with acute respiratory failure and sepsis. However, due to limited understanding of the mechanisms that give rise to these disparities, interventions to successfully mitigate them have yet to be developed. This proposal will use mixed qualitative and quantitative methods to clarify the mechanistic roles of underexplored and novel determinants of acute respiratory failure and sepsis disparities, thereby informing the design of interventions to end these disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Orientia tsutsugamushi (O.t.) is an obligate intracellular pathogen and the etiological agent of scrub typhus, a potentially fatal disease that afflicts over one million people each year. The molecular details of how this important emerging pathogen co-opts the host are largely unknown, predominately due to a lack of tools for genetic manipulation of this significant human pathogen. The goal of our research is to develop genetic tools for use in O.t., which will serve as the first crucial step towards identifying bacterial and host factors that are necessary for O.t. pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project will evaluate a novel biocompatible nanomaterial in preclinical studies to allow its clinical translation for NIR fluorescence and MRI image-guided surgery and sonodynamic therapy of medulloblastoma (MB). Based on our strong preliminary data, we hypothesize that this multifunctional nanomaterial platform can be transported across the blood-brain barrier and accumulate in MB tumors to enable their multimodal detection and safer therapy using non-ionizing low-intensity ultrasound. Translating this technology to the clinic would be transformative in managing MB by significantly reducing morbidities associated with surgery and chemoradiotherapy of MB tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When multi-drug resistant bacteria like Klebsiella pneumoniae take up residence in the airways of ventilator- dependent pediatric patients, both the patient’s and public health are threatened. Research on how these organisms have altered the standard mechanisms of immunity in the lung by changing the metabolic environment is greatly needed to find ways to eliminate or control the detrimental effects on respiratory health. In this study, we aim to identify how lung immunity is negatively affected due to bacterial consumption of glucose, a shared energy source, so we can identify alternative strategies for bacterial eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies link extreme heat with adverse mental health; however more research is needed that focuses specifically on what factors increase vulnerability, and how clinical and policy interventions can better support mental health during times of extreme heat. In this mixed-methods study, we utilize data on psychiatric emergency services encounters in the Greater Boston area and interviews with the clinicians providing psychiatric care, to characterize the impacts of extreme heat among vulnerable patients in low socioeconomic status groups. Our study focuses specifically on identifying the social, behavioral, and environmental factors that influence vulnerability to adverse mental health impacts of extreme heat, with the objective of informing effective clinical and policy interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) has remained a leading global cause of death from an infectious pathogen for over a decade without the advancement of an approved novel vaccine. A slow and complex preclinical pipeline combined with a lack of biomarkers that corelate with efficacy are a challenge for the field. Here we aim to adapt a surrogate high throughput efficacy assay for use in the translational guinea pig model to help accelerate the vaccine pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Monocytes are cells from the immune system that are present during limb ischemia, a process that affects people with peripheral artery disease (PAD), who often require major lower limb amputation despite current treatments. Our previous study demonstrated that certain monocytes with low expression of an important enzyme in the cholesterol pathway, called 24- Dehydrocholesterol Reductase (Dchr24), can help improve blood flow and blood vessels in ischemic limbs. Our goal in this proposal is to decrease Dhcr24 expression in monocytes and understand the molecular mechanisms of this process, which we believe will lead to a unique therapeutic strategy to alleviate PAD in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The extent to which electronic cigarette users may compensate for lower nicotine eliquids by consuming more product has particular implications on the effectiveness of clinical and regulatory interventions. Decisions to use reduced nicotine products or regulations limiting nicotine concentration in eliquids may not reduce nicotine consumption. In fact, such decisions might result in adverse health effects arising from increased consumption of harmful constituents. This project aims to provide evidence to inform regulatory policy on nicotine content in e-liquids by elucidating how nicotine absorption in the body is jointly affected by e-liquid nicotine concentration and vaping behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Over 3 million children in the United States attend schools within 100 meters of a major roadway, resulting in significant exposure to traffic-related air pollutants during school hours and while commuting to and from school. Through our multi-disciplinary partnership with students and community leaders, we will identify time windows of susceptibility to inhaled black carbon pollution. Our innovative approach to integrating laboratory measurements of lung physiology with individual-level air pollution exposures will provide preliminary data for future intervention studies and may directly impact policies in communities where schools are located adjacent to major traffic routes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Anopheles stephensi is a highly competent vector of urban malaria parasites that is rapidly spreading across the globe. The ability of this mosquito to thrive in urban environments distinguishes it from other primary malaria vectors that inhabit rural areas, greatly expanding the number of people it threatens. The proposed research program will evaluate new yeast-based technologies to facilitate the control of this dangerous mosquito.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Evidence-based home visiting programs for new mothers improve many outcomes for children and mothers, including reduction of health inequities, but have not been well studied with telehealth delivery, as has been used since March 2020 due to COVID-19 restrictions. The purpose of this proposed secondary data analysis is to examine the importance of establishing the home visitor-family relationship in person before starting telehealth visits. These analyses will inform the use of telehealth in home visiting, which we anticipate continuing, to a lesser extent, after in-person visits can safely resume.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulated evidence has now shown that following severe inflammatory exposures, hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells can rewrite their transcriptional and epigenetic programs in a type of epigenetic memory that predisposes them to more robust responses to future challenges such as infection or cancer. Understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms of this process, termed “trained immunity”, is a critical step in translating efforts to the clinic. In this proposal, we aim to test and define the role of group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2), and ILC2-derived cytokines such as GM-CSF in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Staphylococci and Enterococci are responsible for over half of complicated skin and skin structure infections (cSSSIs) and effective antibiotic treatments are severely lacking due to widespread antibiotic resistance. We find that combining the unsaturated fatty acid palmitoleic acid with vancomycin sensitizes resistant populations of Staphylococcus aureus and Enterococcus faecalis resulting in rapid bacterial death. We aim to identify how this antibiotic combination leads to bacterial cell death and to determine its potential as a novel therapeutic strategy for the treatment of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of the work proposed here is to better understand how age-dependent dysfunction in human T cells, in terms of both their ability to amplify inflammation and defects in their effector function against pathogens, might result from cellular senescence, the often but not always senescence-related dysfunction of their lysosomal compartment, or both. Clarifying these questions will benefit public health by potentially identifying novel strategies for the targeting of these pathways in T cells for the improvement of both general health and immune function in aged individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Depression is a highly prevalent and debilitating brain illness that is often resistant to treatment. This project will evaluate a novel intervention that delivers low-intensity ultrasound precisely to the deep brain areas that cause depression. This work is expected to provide new noninvasive, individualized, flexible treatment options for an illness that weighs heavily on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has been broadly employed to reveal the brain circuitry with enhanced (“activation”) or suppressed (“de-activation”) activity subserving various sensory and cognitive functions. Unlike fMRI “activations”, the metabolic and neurochemical processes underlying fMRI “de-activations” are much less understood. In this project, we will capitalize on cutting-edge, multi-modal imaging techniques to elucidate the mechanisms of task-evoked fMRI de-activations, facilitating their potential applications as an imaging marker for diagnosing and treating mental illnesses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biological age acceleration starts early in life, even at birth, and has been associated with increased risk for chronic diseases in later life. In this investigation, we will integrate data on environmental chemical exposures, lifestyle factors, and metabolic and inflammatory biomarkers, to determine the impacts of early life environmental exposures on biological age acceleration in children and adolescents, and implicated mechanisms. Findings may inform personalized interventions for the early prevention of aging-related chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative We will develop innovative new technology for tracking precise 3D kinematics during social behaviors in freely moving animals. Our proposed experimental platform will illuminate how natural social interactions are organized and help us understand how they are controlled by the nervous system, and how this control goes awry in disease. The technological leap made possible by this grant will catalyze a host of studies on the neural mechanisms underlying social behavior and mental disorders, and thus help in the discovery of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for afflicted patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  One of the more interesting but also complex challenges of contemporary neurosciences is to study and understand how neural systems in highly social animals operate within complex and realistic social environments. We have assembled an interdisciplinary team of engineers, neurobiologists and computational scientists, to create a platform where we can record evaluate ethologically precise information and brain dynamics in a highly social songbird species within a complex social context over relevant timescales. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Firearm injury and death is a public health epidemic that spreads through communities and social networks in the United States much like an infectious disease. The central objectives of this proposal are to 1) develop and describe trauma networks of all firearm injury events and 2) examine clinical utilization, firearm injury, and mortality outcomes among children, adolescents, and young adult (CAYA) network members, due to the high risk of adverse health outcomes in the 5-years following firearm injury event. This will significantly extend our understanding of the mechanisms and impacts of firearm injury events beyond the individual directly involved and inform interventions that may mitigate adverse and likely debilitating effects among CAYA and will have implications for broader public health significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance: Septic encephalopathy is linked to inflammation and the brain’s inability to produce enough energy and is associated with a 70% mortality rate due to the lack of effective treatments. Using septic mice treated with mesenchymal stem cell-derived structures called extracellular vesicles, this study aims to advance our understanding on how these extracellular vesicles change immune and metabolic pathways involved in septic encephalopathy and improve cellular death and clinical outcomes. The findings from this effort will allow us to develop new therapeutic protocols and use this treatment in other encephalopathies and neurological conditions that cause brain injury and have long-term devastating effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Whereas many states in the United States have completed, or are currently moving toward, legalizing or decriminalizing consumption of marijuana as a recreational drug, epidemiological studies have been accumulating evidence that exposure to marijuana may be linked to increased risk of testicular cancer. Pre- cancerous lesion of this type of malignancy is formed by immature and abnormally developed germ cells in fetal testes before birth; but no experimental studies involving analyses of human or animal germ cells after exposure to the marijuana cannabinoids in the context of testicular cancer risk have been performed so far, leaving critical knowledge gap to understand the potential threats posed by this rapidly prevailing habit of drug consumption. Taking advantage of the cutting-edge techniques to create cells and organoids resembling human germ cells in embryonic testes as well organ culture method of embryonic mouse testes, this project will determine whether marijuana cannabinoids have biological potential to deviate human and/or mouse germ cells from their normal developmental path and thus increase the risk of testicular cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Although difficult to quantify, naturalistic environments provide the opportunity to study the brain and behavior in response to the ethological problems an animal is naturally designed to solve. We seek to expand the capabilities of our current behavioral segmentation approaches to provide a more precise and comprehensive account of behavior. By incorporating recent innovations in machine learning, segmentation approaches that can account for behavioral dynamics at multiple timescales, and increased breadth in the sampling modalities used to classify behaviors, we will create a toolkit that our team and others can make use of to quantify complex, spontaneous behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social behaviors are critical for survival and their defects are hallmarks of many neurological diseases. To enable us to identify genetic changes that affect behavior, we will design naturalistic behavioral arenas, automated tracking assays, and new behavioral frameworks for the study of Lake Malawi reproductive behaviors in contexts that include male competition and female choice. Use of this new behavioral assay will allow us to understand how behavior evolves and identify underlying neural circuits that are conserved even in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allergic asthma often initiates in early childhood and progresses into adulthood. Such progression is driven by pathogenic T helper 2 resident memory cells in the lung. By characterizing molecular mediators and pathways involved in the development of pathogenic T memory cells in the immature lung of young children, we will provide the foundation for the discovery of therapeutic targets to modify the progression of allergic asthma from childhood to adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is focused on identifying and characterizing the genetic basis of a novel and specific antimicrobial produced by a Pseudomonas strain and specifically targeting the agricultural pathogen E. coli O157:H7. E. coli O157:H7 is a major cause of foodborne illness in the United States, with infections often occurring after human consumption of agricultural products colonized with E. coli O157:H7. We have shown using other systems that application of tailocins in a prophylactic manner can prevent bacterial infection, and thus a better understanding of the genetic basis of the tailocin-like killing activity we have discovered could enable the development of treatments to prevent E. coli infection under agricultural and harvest conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative DynamiCare Health has developed a digital therapeutic to address stimulant use disorder (StUD) that combines remote substance testing, appointment tracking, self-guided therapy, and contingency management (CM)—the most effective yet under-utilized treatment for StUD. This project builds on initial clinical success in pilot testing to conduct a rigorous, long-term, large-scale RCT to measure clinical impact and cost effectiveness. If successful, this project will lead to FDA clearance as a medical device and broad payer coverage of a product that could become the standard of care for StUD and address the national stimulant epidemic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Ciliopathies are multi-system disorders of the brain, eye, kidney, skeleton, and other organs, and arise due to defects in cilia structure/function. Over 1000 genes have been predicted to be involved in ciliary function, although most have not yet been functionally identified. The goal of this proposal is to test an emerging model suggesting that cohesin genes, known for regulating nuclear processes, contribute to cilia structure/function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the U.S., accounting for approximately 1 in 5 cancer-related deaths. Annual Low-Dose Computed Tomography screening for lung cancer is recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, but only 6.5% of eligible individuals were screened in 2020, and there are major health inequities in LCS related to race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status. The long-term goal of LungSMART Utah is to increase the reach of LCS at scale among low resource healthcare settings and populations that have been historically marginalized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The overall goal of this proposal is to generate more valid, relevant, and actionable data with regard to risk factors for unfavorable tuberculosis treatment outcomes, in order to inform interventions to reduce tuberculosis-related morbidity and mortality. Using a novel analytic approach grounded in causal inference, we will estimate the causal effect of key baseline exposures on end-of-treatment outcomes and determine the extent to which each causal effect is mediated by suboptimal adherence to treatment, versus an alternative pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cost-effective control of antimicrobial resistance (AMR), an urgent global public health threat, needs to target locations and individuals that drive the transmission of AMR organisms in healthcare settings. This project will develop a series of novel inference methods to quantify heterogeneous transmission rates in hospital wards and identify individuals carrying AMR pathogens for six high-priority organisms in four major hospitals in New York City. The proposed studies will produce inference frameworks synthesizing multi-type observations that are readily available in electronic health records to inform improved interventions, which can be generalized to other healthcare facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Relevance We will develop a new scalable technology enabling high-resolution 3D quantification of a complex predator- prey interactions in freely moving animals, giving the community an easy-to-use, off-the-shelf method for measuring a significantly expanded set of variables describing natural brain function, from sensory input to motor output. By capturing detailed summaries of a dynamic natural behavior, we open the door to wide-ranging studies of the mechanisms underlying neural functions for which the brain has actually evolved, thus allowing the field to move beyond the simplistic and artificial lab assays that are currently limiting our understanding of the nervous system. By offering higher resolution and more diverse measurements, our new technology also makes it easier to detect the effects of new therapies for neurological disease, thus accelerating the pace of treatment discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is an incurable viral infection of the liver that causes hepatocarcinoma and cirrhosis. Even when treated with the best available drugs, HBV causes other long-term health problems for patients because of a persistent viral genome known as covalently closed circular DNA, or cccDNA. To eliminate cccDNA and cure HBV, this proposal creates a group of compounds known as peptide nucleic acids and tests their ability to target and degrade cccDNA in animal models of HBV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We discovered that mutation of TBK1 (a gene that promotes autophagy) is an important cause of normal tension glaucoma (a leading cause of blindness worldwide) and we collected skin cells from our patients with glaucoma-causing TBK1 mutations and 1) reprogrammed then into induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) and 2) differentiated them into retinal ganglion cells, which are a prime site of glaucoma pathobiology. In this proposal we will determine how TBK1 mutations cause retinal ganglion cell death and glaucoma by 1) creating isogenic controls and 2) determine the cellular pathology associated with TBK1 mutation using autophagy, mitophagy, and scRNAseq assays. Our studies of normal tension glaucoma with iPSC-derived retinal ganglion cells will provide important insights into the disease mechanisms of glaucoma and will develop cellular resources to facilitate the design and testing of new gene-directed therapies for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a leading cause of cancer death, but it lacks effective detection and treatment due to complicated pathogenesis mechanism. Our research aims to uncover how a crucial non- coding RNA is abnormal in its methylation in NSCLC and how this impacts the formation and phenotype of the cancer. This study will shed light on the pathological effects of de-regulated RNA modiﬁcation in NSCLC and establish a foundation for creating therapeutic molecular tools that can regulate gene expression through non- coding RNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social vocalizations and movement-generated sounds often provide pivotal knowledge about an animal’s identity, location, or state, yet most studies of natural behavior fail to integrate acoustic information with simultaneous recordings of neural activity and behavioral dynamics. This proposal will develop novel experimental and computational methods to attribute vocal and non-vocal sounds to individuals in a naturalistic, acoustically complex, multi-animal environment. By integrating this rich acoustic information with simultaneous video and wireless neural recordings, we seek to predict auditory cortical responses to auditory cues, as a function of social context and individual identity within the family.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although research documents the concerning rates of mental and behavioral health problems (e.g., substance use/initiation) among Indigenous LGBTQ2S+ youth, there is very little known about how to prevent these deleterious issues that devastate Indigenous communities. The proposed project aims to adapt and evaluate the first ever culturally grounded, family-based program to prevent mental health and related problems among Lakota LGBTQ2S+ youth. The proposed project aligns Goal 3 of the NIMH to identify targets for intervention via a rigorous pilot RCT with a highly marginalized and underserved population and the Healthy People 2030 Goals to eliminate health disparities, which includes reductions in violence and injury among LGBTQ2S+ youth and youth of color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application aims to develop and test a novel, text-messaging intervention for parents of adolescents evaluated in our emergency department for a psychiatric emergency and discharged home with outpatient referral. This proposal has both clinical and scientific significance because it is the first study to develop an automated, text-messaging tool that will support parents of high-risk youth treatment engagement. This research has the potential to improve services for families seeking emergency psychiatric support, with the goal of facilitating treatment engagement and reducing emergency services utilization using scalable, cost- effective, accessible tools.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to lay the groundwork for conducting large scale neural recording experiments in herds of sheep engaging in their normal individual and collective behaviors in the field. We will develop new embedded systems which enable high spatio-temporal resolution tracking of individual behavior as well as measurement of the visual sensorium of the animals. With this cutting-edge data, we will develop a new generation of computational models that predict individual behavior based on internal state dynamics and perception of the environment and the behavior of conspecifics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative We found that two environmental toxins of concern to humans, copper and arsenic, disrupt the localization of a telomere binding protein to telomeres of embryos and to nucleoli of L4 larvae. Characterization of responses to copper and arsenic in wildtype and long-lived mutants may reveal that they epigenetically reprogram a suite of stress response genes with ITS tracts, which would provide a valuable novel model for how environment stresses as well as the status of telomere capping might modify longevity and stress resistance in humans, potentially in the context of inheritance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, continuous breathing from birth is essential to life and requires that the nervous system generate a reliable and robust rhythm that drives inspiratory and expiratory muscles. The proposed studies will significantly advance our understanding of the neural mechanisms generating breathing rhythm and pattern in both health and diseases of respiratory failure. We will determine one or more critical subpopulations of neurons that can be targeted for treatment of respiratory failure during opioid overdose, sudden unexpected death in epilepsy, and central sleep apnea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria, such as vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), are major causes of hospital-acquired infections and contribute to common diseases becoming untreatable and a rise in health expenses. The research proposed here promises to reveal new insights into the biological processes driving colonization with antibiotic resistant bacteria, which is the first step for infection and spread within hospitals. This work will help inform how to prevent antibiotic resistant bacteria by defining which patients are at greatest risk for colonization and which strains are likely to spread in hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Cancer cells, senescent cells in culture, and cells from old humans display widespread losses of an ‘epigenetic’ mark known as DNA methylation, specifically in gene-poor genomic regions known as heterochromatin. Decreased DNA methylation in heterochromatin is associated with aberrant expression of transposable elements, parasitic DNAs which are normally repressed in the genomes of healthy cells, and whose derepression leads to inflammation. The underlying mechanisms are not fully understood, but inflammation is almost invariably observed in both cancer and aging. We have recently observed that cells deficient in DNMT or TET proteins, which act to add or remove DNA methylation respectively, show similar losses of DNA methylation in heterochromatin, concomitantly with increased transposable element expression and inflammation. We will test the hypothesis that TET and/or DNMT deficiency underlies the depression of transposable element expression and consequent inflammation in human aging. Our studies in this area will illuminate the mechanistically elusive connections among cellular senescence, aging and cancer, improve our understanding of heterochromatin, and perhaps inform future therapies for combating aging.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hypergonadotropic hypoestrogenic infertility due to ovarian damage is the greatest burden for women suffering from hereditary Classic Galactosemia, an inborn error of metabolism included in the newborn screening programs. Timely diagnosis and introduction of diet have shown to be beneficial, but diet does not prevent ovarian damage, which invariably affects women with this disease. This project aims to develop gene- based therapy targeted to the ovary to prevent or halt the damage cascade and determine the optimal window of opportunity for this treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project presents a strategy for developing novel aminoglycoside therapeutics with reduced ototoxicities with evasion of resistance. Antimicrobial resistance occurs when microorganisms (often infectious bacteria, viruses, and certain parasites) are no longer sensitive to drugs that were previously used to treat them; this is of global concern because it hampers our ability to control infectious disease and increases the costs of health care. In order to combat this world-wide problem, innovative strategies for antibiotic drug design must be implemented. The proposed research describes a strategy for improving the therapeutic index of aminoglycosides by designing novel structures that lower their ototoxicity and evade common resistance pathways.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of The Environmental Determinants of Diabetes in the Young Study (TEDDY) is the identification of infectious agents, dietary factors, or other environmental agents, including psychosocial factors which trigger type 1 diabetes (T1D) in genetically susceptible individuals. This project will extend the study to include viral markers. Identification of such factors will lead to a better understanding of disease pathogenesis and result in new strategies to prevent, delay or reverse T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it could make available an effective and safe therapeutic regimen that dramatically increases the response rates of cancer patients to immune checkpoint inhibitors, immunotherapies that have revolutionized cancer therapy because they elicit robust treatment responses in previously untreatable tumors. It will also advance insight into the scientific merit and feasibility of engineering ensemble nanoimmunotherapies by combining biofunctionalized nanoparticle-based photothermal therapy with immune checkpoint inhibition for treating cancer, and the immunological basis for the observed treatment responses. Successful completion of the project will provide the impetus for clinical translation of our nanoimmunotherapy, thereby extending lasting benefits to a larger proportion of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Severe defects in the primary cilium cause prenatal lethality while less severe defects result in a variety of diseases including polycystic kidney disease and blindness along with a group of syndromes called the ciliopathies. These syndromes, which include Bardet-Biedl, Meckel Gruber and Jeune Syndromes, often present with cystic kidney disease and blindness along with a variety of symptoms including obesity, mental retardation, and structural birth defects. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanism by which cilia are assembled and function to ultimately drive the identification of a treatment or cure for these diseases.

PHR: Narrative: The Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy Connectome Project will use state-of-the-art imaging methods to measure altered connections between brain regions in patients with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The biological embedding of maltreatment may explain the variability mental health outcomes. The proposed research will identify specific genome-wide DNA methylation patterns unique to maltreatment and link those with changes in mental health symptoms across adolescence. This will further the development of clinical risk assessment and prevention approaches for maltreated youth which will be of substantial benefit to population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: TITLE: Refining the Genetic and Genomic Architecture of Non‐syndromic Orofacial Clefts The long term goal of this study is to identify novel risk loci for orofacial clefts (OFCs) in the African population. This project is inherently transformative and has the potential for far- reaching impact not only in the African population, but also in populations in the United States, Canada, Europe and other societies with multiracial immigration and distributions with persons of African descents. The successful completion of this project will have significant positive impact on strategies designed towards understanding the biological role of identified variants and modification of genetic risk that will reduce the outcome of OFCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging is associated with the development of vascular dysfunction, which increases the risk for cardiovascular disease. This clinical trial will determine whether a new oral supplement called MitoQ, which reduces the production of damaging reactive oxygen species from mitochondria, can improve vascular function in older adults, and will provide insight into the biological reasons (mechanisms) by which supplementation with MitoQ exerts these benefits. Overall, this research will provide scientific evidence supporting the use of MitoQ for preserving vascular function and decreasing cardiovascular disease risk with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pancreatitis is a common and potentially lethal and/or debilitating condition for which existing treatment options have shown limited efficacy. Since inflammation is a key driver of disease progression in pancreatitis, we propose to conduct a Phase II randomized clinical trial to establish if a brief course of anti-inflammatory corticosteroids given very early in the acute process will improve key clinical outcomes including illness severity, inflammation and pancreatic injury, hospital and ICU-free days, and death. Successful trial outcomes will set the stage for a larger multi-site Phase III trial and potentially lead to a new and effective treatment option for pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Acute emergency healthcare within a rural state varies, with marked disadvantages and poorer outcomes for emergency events occurring in rural areas. This program builds upon Maine Medical Center's exceptional clinical experience and strong basic/translational research program to create a framework for enhancing acute care research throughout our state. We will also address consent and inclusion for research in acute care to increase participation of rural subjects in clinical studies, with the long-term goal of improving acute care outcomes for patients in rural areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicide risk prediction models are being used by health care systems to guide delivery of suicide prevention interventions, but these prediction models may not accurately identify high-risk patients in racial and ethnic subgroups that are less prevalent or have lower rates of suicide attempt and death. This project will reduce racial and ethnic disparities in suicide risk models by developing methods for prediction model estimation that optimize performance within subgroups, rather than across the whole population, and adjust for misclassification of suicide outcomes. We will also design sample size calculations that evaluate the ability of a prediction study to accurately identify high-risk individuals within racial and ethnic subgroups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Subjective cognitive decline (SCD), or a person’s perception of changes in their cognitive abilities, has been identified as a possible early marker of preclinical Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in non-Hispanic Whites; however, research is lacking about the value of SCD reporting in diverse populations. This study will investigate the associations of self and informant reports of SCD with biomarker profiles of AD and objective cognitive trajectories in Hispanic/Latino older adults living in the United States over 3 years. Learning about the value of SCD to predict biomarker profiles of AD and changes in cognition in older Hispanics/Latinos can help with early detection of individuals at risk for cognitive decline and improve outcomes via preventative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: The identification of critical therapeutic targets in MPN cells will have a significant impact on the development of much needed treatments for the 300,000 MPN patients in the U.S. While deregulated JAK2 activity has been identified as an important factor that contributes to MPN formation and has been targeted by small molecule inhibitors, these drugs have had very limited success in patients. This proposal will investigate a potential Achilles’ heel of JAK2 inhibitor-treated cells as a target for novel strategies to improve MPN therapeutics, as well as interrogate unknown molecular details of the molecular biology of MPNs and response to JAK2 inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Chemotherapy is the standard of care for triple-negative breast cancer, however up to 25% of patients who receive this treatment will suffer metastatic recurrence within five years. The extracellular matrix is a major component of the tumor microenvironment, which provides structure and support to our tissues, which is known to drive invasion and metastasis. The goal of this project is to investigate how the extracellular matrix contributes to chemoresistance and chemotherapy-induced metastasis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative  Most neurobehavioral diseases emerge at different life stages, and progress in a different pattern in males and females, but fundamental knowledge is lacking regarding when and where sex alters neural development. This project establishes sex-biasing effects of sex hormones and sex chromosomes on localized brain regions across the entire brain at specific times of life, and investigates cellular and molecular mechanisms operating in a sex-specific manner at salient sites of sexual differentiation. Mechanistic information developed in an animal model will be translated to humans using novel high-throughput analysis of patterns of sex differences in brain that have common development across species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Screening for lung cancer reduces lung cancer mortality but fewer than 4% of eligible Americans get screened, and lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer death in the United States. mPATH-Lung is an innovative digital outreach program that identifies patients who qualify for lung cancer screening and helps them get screened. This project will determine how mPATH-Lung affects patients’ screening decisions and their completion of screening, potentially reducing the number of people who die from lung cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dr. Pardue’s research program is centered on developing life-changing treatments for veterans with vision loss. Her pre-clinical research in the areas of neuroprotective treatments for retinal disease, detection and treatment of diabetic retinopathy, and mechanisms for myopia or near-sightedness have formed the basis for 3 translational studies to human patients (retinal prosthetics, diabetic retinopathy, and neuroprotection therapies). Dr. Pardue’s dual appointment between the VA and GaTech and her research interests create novel opportunities to develop ground-breaking treatments that can preserve or halt vision loss.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Chronic pain after injuries is a major medical problem for Veterans and members of the general population. Chronic pain in the setting of traumatic brain injury (TBI) is particularly prevalent and difficult to treat. Patients suffering TBI and additional injuries (polytrauma) are even more likely to experience chronic pain. Commonly employed treatments such as the use of opioids and NSAIDS are highly problematic in Veterans with TBI. On the other hand, recent evidence suggests that persistent pain after TBI results from damage to endogenous pain control mechanisms residing in the brainstem. Thus we may be able to reduce or even prevent pain after TBI by augmenting the actions damaged neural circuitry. This project will pursue this goal using multiple approaches in a well-characterized rodent TBI and polytrauma models. At the conclusion of the project we expect to be in position to translate our findings to clinical populations using agents similar or identical to those optimized for use in the animal subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Ubiquitin System is an intense research area with great promise for the improvement of human health. In addition to its critical role in normal physiology, malfunctions in ubiquitin biology have been implicated as a contributing factor in the causation of many illnesses as diverse as diabetes, cancer, and Alzheimer's disease. This proposal will develop new mass spectrometry-based technologies for sample multiplexing specifically tailored to chemical biology workflows to define small molecule-protein interactions which can be used as precursors for therapeutic interventions. 0

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Activation of the immune system to eliminate tumor cells is an exciting approach to cancer therapy, but only a portion of patients respond to these interventions. Clear cell Renal Cell Carcinomas are variably responsive to treatment with immunotherapy, and we have found that the tumor microenvironment of this cancer may restrict metabolic pathways essential for effector T cell function. This study will examine mechanisms and potential approaches to overcome these metabolic barriers to anti-tumor immunity to improve immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching hypothesis of our PPG states that early life stress (ELS), such as household dysfunction, neglect, sexual or physical abuse, economic hardship, and exposure to violence induces immune cell activation leading to vascular dysfunction with increased hypertension risk and CVD risk that are exacerbated by later life stressors or moderated by resilience/protective factors. This PPG with both basic science and clinical projects utilizes a synergistic and integrative approach translating concepts from animal models to humans with our major goal being to inform prevention and intervention strategies to mitigate future CVD risk in individuals exposed to ELS. Our PPG will address two critical barriers to fulfill our goal: 1) need for ELS-specific in-depth mechanistic and translational studies; and, 2) identify modifiable protective factors that can mitigate ELS-induced CVD risk.

PHR: ADMINISTRATIVE AND DATA ANALYTICS CORE A NARRATIVE The primary goal of the Administrative and Data Analytics Core is to enhance the research environment and infrastructure in pursuit of building on the strong synergy between Project Leaders, Core Directors, and all investigators to ensure cost effective management and integration of the goals of the PPG. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: This project utilizes a combination of the most advanced biochemical, biophysical, and structural techniques to investigate mechanisms of Arp2/3 complex inhibition by Arpin and Coronins. A wide coverage of studies will reveal the mechanistic structure-function relationship that underpins inhibition, a critical component in Arp2/3 complex regulation that controls cell motility, tissue development, and muscle contraction. Mutations in Arp2/3 complex and its regulatory proteins have been linked to cancer metastasis, cardiomyopathies and vascular diseases, and the expected outcome is a better understanding of the mechanisms of inhibition that should inform strategies for treatment.

PHR: CARDIOVASCULAR PHENOTYPING CORE B NARRATIVE The Program Project focuses on elucidating mechanisms by which stress early in life contributes to the serious health problem of cardiovascular risk later in life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This double-masked randomized controlled trial will leverage the NCI National Community Oncology Research Program (NCI NCORP) and NCI National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN) sites to conduct the first national, full- scale test of a computerized cognitive training program (BrainHQ) against a computerized active attention control program to improve self-reported (perceived) and objective (performance) cognitive functioning as well as examine its impact on other real-world, everyday outcomes in breast cancer survivors with cancer and cancer treatment-related cognitive impairment. Positive or negative findings about this easily accessible therapeutic treatment option will help provide evidence to guide clinicians’ recommendations and survivors’ treatment selections for managing this prevalent, persistent, disruptive, and often debilitating problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although tobacco smoke exposure is the most important risk factor for lung cancer inherited genetic factors also play a role as shown by many family and genome wide association studies. The proposed studies will detect novel rare genetic factors, examine interactions between smoking history and the rare genetic factors and evaluate the impact on the cellular phenotypes of these mutations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Hearing complaints such as tinnitus (ringing in the ears), hyperacusis (intolerance to loud sounds), and difficulty understanding speech in noisy environments are commonly reported by Veteran patients even when their hearing test is clinically normal. Unfortunately, there is a lack of consensus among clinicians about the best way to manage these patients because treatment options are limited and the outcomes are variable. One of the major barriers to developing treatments for this patient population is that although these patients likely represent a heterogeneous population with etiologies including lesions to the peripheral and central auditory system as well as cognitive deficits, there are currently no test measures that can pinpoint the damage location. This project will enable differential diagnosis of damage to the peripheral auditory system and will characterize the auditory perceptual deficits associated with peripheral damage. This will have a positive impact on Veterans' health because it will allow for the future development of treatments that are specific to the underlying auditory deficit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanisms of learning and memory and their dependence on behavioral contexts have important implications in memory disorders such as Alzheimer's disease and age-related dementia, as well as post-traumatic stress disorders. The olfactory bulb adult neurogenesis presents an excellent model for studying experience- dependent plasticity. We propose to study the cellular and circuit mechanisms for the context specificity of synaptic structural plasticity of adult-born neurons in the olfactory bulb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a proposal for a K24 Midcareer Investigator Award in Patient-Oriented Research for Kelly E. Dooley, MD, PhD. This award will support Dr. Dooley’s mentorship of new and existing young investigators and her clinical research programs which are focused on improving tuberculosis (TB) therapeutics and optimizing treatment of HIV-associated TB, using clinical pharmacology as a powerful tool for doing so. The overarching goals of her research are to improve the treatment of drug-sensitive and drug-resistant TB, TB meningitis, and mycobacterial diseases, and to ensure new treatments are available to those patients who need them most, including populations such as children, pregnant women, and patients living with HIV, all through well-designed clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is a serious public health crisis and a leading cause of death in young adults, especially among those with borderline personality disorder (BPD). Results from this study will advance understanding of dyadic interpersonal mechanisms within romantic relationships that exacerbate and maintain suicide risk in young adults, including those with and without BPD. The ultimate impact of this work is to inform improved, evidence- based assessment tools, identify new targets for intervention, and develop partner-involved intervention strategies to reduce suicide risk and improve psychosocial functioning in vulnerable young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 NARRATIVE Early life stress (ELS), or traumatic events during childhood or adolescence, is widespread in the US with ~50% of children and adolescents having one or more major ELS experiences as well as being an independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Project 1 utilizes unique mouse models of ELS to determine how ELS initiates and promotes future cardiovascular disease. An in-depth understanding of how ELS promotes cardiovascular disease is essential to reduce the healthcare and economic burden of cardiovascular disease on our society.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposed research is of particular importance to the health of veterans. Veterans are more likely to get Parkinson’s disease (PD) because of links between PD and Agent Orange exposure, repetitive head trauma, and posttraumatic stress disorder. This confluence of factors in an aging veteran population will drive the rising incidence of PD and adversely impact quality of life, for both veterans and their care partners. Through identifying in vivo markers of mitochondrial function, this proposal promises to identify ways to better predict how fast PD will progress, allowing clinicians to better counsel patients and their families on what to expect and when. Another important consequence of being able to better monitor and predict disease progression in PD patients is being able to design more efficient clinical trials, ones that may call for fewer participants and last a shorter duration. This outcome will increase the possibility of finding a drug that helps PD patients sooner, allowing them and their caregivers to more fully participate in their lives and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is the leading cause of deaths from gynecologic cancers in the U.S. While most women present with advanced disease, more than 1 in 10 of such women will survive >10 years after an initial diagnosis, underscoring the paramount importance of treatment selection. In the proposed research, we will use mathematical modeling techniques to identify personalized treatment approaches – tailored to individual patient and tumor characteristics – that can improve women's chances of long-term survival and minimize their likelihood of receiving harmful, low-value care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE The response to hypertension-eliciting stimuli in adults is sensitized by prior exposure to aversive conditions during early life. Evidence indicates that this sensitized response is the result of neuroplasticity in brain pathways controlling the sympathetic nervous system and long-term blood pressure regulation. The proposed studies investigate the mechanisms of postnatal nervous system programming on hypertensive response sensitization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health and precision health because comprehensive evaluation of a wide range of modifiable environmental exposures, including the currently ubiquitous environmental neurotoxicants lead and cadmium, will advance scientific understanding on the etiology of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) and inform individual-level and population-level interventions to effectively prevent or reduce the burden of ADRD. The proposed study is directly responsive to the 2018 National Institute on Aging AD Research Summit recommendations related to Understanding the Impact of the Environment to Advance Disease Prevention and Enabling Precision Medicine Research for AD/ADRD, and to the research goal of NOT-AG-18-053, Enabling precision medicine for AD/ADRD through deep molecular phenotyping.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer is the second leading cause of mortality in the United States and disproportionately affects minorities. Clinical research designed and conducted within a consortium of multiple institutions enables faster evaluation of novel therapies, in a variety of malignancies, across different populations nationwide. It also facilitates assessment of scientific correlates that may help assess the effects and individualize cancer therapies.
