IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to increase our collective knowledge on the contribution of vascular and immune components to the pathophysiology of autosomal dominant Alzheimer disease (ADAD), a form of AD with a known genetic etiology involving β-amyloid (Aβ) metabolism, as well as the influence of these components on anti-Aβ therapeutic strategies. This proposal employs multiparametric approaches to assess neurovascular unit disruption using molecular techniques and proteomics, along with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for biomarkers of small vessel disease (SVD), imaging measures of cerebral blood flow, and amyloid burden. Determining how these vascular and immune factors impact ADAD pathophysiology and response of individuals to anti-Aβ therapies will greatly further our understanding of the biological mechanisms of this early-onset form of AD and provide insight on potential novel and more targeted therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 NARRATIVE Early life stress is strongly associated with cardiovascular risk and multiple poor health outcomes in adulthood. Adolescence presents an important age window for identifying targets for early interventions that can limit the impact of early life stress on future cardiovascular risk. This proposal seeks to understand the relationships between early life stress and indicators of future cardiovascular disease risk in adolescents, which will provide therapeutic targets for future intervention studies to reduce the public health burden of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dr. Cooper is a world leading rehabilitation engineer. He is a US Army veteran with spinal cord injuries who has dedicated his career to helping veterans to lead full and rewarding lives through engineering and advancing assistive technology. He has made broad contributions to science, engineering, and education applied to improving the quality of life of veterans with disabilities, and providing opportunities to become scientists and engineers. His research activities focus on the design, engineering, and evaluation of mobility devices, robots, and other systems for veterans with disabilities. Dr. Cooper is Director of the VA Rehabilitation Research & Development Center for Wheelchairs and Assistive Robotics, and a VA Senior Research Career Scientist. He has built research collaborations and provided training to >4,000 clinicians/scientists. His work has resulted in four books, >30 patents awarded/pending, and >100 inventions/innovations. His work engages veterans from concept to deployment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The goal of the proposed research is to test the role of interactions between brain stress and brain reward circuits in mediating behavioral dysregulation during alcohol withdrawal. The proposed experiments will test the effects of chronic alcohol on specific brain reward and brain stress circuits, and the role of those circuits in mediating alcohol withdrawal-induced increases in anxiety-like behavior. The results of this work will advance our understanding of the neurobiology underlying alcohol use disorder (AUD) and may identify new targets for treating AUD in humans.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Aspergillosis is associated with high morbidity and mortality among immunocompromised patient populations. The recent emergence of antifungal resistance in Aspergillus is threatening our already limited therapeutic armamentarium for this disease and represents a major impediment to effective treatment. It is of vital importance to understand how resistance develops in Aspergillus, so that this knowledge can be translated into therapies that prolongs the lives of affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Despite the increasing prevalence of kidney diseases, there is a shortage of nephrology workforce to advance scientific discoveries and technology to address the growing burden of kidney diseases. The lack of innovation and kidney technology development over the past decades has been a primary barrier to breakthroughs in the field. The VA K-TUTOR program will provide a rich environment to excite and recruit young talent to foster innovative solutions to benefit the 40 M people in the US with kidney diseases. The VA K-TUTOR will be a partnership of UVA Division of Nephrology, UVA schools of Engineering and Arts and Sciences, College of Arts and Sciences and VA Tech School of Medicine to recruit and train undergraduate students for identifying problems in kidney research and finding novel solutions.

PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a serious health problem affecting more than one-third of adults in the United States that is generally caused by excessive food intake. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 4 NARRATIVE Early life stress is an important risk factor for cardiovascular disease, but the biological mechanisms of these effects are not clear, nor is it known whether lifestyle factors during development diminish the negative impact of early life stress on cardiovascular outcomes. This project investigates the roles of gene expression, inflammation, and gut microbiome in the connections between early life stress, lifestyle/psychosocial factors, and vascular function in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The protein, eIF4E, is important to normal cells and when dysregulated can drive the development of a broad array of cancers. eIF4E does this by co-opting the signal from the DNA (known as RNA) allowing it to generate more of the proteins that can drive cancer. In this proposal, we identified a new mechanism by which eIF4E uses this activity to imbue cancer cells with the ability to move, and thus invade neighboring tissue. We can exploit this new knowledge to ultimately develop new therapeutic strategies for high-eIF4E cancers.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER

PHR: Project Narrative Non-malarial acute undifferentiated febrile illnesses (AUFIs) continue to be significant causes of morbidity and mortality in Latin America, and the lack of definition of the underlying etiologies and involved vectors has prevented the development of appropriate public health interventions. Over the past five years, we completed advanced training of Colombian Faculty members, PhD students and postdoctoral fellows. We will implement new strategies as we continue to build capacity and train investigators from six collaborating institutions in Colombia to address these important and frequently lethal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans are ubiquitously exposed to endocrine-disrupting chemicals (EDCs) in the environment; among these, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) strongly affect hormone-sensitive developmental processes and are associated with a wide-range of adverse neurobiological health outcomes in humans and wildlife. Understanding the underlying mechanisms of PCBs on neural development across generations, and how these exposures can alter future behavior, can inform medical interventions and guide public health policy. In my proposal a rat model of perinatal PCB exposure relevant to humans is used to explore the phenotype of neurobehavioral disorders and the molecular and epigenetic processes that underlie them in exposed individuals and their offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system plays a critical role in eliminating cancer cells. We have data showing that inhibition of Galectin-1, a hypoxia and radiation regulated protein, leads to a significant decrease in immune suppressive immature myeloid cells (MDSC) in the tumor and blood of tumor bearing mice. Therefore, we posit that Galectin- 1 can enhance the expansion of MDSC in the circulation and attract them to the tumor after radiation, where they exert a negative effect on T cells. We also postulate that targeting MDSC with CXCR2 inhibitor in combination with radiotherapy and PD1 immune checkpoint therapy will overcome the deleterious effect of Galectin-1.

PHR: NARRATIVE Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is a devastating neurodevelopmental disorder with prominent sensory hypersensitivity that negatively impact the quality of life of individuals. These studies will determine how the formation and function of brain circuits that underlie this are disrupted in a mouse model of FXS. Ultimately, our translational studies in mice will test new classes of treatments to alleviate sensory symptoms in FXS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  When preterm birth occurs at the most extreme youngest gestation, the hope of neurologically intact survival must be weighed against the very severe trauma that infants and families may undergo in efforts to resuscitate and care for an infant that may ultimately have a very short life or severe life-long disability.  Clinicians lack the ability to provide the most accurate and up-to-date information to the family so that they can come to the best decision for the infant, as current prediction models rely on older data, are not tailored to the individual institution where the birth is occurring, and use limited information to make predictions; furthermore, there is a gap in knowledge in the following: how the use of prediction tools might impact counseling and clinical practice; whether tools can make any difference in outcomes such as survival without morbidity and length of stay before death; and the cost impact and cost-effectiveness of using such tools.  We propose to expand the knowledge base on prediction models for periviable gestation in an existing network of neonatal intensive care units in California – involving 140 hospitals from which to obtain data—by implementing the prediction model with established collaborative quality improvement methods, evaluating the impact of implementation on practices and outcomes, and examining the cost impact of implementation in clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall Component This application would initiate a Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) in Omaha, Nebraska, with a focus on human neuroscience research across the lifespan. The Cognitive Neuroscience of Development and Aging (CONDA) Center would include an administrative core that oversees a dynamic collection of supporting programs, an advanced Neuroimaging Acquisition and Analysis Core Facility, four primary COBRE junior research projects led by NIH-defined early-stage investigators, and an established cohort of senior investigators. The Center would be based at the University of Nebraska Medical Center (UNMC), but its programs and supported members would extend across four centrally-located academic campuses in downtown Omaha, and its impact would be felt across the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative More than 100,000 patients undergo surgery to create a stoma (an opening in the abdominal wall) for treatment of intestinal disease or injury each year in the United States. To decrease the risk of complications, we have developed the LimpetTM, a new device designed as an alternative to conventional pouches used to collect waste from the stoma. Our goal is to deliver a new post-surgical standard of care to improve ostomy patient outcomes, shorten hospital stays, reduce readmissions, and save healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program aims to elucidate the fundamental molecular mechanisms of channelrhodopsins, a family of microbial proteins similar to visual pigments that enable control of neurons and cardiomyocyte cells with light by combined optical and genetic techniques (“optogenetics”). Channelrhodopsins have been used to map brain circuitry, as well as for experimental therapeutics, and clinical trials are underway to use channelrhodopsins to restore vision to blind individuals. Molecular understanding of their mechanisms will enable engineering optogenetic tools that will benefit biomedical research and potentially treatment of neurological and cardiac diseases, such as epilepsy, Parkinson's disease, neuropathic pain, and tachycardia and other heart rhythm disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is an increasingly prevalent clinical problem and the second most common cause of cancer-related death. To address the magnitude of this problem, it is critically important to identify those at high risk for HCC and institute effective surveillance strategies for early diagnosis. In this competing renewal, we will build on and extend our prospective cohort of patients with cirrhosis to develop and validate blood-based and imaging-based modalities for risk stratification and early detection of HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving psychosocial health for patients with chronic hip pain has a strong potential to increase engagement in physical activity and thereby reduce pain and improve physical function and well-being. The proposed Helping Improve PSychosocial Health (HIPS) mind-body intervention delivered by physical therapists through a hybrid in-person-telephone modality may be an effective and scalable solution to improve physical activity in rural populations through psychologically informed rehabilitation. Consistent with NCCIH priorities, this project may promote a paradigm shift by providing an effective treatment care model through psychologically informed rehabilitation to promote whole joint health and patient well-being for the millions of patients with chronic hip pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  It is now abundantly clear that mutations in many of the key proteins involved in human recombinational DNA repair result in chromosomal instability which, in turn, translates into a predisposition for cancers. The results from these studies will provide unique molecular insights into the macromolecular assemblies that are crucial for genetic stability and tumour suppression. Understanding the function of these proteins, and the failings of proteins defective in this process is consequently of importance to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in attention and goal-directed cognition are likely contributors to age-related memory decline and serve as an impediment to daily living. In cognitively `healthy' older adults, preclinical Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology may nonetheless disrupt attention and goal coding, with deleterious consequences for memory. Using innovative technologies from neuroscience and psychological science, together with biomarkers for AD- related pathology, the proposed research will increase understanding of (a) how moment-to-moment and individual differences in attention and goal coding affect learning and remembering in young and older adults, and (b) how these differences relate to memory decline in aging with and without AD pathology, which holds promise for revealing novel neurocognitive biomarkers for AD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our goal is to understand the genetic and molecular basis of selfish chromosomes and speciation in animals, including humans. We are using a multidisciplinary approach and developing new techniques to identify genes and molecular pathways that evolve rapidly between species and cause defects in hybrids. Our studies will provide a unique perspective to fundamental cellular processes that are important in cancer biology and birth defects in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Magnetic resonance (MR) is a safe method for imaging that does not rely upon ionizing radiation. We will develop MR detection of hyperpolarized 13C-labeled and thermally polarized, 2H-labeled substrates as markers of metabolic dysfunction in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Our overall goal is to develop a robust, safe, MR based assessment of hepatic energy metabolism that can be applied to diagnose and stage these diseases.

PHR: We will convert oral daily HBV treatment regimen (tenofovir and entecavir) and an immunomodulatory agent (tizoxanide) into medicines that can be administered once every two months. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial therapy can lead to disruption of the gut microbiome and infection with Clostridioides difficile, a disease associated with high morbidity and mortality, particularly among the elderly. Drawing on observations that pet ownership and close contact with pets are protective against colonization with C. difficile and recurrence of C. difficile infection, the proposed study will test the hypothesis that microbiota that provide colonization resistance against C. difficile are shared between patients and their pets and that pet contact can mitigate antimicrobial-associated gut dysbiosis and the risk of C. difficile infection. This study will further define epidemiologic and pathophysiologic characteristics of C. difficile infection and gut microbiome dysbiosis that could enhance therapeutic options for these conditions, potentially through non-invasive interventions involving animal contact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Rectal cancer represents a growing problem, because it is increasingly diagnosed in people in the prime of life; however, research into new treatments has been hampered because current models of rectal cancer poorly represent patient tumors. Our goal is to develop rectal cancer organoids (tumoroids) as models for rectal cancer research and to establish whether the tumoroids allow for prediction of individual patients' responses to the components of standard treatment, including chemotherapy or radiotherapy. The ultimate result will be expansion of patient-specific research tools, accelerated discovery of new treatment options for rectal cancer patients, and eventually better treatment decisions for individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of hematopoietic stem cell diversity can occur after administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy, stem cell transplantation, or toxin exposure, leading to cytopenias or other blood disorders and decreasing the quality and length of life. This project aims to understand how the cellular niche surrounding the hematopoietic stem cell is able to modify its gene expression program in order to be able to support hematopoiesis. These studies may lead to new therapies that can expand the hematopoietic capacity of the niche, aid recovery of hematopoiesis with a phylogenetically and functionally diverse population of stem cells, and prevent the devastating late complications of chemotherapy on the blood system.

This new technology will be built into existing devices that are currently used to image disease in the retina, providing a simple way for clinicians to evaluate patients using a simple retinal scan. This would have significant implications for detecting and managing diagnostic that can be widely used at a lower cost than current methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pericytes are a key cell type in the capillary wall, and their deficiency during Alzheimer’s disease leads to impairment of important vascular functions, such as blood-brain barrier integrity and regulation of blood flow. This project uses cutting-edge live imaging to study the dynamics of brain pericytes in live mice, with the goal of revealing how the brain responds and adapts to pericyte loss. It will also test whether augmentation of pericyte-endothelial coverage can improve capillary health and function in adult and aged brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health The lack of reliable detection methods of small amyloid oligomers in vivo has hampered elucidating their contributions to Alzheimer's Disease and related disorders. This projects aims to identify and validate new fluorescent probes for reliable detection of the elusive and transient amyloid oligomers. Such oligomer-selective dyes are highly promising candidates for developing in vivo PET imaging probes for oligomer detection in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative As a result of limited treatment options, poor prognosis and the propensity to metastasize, basal-like breast cancer accounts for a disproportionate number of breast cancer-related deaths in U.S. women. Data from our lab shows that suppression of POLE differentially affects inflammatory gene expression of breast cancer cells of the basal type (BLBC) compared to luminal breast cancer cells, raising the question of what underlies these differences and how to leverage them therapeutically. This proposed work may illuminate a strategy for clinically targeting NF-? B and other pathways sensing genotoxic stress by the innate immune system in tumors primed to activate this pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Medical and recreational Cannabis use has doubled in the last four years, and as the primary psychoactive compound, ∆9-Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), becomes more prevalent it is critical to understand the various behavioral effects such as hypolocomotion. Using a cutting-edge endocannabinoid sensor, we have found that endogenous cannabinoid activity in the prelimbic cortex of the brain correlates with movement in THC treated animals. The goal of this proposal is to leverage cutting-edge approaches, while simultaneously enhancing neuroscience training in neuromodulation, to isolate the mechanisms by which THC modulates prelimbic cortical activity to mediate spontaneous movement in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: With no current therapeutics for cocaine use disorder, thousands of individuals are left vulnerable to relapse. This proposal seeks to identify the circuit-specific changes in neuronal activity and gene expression that drive cue-induced relapse to cocaine-seeking. These findings have the potential to identify novel therapeutic targets to treat cocaine relapse and cocaine use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately half of smokers engage in cigarette relighting (extinguishing, saving, and later relighting unfinished cigarettes) to save money, cut back to quit smoking, try to reduce harm, or due to lack of time to finish a cigarette. This behavior may increase health risks both due to compensatory smoking behavior and inadequate treatment and cessation attempts. This project will provide important new information about the extent, frequency, contextual factors, and potential dangers of the understudied behavior of relighting, with implications for both surveillance and treatment such as new assessment items that can be used to screen for relighting in population surveys and clinically and potentially inform clinicians in prescribing and delivering adequate-intensity behavioral and pharmacological smoking cessation treatments for the half of smokers who relight.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: NARRATIVE Autistic children might be misdiagnosed as having a language impairment or be at risk of having their language or communication challenges attributed to bilingualism, consequently delaying the attainability of appropriate services. This study seeks to understand the contribution of clinical and demographic predictors of language skills development in autistic school-aged children. The expected results will positively affect public health and educational systems by informing the standards for language assessments for bilingual Spanish–English–speaking autistic children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The role of extrahepatic cells in the physiological effects of very low-carbohydrate, high-fat ketogenic diets remains poorly understood. Our Preliminary Results and the scientific literature provide strong support for the scientific premise of our hypothesis that diet-induced shifts in the host production of ketone bodies selectively inhibit the growth of gut bacteria leading to a decrease in immune cell activation and improved metabolic phenotypes. We will dissect these complex host-microbial interactions through the paired genetic manipulation of host and bacterial pathways, providing a critical step towards our long-term goal of harnessing the microbiome to treat metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Nurses are the largest U.S. professional group, and nurse burnout and depression, causing some nurses to leave the profession, are a major threat to the healthcare system. Working on the front lines, they encounter situations that cause moral distress (or the inability to deliver what they believe is ethically appropriate care because of external constraints). Unaddressed moral distress can have lasting impacts on their personal and professional lives; to improve the healthcare system, we must ask nurses to describe their ethical challenges in order to modify factors that contribute to moral distress and boost their ethical confidence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Modeling How Moral Distress & Ethical Confidence Impact Nurses' Emotional & Physical Health and Safety Culture

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Achilles tendon ruptures are common injuries that have long-term implications on patient function and activity levels. This proposal investigates the healing response of both muscle and tendon following an Achilles tendon rupture to identify the mechanisms responsible for compromised muscle quality and poor function. These findings will provide support decision making of both clinicians and patients and establish a research framework for developing and optimizing therapies for improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the leading causes of disability in older adults. Because pharmacological approaches do not seem to prevent or slow the disease, clinicians need non-pharmacological interventions that might help people with AD remain independent for as long as possible. This study aims to evaluate the effects of a new behavioral treatment for adults with mild cognitive impairment designed to promote independent living skills by explicitly teaching the use of strategies and tools to compensate for cognitive weaknesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is a physically deforming and often fatal disease with limited treatment options. NSD1, a histone methyltransferase involved in epigenetic regulation of gene expression, is inactivated in ~15% of HNSCC. This project proposes to understand the mechanism by which NSD1 loss promotes the development of HNSCC, with a specific focus on the role of NSD1 in tumor immune escape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Both of insulin receptor (IR) and type 1 insulin-like growth factor receptor (IGF1R) are receptor tyrosine kinases (RTK) that play essential roles in controlling glucose metabolism and cellular growth, and aberrant IR or IGF1R signaling causes a number of human diseases, including diabetes and cancers. Despite the functional importance, the exact ligand induced activation mechanism of IR and IGF1R are still unknown. In this project, we will study the structure and function of full-length receptors/ligands complex to reveal how ligands binding to the receptors lead to the receptor activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will evaluate implementation strategies for and effectiveness of navigator-delivered electronic patient-reported outcome home symptom monitoring and management (Home ePRO). Once the success of these strategies is demonstrated, there is potential for broad implementation of navigator-delivered Home ePRO to ultimately reduce patient symptom burden, minimize adverse outcomes associated with uncontrolled symptoms, and significantly advance the field's knowledge of optimal approaches to patient-reported outcome implementation. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission with respect to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is the most common brain cancer and one of the deadliest. To date, immunotherapy has not prolonged the life of glioblastoma patients to the same extent as in other advanced cancers such as melanoma. In this proposal, we are going to conduct a clinical trial of a novel combination of immunotherapies for glioblastoma and then analyze tumor and blood samples from patients in the trial to advance our understanding of the immune system in brain tumors.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project narrative Our prior research has shown that dysfunction of a specific nerve, called the vagus nerve, is associated with small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), and that SIBO is associated and signs of inflammation in the blood of people living with HIV (PLWH). This research will explore pathways linking vagal dysfunction to inflammation in HIV, focusing on the gastrointestinal tract, and study whether a medication called pyridostigmine and stimulation of the vagus nerve are beneficial therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Blast-mediated traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of injury for Veterans. Blast TBI triggers an activation of the immune system, generation of auto-antibodies, as well as CNS infiltration of circulating immune cells. Our central hypothesis is that blast-mediated traumatic brain injury activates cellular and humoral immune responses that lead to increased chronic neurodegeneration after TBI. The overall goal of this study is to determine which components of this response are necessary and sufficient to cause neuronal loss and dysfunction after blast-mediated TBI. We will also determine if these responses can be modulated with currently approved medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Narrative The principal goal of the University of Pittsburgh Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center (PITT-ADRC) is to perform and promote research that increases our understanding of the etiology and pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias in order to ultimately advance new therapies. The PITT- ADRC provides the infrastructure to investigate the mechanisms underlying cognitive and behavioral symptoms, and to develop strategies for effective early diagnoses and treatments of AD. We will accomplish this goal with our own research, involving investigators at the University of Pittsburgh and nearby institutions in clinical and basic research, and with collaborations with other national and international centers of excellence, in an environment that supports innovative research and enhances training and educational opportunities for patients, caregivers, students, scientists and clinicians

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we will investigate the rerouting of the lipid synthesis pathways upon enterovirus infections. Our data support a model that diverse enteroviruses target the same cellular factors to induce upregulation of membrane synthesis needed for the protection of their replication sites. Understanding the mechanisms of this hostile takeover of the cellular lipid synthesis will reveal targets for the development of a new generation of broad-spectrum anti-viral therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus that causes hard to treat, often fatal aspergillosis diseases. The fungus grows as invasive filaments in infected patients. Here we will identify the fungal and host factors that favor fungal growth, with the goal to target these factors for therapeutic treatment of fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: UV-induced clonogenic mutations (CMs) can be used to evaluate an individual's overall sun exposure and the status of sun-induced genotoxicity in the skin which can profoundly impact how we diagnosis and treat early stage skin cancer. CMS can be used to evaluate therapeutic response to field treatments for skin cancer. CMS can be used to rapidly evaluate strategies for the prevention of skin cancer, such as the genoprotective efficacy of sunscreens or an individual's adherence to sunscreen application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Gay and bisexual youth make up 80% of all new HIV infections among adolescents ages 14-19 in the United States, yet interventions to improve sexual health outcomes in these youth are extremely limited. Our team has developed an intervention to reduce HIV risk for gay and bisexual youth by working with their parents to improve the ways parents communicate with their sons about sexual health. We propose to deliver our intervention to parents of gay and bisexual teens ages 14-19 and to test whether it helps their sons by reducing sexual risks and increasing HIV testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While several research studies have demonstrated the positive impact of protective factors in Alzheimer's disease, this knowledge is yet to be translated into feasible dementia prevention trials. Understanding fundamental mechanisms through which important protective factors alter Alzheimer's disease trajectories is crucial to facilitate bench-to-bedside translation. In this proposal, we provide a theoretical framework to discover mechanisms that help prevent Alzheimer's disease pathologies or cope without cognitive symptoms even with Alzheimer's disease pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Pneumonia is a leading cause of morbidity and death, with no improvement in pneumonia-associated mortality rates since the 1950s. Because of rising antibiotic resistance in bacteria and significant limitations in the accuracy of diagnostic tests for pneumonia, many patients receive antibiotic treatment that is either ineffective against the bacteria causing their pneumonia or entirely unnecessary – while suspected pneumonia drives 49-60% of antibiotic prescribing in the United States, 30-60% of these prescriptions are ultimately unnecessary or inappropriate. We will further develop a rapid breath test for the diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia and early determination of whether the bacteria is susceptible to the antibiotic being used – this would allow patients with bacterial pneumonia to be identified earlier and more accurately than currently possible, improving clinical outcomes and reducing unnecessary antibiotic use.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative This proposal will examine the ME/CFS from the perspective that an aberrant response to an immunological trigger like infection results in a dysregulated immune system that is partially immunosuppressed due to CD8 T cell exhaustion. These studies will identify potential biomarkers and mechanisms driving the immunopathogenesis of ME/CFS leading to future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Primary Dysautonomia (PD) is a condition in which the autonomic nervous system does not function correctly leading to disabling and pervasive disease. To start investigating the pathogenesis of PD, we initiated a large- scale exome sequencing project consisting of an unprecedented pool of patients and identified mutations in voltage-gated sodium channels as clinically relevant. To probe the involvement of these genes in autonomic dysfunction and PD, we will create robust animal models in which therapeutics can be tested, and by doing so, we expect to generate a first glimpse into possible causes of PD.
PI_NAMEs: BOSMANS, FRANK GERT WERNER;BROCK, MALCOLM V (contact)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension prevalence increases with aging and is a leading risk factor for chronic illnesses including dementia, cardiovascular disease, and several cancers, as well as mortality. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) are two of the most commonly prescribed antihypertensive medication classes, used by ~40 million US adults, and are often prescribed interchangeably despite different beneficial effects on physiologic abnormalities in hypertension. In this study, we will use national Veterans Health Administration and Kaiser Permanente Southern California data to determine the long-term comparative effects of ARBs versus ACEIs on the risk of dementia, cardiovascular disease, cancer, frailty, and life expectancy accounting for level of illness and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Current theories dichotomize decision-making into planning and procedural information processing, but newer theories suggest more complex, hybrid algorithms may exist within mammalian decision-systems. Understanding the information processing within these decision-systems is critical to help recognize and alleviate disorders that arise from imbalances and dysfunctions within those decision-making systems (such as OCD, eating disorders, and drug addiction) and can also help us develop new behavioral “nudges” that can guide behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is the eighth and ninth leading cause of cancer in men and women, respectively in the United States. The therapeutic options for patients with pancreatic cancer have not improved as quickly as other cancers because the main driver mutations are KRAS and GNAS, two GTPases. We propose a research effort to make the first GNAS inhibitor to treat a subset of pancreatic cancer patients that currently have no targeted therapeutic options.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA-CHAPEL HILL, FROHLICH The proposed research is relevant to public health since it investigates the causal role of oscillatory dynamics in cognition with emphasis on output-gating of information and the mechanistic implementation of gating processes in the brain. This work will contribute to a mechanistic understanding of how network-level neural dynamics facilitate cognition across scales, providing new network targets for psychiatric disorders with cognitive impairment, making it highly relevant to the NIH mission of fostering innovative research strategies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Current treatment decisions for millions of patients rely on classification of patients into risk categories using a single model for predicting 10-year risk of cardiovascular events. Although this model and other recently published models have comparable overall performance, their performance varies in racial and other important subgroups. We propose instead of focusing on a single model, develop a consensus of models that best performs in clinically-important subgroups, accommodates availability of known risk factors or missing data patterns to personalize risk estimates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Nearly half of the U.S. population sometimes or always experiences loneliness, which is alarming given that loneliness confers risk for negative mental and physical health outcomes. Extensive research suggests loneliness is characterized by subjective isolation: many lonely individuals maintain a number of relationships but still report feeling lonely. The goal of this proposal is to use functional magnetic resonance imaging to reveal how the brain represents our subjective connection to and isolation from other people, which will ultimately inform optimal ways to intervene to reduce loneliness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Behavioral and cognitive symptoms of many psychiatric diseases are linked to synaptic loss in the prefrontal cortex. Converging evidence indicates that dynamic neuron-microglia interactions contribute to synaptic deficits in the prefrontal cortex following chronic stress. This application will examine the role of neuron- and microglia- specific molecular mechanisms that initiate synapse loss and resultant behavioral and cognitive impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority adults face persistent, stark health disparities in both physical and mental health. Romantic relationships are a critical context for understanding health and legalized marriage, an important relationship milestone, is only newly available to sexual minority couples. This project has clear relevance for understanding sexual and gender minority health by examining stress, health, and relationship processes repeatedly and dyadically at multiple levels across the newlywed period among sexual minority couples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Hyperactivation of receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) signaling is associated with cancer aggressiveness, increased metastasis, and chemotherapy resistance yet direct inhibitors of RTKs have had limited efficacy and a new strategy to target metastatic tumors harboring active RTKs is needed. This proposal will functionally connect RTK-driven changes in metabolism of sphingolipids – bioactive molecules involved in diverse cell processes – to cancer metastasis through the acquisition of anoikis resistance, a key metastasis-enabling biology. These studies will mechanistically advance our understanding of how sphingolipids promote tumorigenesis and establish the sphingolipid enzyme DES1 as a novel therapeutic target for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer harboring hyperactive RTK signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) affects millions of Americans; however, we do not have effective therapies for AD due to lack of understanding of the disease at cellular level. In this project we take the advantage of CRISPR- Cas9 to unlock the molecular role of AD linked protein SORL1, in resident immune cells of the brain. Parallel, we examine the therapeutic potential of SORL1 and its partner proteins using newly developed CRISPR tiling screen strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative This proposal seeks to elucidate how human T cells use asymmetric cell division to generate long- and short- lived daughter cells with distinct phenotypes, metabolism and functions. The proposal has broad public health relevance, as the cellular mechanism underlying the development of distinct T cell phenotypes determines the clinical outcome of engineered T cell therapeutics. Similarly, a better mechanistic understanding of persistence of skin-resident T cells has significant implications for inflammatory skin disease pathophysiology and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The modern era of molecular biology has revealed key variants throughout the genome that are enriched in those who develop complex autoimmune diseases, including type 1 diabetes (T1D). Our goal is to understand how these variants in immune checkpoints contribute to a loss of immune tolerance to pancreatic -cells, and toward that objective, this R01 renewal application is centered on CD226, a gene encoding a costimulatory molecule associated with T1D genetic risk and disease development. The results of this project are expected to inform on the biological mechanisms by which CD226 signaling alters peripheral tolerance and contributes toward disease progression, as well as provide preclinical data related to therapeutic targeting the CD226/TIGIT/CD96:CD155/CD112 pathway to correct immune defects and restore immune tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT The goal of this study is to understand the specific mechansims underlying activation of T cells that already migrated to the tissue and cause inflammatory reactions. We expect to uncover this novel mechanism using molecular and genetic tools, NKD2 and Rab44, that we have identified from large-scale screening efforts. Outcomes of the proposed studies will have positive impact on development of drugs that specifically suppress local inflammatory events (multiple sclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, etc.) without affecting general immune cell functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The coordination between breathing and postinspiratory behaviors such as swallow and laryngeal postinspiratory activity is essential to health and is disrupted in a host of neurological disorders. This project aims to advance the understanding of neurocircuitry governing these complex behaviors, which is currently limited. Novel experimental techniques will be used to elucidate the neural coordination of breathing with the postinspiratory behaviors vital to efficient ventilation and airway protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The TRPM8 ion channel protein has emerged as a promising drug target for diverse diseases including many types of pain; however, we currently understand relatively little about its function at the molecular level. This proposed research sets out to illuminate the mechanisms and networks that underlie TRPM8 function. The outcomes of this research will help us better understand normal human physiology, general fundamentals of membrane protein function, and contribute information that will be helpful in guiding future TRPM8-based drug discovery efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol abuse affects millions of people in the United States, and individuals who are resistant to alcohol intoxication and sedation are more likely to develop alcohol use disorder. Chromatin remodeling in GABA neurons is one mechanism that may be involved in alcohol use disorders, because these mechanisms regulate downstream gene expression and neuronal function. I propose to investigate how chromatin in GABA neurons is altered by alcohol abuse, which will elucidate the role of GABA neurons in alcohol use disorder and will identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project will investigate the strain-dependent tau pathogenesis in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration with tau pathology (FTLD-tau) using spreading models of tauopathy. The study aims to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which diverse tau strains transmit through the interconnected neurons and compromise neuron functions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Failures in the evolutionarily conserved cell division of meiosis result in infertility and birth defects such as Down syndrome. Proper meiotic segregation requires double strand break repair—a process also required to maintain genome integrity and prevent cancer. This grant seeks to understand the molecular basis for proper chromosome behavior during meiosis. This knowledge may ultimately lead to the diagnosis and/or prevention of certain types of infertility and birth defects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Central to the etiology of the “Great Obstetric Syndromes” (early pregnancy loss, preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction, placentae abruptio, and pre-term birth) is the maldevelopment of the uterine-placental interface. Construction of the uterine-placental interface depends on its constituents, including the interplay between invasive trophoblast cells arising from extraembryonic lineages and uterine cells of maternal origin. Identification of regulators of the uterine-placental interface will permit: i) the effective discovery of diagnostics for early detection of failures in placentation; and ii) elucidation of molecular mechanisms controlling placentation that can be targeted for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Loss of cell polarity and uncontrolled proliferation are two universal hallmarks of cancer. We have shown that cell polarity is temporarily dismantled during cell division, and that the same machinery that controls cell division triggers the removal of polarity proteins from the cell surface. Building on these discoveries, we will decipher the mechanisms that erase and restore cell polarity when cells divide and determine the consequences to tissue architecture when these processes go awry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Invasive fungal infections pose an escalating threat to human health and have enormous economic consequences. This project will optimize compounds that inhibit a newly discovered antifungal target to deliver one or more advanced leads for future development of a clinical drug candidate. In doing so, it will pioneer protein kinases as a greatly needed new target class for highly effective single-agent antifungals which also possess the potential for use in resistance- aversive combination regimens, a treatment strategy that has been missing for antifungals but has proven key to controlling other life-threatening infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection disproportionately affects rural communities in sub-Saharan Africa, leading to high rates of mortality and fueling ongoing transmission. The proposed research seeks to engage and support rural people living with HIV in Uganda through local traditional healers as an adjunct to routine clinical care, with the goal of improving viral suppression and thereby reducing HIV-associated morbidity and transmission. This proposal aligns with the National Institutes of Health’s mission to foster “innovative research strategies … for ultimately protecting and improving health”, and is responsive to the National Institute of Mental Health’s goal of supporting research to improve the HIV continuum of care in order to reduce HIV deaths and infections worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative One of the hallmarks of cancer is its ability to evade the immune system. The immune cells responsible for eliminating tumor cells, known as CD8 T-cells (or informally as “killer” or “effector” T cells), function by entering and destroying tumors. In many cases, however, the CD8 T-cells become “exhausted”, a state in which they infiltrate the tumor normally but fail to kill the tumor cells. The functions of CD8 T cells are controlled by transcription factors that act in the cell nucleus to turn on or repress genes. We previously showed that two distinct classes of transcription factors, NFAT and bZIP proteins, control the balance between CD8 T cell exhaustion and effector function. In this application we will continue our long-term collaboration to investigate the fundamental mechanisms by which these transcription factors influence immune responses against tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is a universal phenomenon, and aging in humans dramatically increases the probability of  developing neurodegenerative diseases. In this proposal, we take advantage of the model organism  Caenorhabditis elegans to investigate molecular mechanisms underlying aging- associated neurodegeneration.  Completion of our studies will pave the way to fully understand aging- associated neurodegeneration and likely  provide new drug targets for potential clinical studies of neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to Public Health: The Notch signaling pathway enables cell-cell communication in critical and diverse developmental processes including neurogenesis, somitogenesis, angiogenesis, and hematopoietic development, and is implicated in many diseases, making Notch a major therapeutic target. Using quantitative single-cell analysis of reconstituted signaling pathways together with mathematical modeling, this proposal will provide an understanding of how molecular components of the Notch pathway function together through a newly discovered dynamic ‘code’ that ensures that the correct target gene expression programs are activated in individual cells. These studies will elucidate fundamental mechanisms of Notch function relevant for diverse diseases and pharmacological interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: There are currently no vaccines against any fungal disease. This application is proposes to develop a vaccine for the prevention of Cryptococcosis, a serious and life-threatening disease caused by the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans. Our goal is to take advantage of recent advances to create a novel polysaccharide-protein conjugate that will elicit protective antibody responses and be useful for the prevention and therapy of cryptococcosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Autosomal Dominant Leukodystrophy (ADLD) is an adult onset disease which leads to CNS degeneration resulting in muscle wasting, weakness and early death for which there is no treatment. We propose to characterize a novel mouse model where we can reduce the levels of the causative protein, lamin B1, to determine whether it can delay or reverse the disease phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed project is relevant to public heath because its performance will demonstrate the undefined contribution of RIPK3 to severe human encephalitis disease pathology induced by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding of the development of anxiety/depression during alcohol withdrawal is critical to the prevention of relapse during alcohol abstinence and overall treatment of alcoholism. This project investigates the effects of adolescent alcohol use on a primary neurotransmitter system (glutamate) in key brain areas (the extended amygdala) known to be important for the development of anxiety/depression. These studies also explore differences in the development of these behaviors between sexes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patient-derived pluripotent stem cells are essential tools for studying human disease biology and for the development of individualized regenerative medicine, however, stem cells from genetically diverse patients behave in unpredictable ways. One potential route to overcome this confounding variable and help realize the promise of precision medicine is accurate prediction of the diverse cellular states that are dictated by an individual's genome. This project will generate key resources to help achieve this goal by providing experimental tools for the identification and validation of critical genes and pathways governing cell state transitions and differentiation propensity, and the information needed to build predictive models based on an individual's genetic background.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heme is an essential cofactor, signaling molecule, and metallonutrient that is implicated in the pathogenesis of numerous human diseases. Using an innovative blend of genetic, biophysical, and biochemical approaches, we seek to characterize the molecules and mechanisms underlying heme acquisition, trafficking, and signaling in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV infection is expanding dramatically across sub-Saharan Africa but is unavailable in Liberia, West Africa; however, planning for its introduction has begun. To inform a PrEP roll-out that is preference sensitive, accepted, and sustained for the key population of Liberian adolescent girls and young women, we will undertake a comprehensive assessment of perceptions related to PrEP among these girls and women, as well their male partners and healthcare providers. The results of this investigation will be directly applied to PrEP programming and inform the crafting of intervention strategies that can be piloted and tested so to have maximal opportunity to reduce HIV acquisition by these girls and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Musculoskeletal disorders are some of the most common in the US. Skeletal stem cells harbor massive therapeutic potential, but we know almost nothing about their identity, location, and function within their endogenous environment. Here, we will use state-of-the-art single-cell technologies to precisely transcriptionally and spatially pinpoint these cells and define their cellular contribution to tissue maintenance and repair, facilitating the development of targeted strategies to promote bone regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple myeloma (MM) is an incurable cancer of plasma cells that is always preceded by an asymptomatic phase comprised of pre-cancerous plasma cells such as in monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), or smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM). Given the incurable nature of MM, this project aims to measure the levels of select metabolites in the bone marrow plasma of patients with a spectrum of plasma cell disorders via mass-spectrometry-based approaches so as to distinguish between pre-cancerous and cancerous plasma cells. Ultimately, the knowledge gained from this study will help lower the risk of morbidity and mortality in the general population who remain at risk of developing MM from entities with pre- cancerous plasma cells such as MGUS and SMM; this study will also lay the basis of developing novel strategies in the future to prevent this progression of pre-cancerous plasma cells to MM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using bacteriophage T4 as a model, we will elucidate the structures, functions, and mechanisms by which a viral genome is packaged, stored, and released into a new host in a precisely regulated fashion. We will harness this basic knowledge to create a novel gene therapy vehicle that can deliver a large amount of therapeutic genetic payload into human cells to treat or cure muscular dystrophy, a debilitating disease for which there is currently no cure or effective treatment. This translational research proposal therefore would establish proof of concept for a new and potentially transformative category of bacteriophage-based gene therapeutics to treat/cure many human diseases in the future.

PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed project responds to one of the high-priority research topics in NIA, entitled “Common Mechanisms and Interactions Among Neurodegenerative Diseases” (NOT-AG-18-048 for PAR-19-070). Somatodendritic accumulation of tau and further mislocalizaiton to dendritic spines are two common features in AD and multiple ADRDs. We will utilize a newly established mTBI model as a novel tool to clarify the common mechanisms underlying tau mislocalization and associated functional deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Mutations in GDAP1 are associated with the peripheral neuropathy Charcot-Marie-Tooth with underlying con- nections to oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction. Here we propose to determine the structure of GDAP1 bound to 4-hydroxynoneal, which we have discovered as the first biologically binding partner con- nected to oxidative stress. This structure and related biochemistry to determine whether GDAP1 has enzymatic activity, pinpoint the ligand binding site, and reveal conformational changes in GDAP1 concomitant to binding.

PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance The cardiovascular health of Hispanic/Latino sexual and gender minorities has been understudied. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is increasing evidence that the progression to psychosis is dynamic and protracted, that cognitive dysfunction is a core feature of schizophrenia with typical maturation throughout adolescence, and that working memory depends partly on widely distributed cortical glutamate- and GABA-mediated neural circuitry. However, connecting the molecular underpinnings of disruptions in this circuitry to in vivo human brain development has been elusive. This integrative project utilizes novel neuroimaging methods and publicly available brain-wide transcriptomic atlases to investigate neurodevelopmental mechanisms of psychosis risk in a prospective longitudinal cohort of youth at clinical high risk for psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Despite aggressive treatment of known risk factors, coronary artery disease (CAD) is still responsible for one in every six deaths in the United States. Evidence from gene expression in diseased human coronary arteries and human genetic studies strongly implicates the gene TWIST1 in CAD. This project will determine the mechanisms by which TWIST1 affects vascular wall biology and thus CAD risk, with the goal of developing novel treatments to reduce the burden of CAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allergies are a risk factor for the development of asthma, and most cases of asthma are allergic in origin, but not all individuals with allergies develop asthma symptoms. Recently it has been recognized that airway lining cells and their interactions with airway immune cells are critical determinants of asthma, but the mechanisms that link changes in the airway lining to airway inflammation in asthmatics are not understood. Our theory is that certain environmental exposures can reprogram airway lining cells and immune cells, causing these cells to respond more robustly upon subsequent exposures; this reprogramming is known as trained immunity, and the objective of this proposal is to determine if trained immunity in the airway lining cells, and immune cells distinguishes whether someone with allergies develops asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The gut microbiota is an important environmental factor that contributes to the development of obesity, a major health problem linked to cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome/diabetes, and some cancers. Building upon prior findings, we will investigate the specific bacterial and host factors that facilitate the uptake and metabolism of fats. Our studies will promote our understanding of how specific gut microbes impact obesity and will identify novel strategies to combat this public health epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The dramatic rise in drug overdose deaths over the last two decades has been driven, in part, by the proliferation of potent, highly toxic synthetic drugs. Here, we propose developing an improved technology for the detection and identification of these drugs in toxicology cases. This technology will better enable medical examiners, coroners, and public health departments to understand the causative agents in drug overdose cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Standard of care for systemic lupus erythematosus involves the use of non-specific immunosuppressants or anti- inflammatory drugs to control symptoms. Unfortunately, the efficacy of these conventional therapies is substandard, and continuous use has the potential to cause serious side effect. In this proposal, we will investigate a novel paradigm for the treatment of lupus, whereby modulators of the protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2 are delivered directly to the spleen with the goal of eliciting a systemic therapeutic effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work will further develop and advance sensitive, non-invasive, non-ionizing, three-dimensional imaging methods to measure regional lung function using inhaled hyperpolarized xenon-129 gas. Specifically we focus on the evaluation of toddlers and preschool-age hematopoietic stem-cell transplant (HSCT) patients who are at significant, elevated risk for deadly lung complications post-HSCT but are too young to perform clinical lung-function testing. 129Xe MRI will address the unmet need for better diagnostic strategies for early lung- function abnormalities in very young children, leading to personalized clinical management, early intervention, and ultimately, improved patient outcomes across the entire spectrum of pediatric lung conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: During aging and diseases of aging, the ability to use memory to guide behavior becomes impaired, often causing severe reduction in independence and quality of life. Our understanding of the neural processes that allow memories to shape ongoing behavior is limited, and we know even less about how they change over aging. This project will use large-scale multi-electrode hippocampal recordings and real-time manipulation of memory-related neural processes in order to understand how memories are used to guide behavior in both young adult and aged subjects and to develop methods to directly counter age-related dysfunction of memory processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE NARRATIVE  Burkholderia cepacia complex (Bcc), consisting of more than 20 species of Gram-negative bacteria, poses a major threat to public health and causes severe opportunistic lung infections in up to 5% of cystic fibrosis (CF) patients worldwide. The colonization of Bcc poses a substantial threat to CF patients marked by rapid heath decline and difficult treatment due to their intrinsic resistance to antibiotics and antimicrobial peptides. Our research proposes to investigate the novel attachment mechanism involved in the bacterial surface protein Sap1Bcc and its host cell receptor GPNMB, which is fundamental to the understanding of Bcc pathogenesis and will eventually aid in the improvement of therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Symptoms of insomnia are common in people with Crohn’s disease and may predict greater likelihood of disease flare, surgery, hospitalization, and reduced quality of life. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is highly effective for treating insomnia and may reduce chronic pain and inflammation, both significant problems in Crohn’s disease. In the proposed mixed methods study, we seek to investigate the feasibility, acceptability, and impact CBT-I in 60 adults with Crohn’s disease in order to improve understanding of treatment of insomnia, pain, and inflammation and inform the development of a rigorous NIH R01 application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Poor sense of smell affects about 25% of older US adults. The proposed study will generate novel and important knowledge on the potential profound health implications of poor olfaction in older adults, including but not limited to dementia and Parkinson’s disease. This knowledge will benefit public health by advancing our understanding of how a poor sense of smell may affect the health of older adults, and thus improve their health, quality of life, and longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorders present a devastating and major public health concern and are marked by behaviors such as a compulsive desire to use opioids despite negative consequences, severe withdrawal symptoms upon drug abstinence and incredibly high relapse rates. More knowledge is needed about the specific brain circuits and cell types that express the mu opioid receptor through which opioids act. This proposal will investigate the properties of such cells and circuits, with the ultimate goal of building upon these findings to uncover new therapies to mitigate opioid abuse and relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Hedgehog (Hh) pathway plays a central role in directing cellular proliferation, differentiation, and patterning choices in the context of embryonic development, tissue regeneration, and cancer. The research proposed here will identify new regulatory modules of the Hh pathway and define the mechanisms that alter target cell sensitivity to Hh ligands. Advances in this area will provide a more comprehensive understanding the mechanisms that regulate Hh signaling and identify new strategies for future pathway targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Global climate change is expected to have significant consequences for the health and wellbeing of affected populations, especially for individuals who are older and (or) economically marginalized. We use demographic and health surveys from Indonesia and Mexico, combined with high-resolution climate records, to measure the effects of climate exposures during early childhood, adolescence, and early adulthood on health, economic, and migration outcomes in older adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project to understand the unique behavior of jawbones, based on our preliminary data demonstrating that osteoblasts from jawbone respond to Bone morphogenic protein (BMP) signaling and mechanical stress very differently from osteoblasts from long bone. We will identify “crossover” points of these pathways using a newly emerged proximity labeling technology to mechanistically connect growth factor signaling and mechanosensing signaling pathway unique in the jawbone. Taken together, completion of the proposed study will provide novel aspects of molecular insights to understand skeletal homeostasis in jawbone and thus provide better ideas for physical and pharmacologic interventions towards pathological conditions specific for jawbone, such as osteonecrosis in the jaw and alveolar ridge augmentation by BMPs upon dental implant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Standard behavioral treatment for adolescent obesity produces minimal weight loss, indicating it misses a key maintaining factor. One possible maintaining factor for adolescent obesity is sleep disturbance, which drives poor decision-making and subsequently, problematic eating behavior/weight gain. Our study aims to integrate a behavioral sleep treatment with lifestyle modification for adolescent obesity to improve outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allergies, asthma, and other immune hypersensitivities during pregnancy are thought to contribute to the cause and severity of neurodevelopmental disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Disruption of mechanisms regulating emergency myelopoiesis (EM) pathways, in particular in response to inflammatory triggers, has significant detrimental consequences for the organism across many life stages and disease contexts, making EM pathways prime mechanisms to target for translational applications. A major barrier in turning these findings into therapeutic strategies is our lack of understanding of EM pathways contributions to many pathophysiological situations. Our research project seeks to remove this roadblock by investigating the contribution of EM pathways to adaptive and maladaptive myelopoiesis associated with immune deregulations, solid cancers, and blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BOYD-SHIWARSKI Studies have shown a significant decline in dietary potassium intake over the past several decades and estimate that 98% of the US population is now deficient in dietary potassium—this deficiency has been attributed to the rise in processed food, decreased intake of fruits and vegetables, and the agriculture soil depletion of potassium. There is an urgent and compelling need to study the health consequences of inadequate potassium intake, specifically how it relates to chronic kidney disease. The purpose of this project is to develop new cell culture methodology using innovative 3D bioprinting technology to isolate the pathological effects of low potassium on the kidney’s proximal tubule.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Syphilis screening during prenatal care visits is a significant public health need given the increasing prevalence, impact on women's and infant's health, and links with adverse birth outcomes and other health conditions across the life course. Recent increases in congenital syphilis infections have warranted state-level policy changes in prenatal screening recommendations to reduce these outcomes; however, barriers and facilitators to implementing these policies into clinical practice remain unknown. This project aims to address this gap by assessing the multilevel determinants that influence implementation of syphilis screening policies and identify implementation strategies for obstetric providers to facilitate translation of these policies into clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The blood-brain barrier blocks nearly 98% of small molecules and nearly all macromolecules and proteins, preventing the entry of most therapeutics that are designed to target and treat neurological, psychiatric, or other central nervous system disorders. Here, we will further investigate our newly designed peptide conjugation strategy that can be used to deliver macromolecules and proteins efficiently across the BBB, as demonstrated in our preliminary data. This project will characterize the distribution and excretion of our modified proof-of- principle fluorescent protein following its administration to wild-type and target-protein knockout mice to further demonstrate the safety and efficiency of our method.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Randomized trials are the gold standard for assessing interventions for preventing and treating cancer, but even a well-designed and well-executed trial can fail to replicate outside of the study if characteristics of the trial sample and the target population differ in ways related to the effectiveness of the intervention. This project will develop a novel method of assessing the generalizability of trial results to external populations when factors that are associated with treatment effects are unmeasured in the trial. This work will have broad applicability beyond cancer trials, as generalizability is a universal concern of randomized trials across application areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Microbial keratitis (MK) therapy by eye drops has many deficiencies including high frequency dosing and low dose delivery to target tissues of about 1-5%. We propose to develop drug eluting contact lenses capable of delivering about 50% dose to target tissues, allowing replacement of tedious drop therapy involving multiple drops each day with the use of a single contact lens for 3-days therapy, followed by another lens for 3-days, if needed. The proposed research aims to manufacture and characterize novel nanobarrier lenses and measure in vivo drug release and efficacy in an animal model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Staphylococcus aureus produces nano-sized extracellular membrane vesicles (MVs) with cargo that includes cytoplasmic and membrane proteins, as well as secreted virulence factors. This project aims to investigate the generation of S. aureus MVs in vivo in models of staphylococcal infection to better understand their contributions to pathogenesis. Results from this project will further our understanding of S. aureus MVs and may lead to new strategies for the treatment and diagnosis of S. aureus infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) is the most common form of dementia affecting the elderly population. Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE4) is recognized as the strongest risk factor for LOAD. How ApoE4 exerts this effect on LOAD remains unclear. The purpose of this project is to evaluate the effects of ApoE genotype on a new state-of-the-art ‘gene-edited’ rat model for the LOAD to more accurately investigate the pathogenesis of this condition and to provide a vital new preclinical model to the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The success of pathogen transmission by mosquitoes is partly determined by the insect immune system. This project is aimed at a partial elucidation of the extracellular network of serine proteases and their noncatalytic homologs in a major vector species, which yields pehnoloxidases and reactive compounds to kill the invading pathogens. Acquired knowledge may be applied for disrupting human disease transmission in mosquitoes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We have discovered a molecule from the microbiome that enhances checkpoint blocking therapy in 2 experimental models of cancer. This molecule is a glycolipid that is found on anaerobic gram-negative bacteria that live in the intestine and is a tetraacylated monophosphorylated analog of lipid A (4A1P-MPLA). Using a synthetic form of 4A1P-MPLA that enhances regulatory T cells in the gut, we will determine mechanisms of action and breath of therapeutic targets.
