IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because it will provide critical insight into how smartphone- or computer- based software can be used to help transgender people train their voices. Transgender people often wish to modify their voice to match their gender, but voice training administered by experts is expensive and often inaccessible. Our project will thus create and evaluate the first transgender voice training software that combines real-time information about vocal pitch and resonance with structured exercises.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity has well-established profound nutritional and public health consequences, including diabetes, obesity, and cardiometabolic disease. The negative physical and mental health consequences of water insecurity are just beginning to emerge but have never been examined among children or adolescents; water insecurity also plausibly exacerbates food insecurity. We will therefore examine the concurrent role of water and food insecurity among US children and adolescents, and measure how they interact to affect sugar-sweetened bev- erage intake and cardiometabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Life and Death in the Nursery will analyze the emergence of a new subspecialty – neonatology – and the medical technologies employed by neonatologists from the 1960s to the present, centering the experiences of clinicians and parents who met in the NICU as they operated and interacted in the ever- changing world of this new specialty. I will investigate how health care providers and parents experienced the NICU, how it shaped their identity, and what impact their personal position and understanding of neonatology had on their clinical experiences. The book will focus on the impact that changes in medical technologies, reproductive politics, our understanding of disabilities, and attitudes about race had on clinical care and the ways these changes shaped medicine in the NICU, thereby shedding light not only on the history of neonatology, but also pointing to ongoing dilemmas in medicine: decisions about the continuation/ discontinuation of therapies at the edges of life and death, as well as the pervasive existence of health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The two-year randomized controlled trial, the CALERIE study, demonstrated that calorie restriction (CR) has the potential to attenuate aging and improve cardiometabolic health in humans. The proposed project is to examine whether CR attenuates mitochondrial DNA heteroplasmic mutations over time in CALERIE participants. The proposed study will provide novel evidence to better understand the molecular underpinnings of the observed effects of CR on aging and cardiometabolic health.

PHR: Project Narrative In this collaborative project, we will develop efficient methods for the construction of 18F labeled agents using the tetrazine-trans-cyclooctene ligation. We will develop new 18F labeled trans-cyclooctenes and tetrazines as reporters for large molecule distribution in the CNS. The success of this approach will lead to a comprehensive platform for Positron Emission Tomography (PET) agent preparation and drug distribution mapping.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents with substance use disorders (SUDs) have limited access to developmentally appropriate recovery supports upon discharge from treatment, increasing their risk of relapsing and a cascade of public health consequences. Recovery high schools (RHSs) are one of the few adolescent-focused continuing care options available, providing adolescents with therapeutic and peer recovery supports in an educational setting where all students are committed to maintaining recovery from an SUD. In an effort to dislodge the continuing care barrier and advance the science of recovery support, this project will use a novel dataset and approaches to examine the long-term effects of RHS attendance on recovery outcomes and the mechanisms underlying them, producing the critical knowledge needed to inform the refinement and development of adolescent- focused continuing care and recovery supports.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Over 700,000 Americans live with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) and 90% percent depend on a functional vascular access for hemodialysis (HD) treatments. Up to 50% of arteriovenous fistulas (AVF), the preferred vascular access for HD, fail to mature after creation (be usable for dialysis) despite improvements in preoperative planning. The research proposed in this application is relevant to public health because it investigates the role of catheter-associated inflammation with failure of the fistula.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Profound sex differences exist in obesity, a growing epidemic in the United States associated with increased risk of infection and allergic disease, yet studies on sexual dimorphic mechanisms underlying these disorders are limited. We propose to investigate the crosstalk between immune and endocrine pathways underlying obesity that influences macrophage- eosinophil interactions, and whether it is regulated by sex hormones and macrophage protein RELMα. Results from this study will delineate previously unknown innate immune pathways that govern sex-specific regulation of obesity and provide novel macrophage effectors that can be targeted to treat obesity and associated co-morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative This project is significant since chronic pain is a major global health problem, a leading cause of disability, with just partially effective treatments associated with major adverse events. Thus, there is a need to develop non-pharmacological, non-invasive, and fully home-based interventions for chronic pain. An alternative is interventions that target the brain plasticity. Our proposal aims to assess the effects of these alternative neuroplasticity-targeted interventions in chronic pain, and to develop models to predict the response to the treatment based on artificial intelligence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New medications are being developed for methamphetamine use disorder (MUD) treatment at a time when treatment options are scant and dropout is high, but clinical trials evaluating new MUD medications are currently limited by only assessing abstinence or urine drug screens as endpoints. Both NIDA and the FDA have recognized abstinence as a high bar for MUD treatment, demonstrating an unmet need for a survey of patient-reported outcomes (PRO) that would expand options for measurable endpoints to address how a patient feels and functions. Since no validated PRO instrument for MUD treatment exists, the proposed study will develop and validate a PRO survey (PROMT, Patient-Reported Outcomes for Methamphetamine Treatment) intended to capture a fuller picture of the therapeutic benefits of medications for MUD and promote the continued development of new treatment products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson disease (PD) is a progressively disabling neurodegenerative disease that occurs at a frequency of 1- 2 cases per 1,000 population with a prevalence of >2% in persons over 65 years. Genetic insights, namely DNAJC13 p. N855S, now facilitate an accurate and early diagnosis, provide a target and rationale for prevention, and insightful animal models to facilitate development of novel treatments to slow or halt disease progression. This proposal aims to provide mechanistic insight into DNAJC13 p.N855S gene dysfunction characterizing a novel mouse model with respect to its alpha-synuclein and dopaminergic biology, and their relationship with neuroimmune responses in the brain. 1

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The scientific investigation of this Research Career Scientist is focused on the elucidation of the molecular bases underlying major urinary diseases, in particular bladder cancer and kidney stone. These diseases are extremely prevalent among the Veterans, and are a main reason of high medical expenses, physical and emotional suffering, morbidity, time lost from work and poor quality-of-life. Despite their prevalence and clinical challenges, relatively little is known about how these diseases arise and progress. By identifying the precise molecular events that underpin the disease processes, the Principal Investigator's laboratory has already made several important findings that have significant potential for improving the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of these diseases. The renewal application intends to continue and expand the research activities to further advance our knowledge on these important diseases in order to develop effective management strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poverty has long been recognized as an important social determinant of health, and we recently showed that large-scale, government-led cash transfer programs lead to important reductions in mortality among women and young children in low- and middle-income countries. Through this project, we seek to examine pathways that might explain these reductions using national survey data from dozens of low- and middle-income countries. At a time when many countries are considering scaling back or expanding cash transfer programs, this project has the potential to have timely public health and policy impact by producing a comprehensive, global assessment of the causal effects of cash transfers on key child and maternal health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Colorectal Cancer is one of the most frequently diagnosed and deadliest cancers in both the US and the world. Our preliminary data indicate that AlkBH8, a tRNA methyltransferase, is essential for the growth and tumor forming ability of several colorectal cancer cell lines. We will therefore study the necessity of AlkBH8 in colorectal cancer using cell and animal models and characterize the biochemistry and function of recombinant AlkBH8.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Capillary blood vessels are lined by endothelial cells that are themselves covered by vascular mural cells known as pericytes. Communication between these cells is essential for normal capillary function and, when disrupted, can precipitate disease. Despite their importance, little is known about how pericytes develop. The studies in this proposal seek to understand how pericyte development is controlled during embryogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Determining when and what the hippocampus does to support spatial memory and, thereby, healthy independent living remains a major outstanding challenge. This project will study the relevance of rearing, a ubiquitously observed but minimally studied behavior, as a marker of critical hippocampal processing. Through a combination of behavioral analysis, closed-loop optogenetic manipulation and high-density extracellular electrophysiology, this project will establish rearing as a key epoch of hippocampally-dependent spatial memory encoding and determine the relevance of these events on the precision of spatial coding in the hippocampus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For amputees, directly anchoring a prosthetic device to the bone (as in osseointegrated (OI) prostheses), much more closely matches the physiology and mechanics of a non-amputated limb, resulting in superior outcomes with regards physical function, skin-related complications, chronic pain and osseoperception. However, widespread adoption of OI prostheses to the almost 2 million US patients with limb loss has been limited, to date, by risk for infection given the transcutaneous nature of the implant. In the proposed study we will translate enormously promising home-based antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT), using an FDA-approved topical agent and light, to prevent infection in patients with OI implants by (1) optimizing and fabricating custom light tunnels that link directly to the OI abutment and (2) through an early phase clinical trial designed to demonstrate feasibility, acceptability, usability, preliminary efficacy and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH In this high-risk, high-reward project, we have assembled a uniquely qualified team to explore novel applications of FUS to improve Chimeric antigen receptor T cell (CAR-T) therapy for glioblastoma (GBM) treatment. CAR-Ts are a promising new treatment platform that allows directed targeting and killing of tumor cells. We hypothesize that FUS-mediated BBB disruption will result in increased trafficking of systemically administered B7-H3.CAR- Ts to GBM tumors; and FUS therapy will improve overall anti-tumor efficacy of B7-H3.CAR-Ts by modulating the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a serious health issue, which commonly has cognitive and mood dysfunctions, potentially from brain tissue changes resulting from impaired blood brain barrier function, which are associated with increased morbidity and mortality, early risks for dementia and Alzheimer’s disease, and reduced quality of life. We will examine whether a low-cost thiamine intervention can improve blood brain barrier function and reduce mood and cognition deficits in Type 2 diabetes mellitus adults. The findings will have direct public health implications and could reduce cognitive and mood deficits, and thus, advance the National Institutes of Health mission by dramatically impacting the morbidity, mortality, early risks for dementia, and quality of life in Type 2 diabetes mellitus patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is one of the most common nosocomial infections with significant morbidity and mortality, and biofilms on endotracheal tubes are recognized to be a leading cause of VAP, and currently there are no available options that are both treatment-effective and cost-effective to prevent VAP effectively. In this application, we aim to explore the utility of a novel optical endotracheal tube (Optical-ETT), which emits antimicrobial blue light from the ETT surface, to prevent biofilm formation and eradicate preexisting biofilm on the ETT. A successful completion of the studies this application will provide the preclinical evidence required to determine the effectiveness and safety of the Optical-ETT, and will demonstrate the functionality of a prototype system of Optical-ETT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Current inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) therapies offer insufficient long-term treatment management and have undesirable side effects, highlighting an unmet clinical need for new strategies that can sustain immune tolerance in IBD. The current proposal is aimed at understanding PD1 signaling in IBD patients, a major pathway implicated in peripheral immune tolerance, and leveraging the insights generated to maximize the efficacy of PD1 agonist monotherapy and low-dose IL-2 combination therapy in humanized IBD mouse models. The successful completion of this clinically oriented proposal has the potential to advance novel therapies for IBD and other autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The use of nucleic acids-based drugs has great potential for therapeutic applications in numerous diseases, including cancer. However, their delivery is challenging, as they face numerous biological barriers, and despite the development of many promising carrier technologies, achieving a clearer understanding of the mechanisms they employ to facilitate cell entry is in-part critical to advancing their clinical translation. Hence, the relevance of this project to public health is that it will shed new insights into our understanding of the cell entry mechanisms small protein carriers employ to target and deliver therapeutic nucleic acid-based drug cargos into cancer cells, with the potential to lead to an effective molecular targeted therapy for human cancer intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) is a rare and fatal disease that predominantly affects women. Abnormalities in pulmonary arteries, the blood vessels in the lungs, have been shown to associate with the elevated blood pressure in the lungs. This study is designed to determine the role of membrane receptors and ion channels, proteins on cell surface membrane that mediate cell growth and mobility in the cellular processes that lead to the high blood pressure in the lungs in patients with this devastating disease, and to reveal potential novel targets for therapeutic approaches to treat IPAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a prevalent vascular disease contributing to dementia in >50% of people over the age of 60 and in the majority of Alzheimer’s disease patients. CAA arises from amyloid deposits in the cerebral small blood vessels, and results in extensive neuroinflammation, vessel occlusion and vascular damage, microbleeds, and neurodegeneration. Inflammation is an important pathological component contributing to CAA progression, and this study will employ techniques in cell culture and animal models to investigate the impacts of the innate immune cell neutrophils on development of vascular damage and neuroinflammation in CAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Infections by RNA viruses continue to pose global public health challenges, yet we still only poorly- understand both the host immune responses that inhibit RNA virus replication and the strategies used by these viruses to evade such host responses. Here we characterize a novel “FACT-ETS-1 Antiviral Response (FEAR)” Pathway we discovered that restricts RNA virus replication in human cells. We will identify human immunity genes regulated by the FEAR Pathway during RNA virus infection as well as identify RNA virus-encoded factors that antagonize this host response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Specific phobias and other fear-related disorders, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), represent a major mental health problem as gold standard exposure therapy involves repeated exposure to feared stimuli, but the high levels of distress can lead to refusal to start or premature treatment termination. Recent advances in computational functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) provide a method by which individuals may be unconsciously exposed to feared stimuli, leading to effective fear reduction while eliminating a primary cause of attrition. If successful, this approach may be extended to posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and other fear-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of both adult and neonatal death in the US. Cardiac and vascular function depends on cardiac and smooth muscle electrical activity. We are using molecular, cellular, animal and human studies to understand the mechanistic basis of cardiovascular pathology resulting from altered electrical activity and to develop new specific therapies to treat such cardiovascular pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many individuals with advanced heart failure experience poor outcomes including frequent admissions to the hospital. These outcomes are worse in racial and ethnic minority groups resulting in health inequities. Health inequities are often associated with social determinants of health (SDoH), which are the economic and social conditions that influence health. This project will investigate the SDoH of individuals with advanced heart failure and determine how their SDoH may influence future hospitalizations and if patients are receiving care in alignment with their values and goals. These findings will inform current care practices and provide a foundation for future studies to support patients with advanced heart failure more holistically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Completely noninvasive neuromodulation using transcranial ultrasound stimulation (TUS) offers the promise of precisely stimulating specific targets deep in the brain, such as the nucleus accumbens for substance abuse disorders, at low power levels commonly used for diagnostic imaging studies. It is currently under active investigation in humans. However, when it comes to safety, we are compelled to examine all existing data. In particular, we seek to extend a prior analysis of TUS to the sheep brain to the examination of inflammatory cytokines and the examination of glial cells using immunohistochemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Current models of operations and research involving clinical decision support (CDS) are too site-specific, not scalable, and do not measure translational outcomes. We propose to create a collaborative infrastructure centered around reusable CDS metrics that more effectively measures clinical outcomes and compares these benefits against the tradeoffs of alert burden and fatigue. Through our collaborative approach across ten CTSA Hubs, this study will be the first to use a translational science approach to understand the impact of CDS systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Text-message-based services have the potential to greatly improve access to crisis evaluations for persons who are at risk of suicide, especially for adolescents and young adults who may be more comfortable using text-based platforms than voice-based telephone services. Utah has made a statewide text-message-based crisis service (SafeUT) available to teens and young adults since 2017. We propose to use cutting-edge machine learning techniques to identify features of rigorously anonymized SafeUT text conversations that predict key outcomes, like involvement of emergency services and loss to follow-up, and quality measures like the completion of a suicide risk assessment, in order to develop a system for evaluating and improving SafeUT services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The generation of a robust disease-specific immune response remains a critical challenge in the design of cancer immunotherapies and infectious disease vaccines. Activation of innate immune signaling pathways via synthetic mimics of pathogen-associated molecular patterns is highly promising for augmenting vaccine efficacies, but key knowledge and technological gaps remain in designing such molecules. To address these challenges, we will engineer a molecularly defined, modular “all-in-one” RNA platform for targeted combinatorial innate immune activation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Homicide is a leading cause of death during pregnancy and postpartum in the US. This project seeks to optimize health care settings as critical windows of opportunity to identify and respond to pregnant and postpartum women experiencing intimate partner violence that may lead to homicide. Finding from this study – informed by both health care providers and survivors of violence during pregnancy and postpartum – will help to establish effective and efficient practices, policies, and procedures that can protect the health and safety of women during pregnancy and beyond.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OTC and NAGS deficiency are very rare genetic diseases that cause the build-up of ammonia in the body, which can cause brain damage or death. DNA sequencing of the OTC and NAGS genes is used to diagnose patients, but often the test results are not clear because not all genetic changes cause disease. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will provide information that will help medical experts determine which genetic changes in the OTC and NAGS genes cause disease and require treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: We will develop a new experimental strategy in mice that tests variants of uncertain significance found in patients with neurodevelopmental disability (NDD), focusing on genes that cause NDD by haploinsufficiency. We will demonstrate proof of principle for the NDD gene ANKRD17 by using i-GONAD in vivo gene-editing technology to introduce hemizygous and homozygous Ankrd17 variants in zygotes and then comparing the resultant fetal phenotypes to that of Ankrd17 knockout mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a metabolic disease that can also lead to extremely serious vascular (i.e., blood vessel) disease. This project will provide novel insights as to why patients with diabetes are susceptible to developing vascular disease and will fill important gaps in our understanding of mechanisms that connect metabolic dysregulation with impaired vascular function. We will also develop novel nanomedicine to target these mechanisms for treating diabetes-associated peripheral artery disease, which has very limited therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Herpesviruses are ubiquitous human pathogens and cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. Direct antivirals have been developed solely targeting viral thymidine kinase to impede viral genome replication and antivirals of new mode of action is desperately needed to overcome emerging drug-resistant variants. We propose to develop a new antiviral therapy targeting the immune evasion viral protein, UL37, to block protein deamidation and restore host immune defense.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Aging is associated with the loss of resilience and reparative potential at the cellular level and is the most powerful risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disease. While most of the known risk factors for CV disease are susceptible to contemporary therapeutic or lifestyle interventions, there is no specific therapy that slows, prevents or reverses the impact of age on the cardiovascular system. We have assembled an integrated proposal and a multidisciplinary team to investigate systematically the pleiotropic effects of lifelong PAI-1 deficiency on cardiovascular aging. We anticipate that the studies proposed here will advance our understanding of the pivotal role of PAI-1 in aging-related cardiovascular morbidity, the molecular and epigenetic mechanisms that explain this relationship, and provide proof of principle that pharmacological inhibition of PAI-1 is a rational therapeutic approach in preventing aging-related cardiovascular disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project develops an advanced mouse model of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell cancer immunotherapy for malignant brain tumors, which has been challenging in the clinical setting because of limited ability of the CAR T cells to travel to the tumors and survive in the hostile microenvironment. We will use an immunocompetent transgenic mouse model to induce brain-intrinsic tumors via viral delivery of oncogenes into brain progenitor cells, and image the tumor growth and CAR T cell infiltration into the tumor using two-photon microscopy via a cranial window. The overarching goal of this work is to create a flexible, freely shared model that enables the study of molecular mechanisms of CAR T cell targeting against brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A substantial number of people infected with COVID-19 experience persistent debilitating symptoms for months or years after the initial infection, consistent with post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC). There is an urgent need for research that identifies effective treatment strategies for the growing number of patients with PASC, about half of whom have persistent pain. This feasibility study will lay the foundation for a large trial of acupuncture, which has been found effective for chronic pain but has not yet been studied for persons with PASC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Health Relevance Millions of human infants sustain a brain injury each year but our means to visualize cell death in their brains are limited. We have been able to image cell death in cancer and the brains of non-human primates using quantitative ultrasound (QUS). Here we propose to use QUS in typically developing neonates, and neonates with perinatal asphyxia, aiming to show that QUS features change within brain regions that suffer injury due to perinatal asphyxia and that QUS can be useful as a bedside tool to study cell death in the brains of human infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Scleroderma (systemic sclerosis) is an immune mediated fibrotic disease that results high patient morbidity and mortality due to dysfunction of the skin and internal organs. This proposal evaluates how antigen independent activation of CD4+ T cells (bystander effect) regulates fibrosis pathogenesis in mouse models. By understanding the signaling mechanisms that drive bystander T cell activation and their effects on fibroblasts, we will gain better understanding of disease pathogenesis and may identify new interventions to help improve patients’ lives.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gynecologic disorders are diagnosed in up to 30% of reproductive-aged North American women in their lifetime and they are associated with substantial morbidity, reduced quality of life, and high health care costs. The proposed study will evaluate the extent to which child abuse is associated with three highly prevalent and debilitating gynecologic diseases: uterine fibroids, endometriosis, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. The proposed research will provide important information to patients and clinicians about the importance of child abuse for development of gynecologic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endogenous thymic regeneration is a crucial process that enables restoration of immune competence after damage caused by everyday insults like stress and infection. However, thymic regenerative capacity diminishes with age and after severe injury such as that caused by chemotherapy and the conditioning required for successful hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT); leading to a prolonged period of lymphopenia that detrimentally impacts transplant outcomes. In this proposal we seek to understand the mechanisms that govern this regenerative response so that they may be exploited into rational therapeutic strategies to boost thymic function and T cell reconstitution in recipients of HCT; which could have profound beneficial effects in outcomes following HCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is a widely used ophthalmic imaging technology uniquely able to image the eye with micron resolution over a large 3-dimensional volume. The proposed research will push its performance on the cutting edge of resolution, speed, range, and field of view, and investigate applications in retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Magnetoencephalographic (MEG) imaging is a noninvasive method for mapping human brain dynamics that has been used with major success, by our group and others, to identify neural markers of HIV-related cognitive decline and cannabis use disorder. The first next-generation MEG instruments were recently released, and these systems have significantly improved the precision of dynamic functional brain mapping and enabled many longstanding questions to be rigorously tested. The proposed project will examine such questions by probing whether HIV-related cognitive decline is primarily due to cortical or subcortical aberrations and whether the seemingly beneficial effects of regular cannabis use on brain function in adults with HIV are due to alterations in cortical or subcortical dynamics and circuitry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Racial disparities in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) have been well documented and there is increasing scientific evidence that early-life education is a key modifiable risk factor for ADRD. We propose leveraging and expanding an existing cohort of autoworkers at General Motors (GM) to test the hypothesis that, despite having similar jobs and access to healthcare in midlife, access to quality education in early life will be related to ADRD risk, specifically among Black autoworkers. We will characterize the cohort’s ADRD profile by linking to Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services data, describe early life characteristics by linking to historical census data, and model the association between early life education opportunity and ADRD risk separately among Black and White autoworkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative By the year 2050, the US population over age 65 will double and the population over age 85 will increase 5-fold, so the large and increasing number of older individuals living with schizophrenia will need more effective services. Older adults with schizophrenia are at greater risk for cognitive and functional decline leading to premature institutionalization. The proposed clinical trial of a psychosocial rehabilitation intervention specifically targeting improvement in cognition and functioning in older individuals living with schizophrenia is greatly needed and could have a profound effect on patients, family members, society and the economy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes(T2D) is increasing at an alarming rate in youth and can lead to devastating long-term consequences, necessitating appropriate risk stratification and precise treatment strategies right from the onset of disease. We will use machine-learning based clinical and genomic clustering methods in existing pediatric datasets to identify groups of youth with T2D at highest risk for complications and most likely to fail metformin treatment, based on underlying biological mechanisms. These results will generate a prediction model and provide a framework for precision medicine-based dosing of metformin and other drug classes in youth with T2D.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity, characterized by an excess of adipose tissue mass, is a major risk factor for many chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and hypertension. Results from our research will provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanism(s) by which vascular endothelial growth factor-A stimulates adipose tissue activity and hence brings about metabolic benefits which will further help to identify new strategies to treat obesity and related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses a gap in clinical decision-making for the assessment of cognitive symptoms after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH; a form of stroke), a burden that is disproportionately felt by African American (AA) patients and those that reside in rural areas. Specifically, we propose to investigate the application of the Quality of Life in Neurological Disorders (Neuro-QoL) patient-reported outcome measures and, in particular, one of its components—the Neuro-QoL cognition short form—as a screening tool to support clinical decision-making and trigger individual, in-depth cognitive assessment post-aSAH. This work will improve health equity by informing new practice guidelines to provide earlier and more accurate assessment of cognitive symptomatology post-aSAH to reduce disparities and improve quality of life (QoL) for survivors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the mechanisms of brain development and detecting abnormalities in the early stage of infancy is essential for the early diagnosis of motor disabilities and the design of early intervention programs. Inherent limitations of current neuroimaging tools make large-scale monitoring of neural activity with high spatiotemporal resolution and specificity in young populations performing motor tasks challenging. The proposed study will assess the functional organization of the motor system in awake and behaving infants using functional ultrasound imaging (fUSI), a unique real-time, portable and deep brain functional imaging tool with unprecedented spatiotemporal resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer-related fatigue (CRF) is a highly prevalent and distressing symptom reported by patients that persists for many after treatment is completed, and is commonly associated with depressive symptoms, decreases in ability to work and care for family members, and decreases in quality of life. In a prospective cohort of oncology patients undergoing combined chemotherapy and radiation therapy (CCRT) with different levels of morning and evening CRF, our first objective is to evaluate for associations between phenotypic and molecular characteristics associated with changes in CRF over time to determine the underlying mechanisms for CTXRF, which could identify potential therapeutic interventions. Our second objective is to develop and evaluate a risk prediction model which would assist clinicians to determine which patients are most likely to experience high levels of CRF during and following CCRT and provide recommendations for activity modifying interventions (e.g., exercise).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People who use tampons are chronically exposing the mucosal barriers of the vagina and cervix to nanoplastics. It is currently unknown if this route of nanoplastic exposure leads to local infection and chronic health problems. Thus, for people who menstruate to make informed decisions about their use of tampons, the physiological effects of these particles coming in direct contact with vaginal and cervical tissue will be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE Recordings of local field potentials (LFPs) from deep brain stimulation (DBS) electrodes have played an important role in expanding physiological understanding of Parkinson’s disease (PD). However, fundamental questions remain unaddressed on the underlying biophysics of LFP signals. The goal of this project is to create patient-specific computational models that enable dissection of the LFP signal at the cellular-level. These research tools will be customized to PD patients implanted with DBS systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Smoke-free housing policies in multiunit housing are promising and increasingly widespread interventions to reduce smoking and secondhand smoke exposure. Little research has identified factors that impede compliance with smoke-free housing policies in low-income multiunit housing and test corresponding solutions. The proposed RCT addresses key gaps in knowledge and capitalizes on key scientific opportunities by: 1) leveraging the federal mandate to ban smoking in a public housing system of more than sufficient size to conduct an adequately powered RCT; 2) expanding our understanding of smoke-free policy compliance beyond policy implementation by testing two novel treatments: a) in-residence smoking cessation and b) resident endorsement, while 3) addressing population and location-specific tobacco-related disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because invasion and metastasis during breast cancer progression are associated with increased mortality, yet the biophysical mechanisms underlying these two processes are not well understood. Therefore, the proposed research on understanding how extracellular matrix malleability regulates the collective invasion and migration of breast cancer cells is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is anticipated that this study will uncover previously un-described modes of invasion and migration, thereby leading to new diagnostic measures of pre-invasive breast cancer and new therapeutic strategies to block invasion and metastasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A great deal of the V.A. mission involves surgical intervention after stroke, head injury and spinal cord injury. A portion of this proposal would provide guidelines to physicians making surgical decisions during reconstructive procedures. Improved efficacy of surgical procedure will greatly aid the rehabilitative process. We will also provide data useful to therapists treating patients conservatively with strength training since the physiological condition of the muscles will be defined. In both cases, these studies will affect a large fraction of the V.A. inpatient and outpatient population and, based on improved outcomes, should result in significant savings of time and energy as well as improved patient independence and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program will elucidate the organization of human brain networks engaged in speech perception using a unique combination of non-invasive and invasive experimental methods. By using direct recordings from the brains of neurosurgical patients, detailed information will be obtained that is not available using conventional non-invasive methods. This information will aid the development of novel approaches to diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitation of patients with a wide range of communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to more fully understand how the gut behaves in patients with Cystic Fibrosis. Using fruit flies as a model organism I will study both environmental factors like bacteria and genetic factors that impact the outcomes of Cystic Fibrosis in patients. This work will establish fruit flies as a model to study CF and may uncover new drug targets to treat the disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolites act as important signaling molecules in both the adipose and immune systems. A type of adipose tissue called brown fat has been shown to be anti-inflammatory but the mechanism for this is unclear. An exciting and interesting idea is that manipulating how these metabolites signal to fat and immune cells could be a new way of treating metabolic disease. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The mammalian retina does not possess the capacity to regenerate; thus, progressive retinal neuron death leads to irreversible vision loss in glaucoma optic neuropathies and other degenerative diseases of the retina and optic nerve. Cell transplantation has been proposed to restore the retinal neurocircuitry; however, current state-of-the- art studies show that most donor retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) do not integrate into the ganglion cell layer and connect with the existing host retinal neurons. This research proposal will investigate the role that Down Syndrome Cell Adhesion Molecule (DSCAM) has in directing donor RGC migration and synapse formation with their natural connecting points in the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: TDP-43 is a protein central to devastating and neurological disorders, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD). TDP-43-associated pathology is also present in Alzheimer's disease and other neurodegenerative disorders. Our work has revealed important findings on the aggregation of TDP-43 and promises to be a significant and revolutionary step forward in generating tools for effectively defining therapeutic and diagnostic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Clinical validation and translation of blood-based biomarkers is the next necessary step in our efforts to cure PPB and other DICER1-related cancers. This global partnership focuses on the clinical validation of novel circulating tumor DNA-based "liquid biopsy" assays for quantification of tumor burden and detection of treatment response in DICER1-related cancers. Development of novel biomarkers will improve outcomes for children and adults with DICER1-related cancers through early diagnosis, risk stratification and intervention and development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Head impact exposure in contact sports such as football is a rising concern, since it appears that exposure to repetitive head impacts, even if a concussion is not suspected, may be linked to brain disease later in life and changes in the brain over a single season. This K25 Mentored Quantitative Research Development Award will develop and pilot test an evidence-based intervention to reduce head impact exposure in youth football, involving coaches and parents in the development of the intervention. Formal training in organizational systems theory, intervention planning and evaluation, community engagement, and implementation monitoring will prepare the applicant to lead future studies combining public health sciences and injury biomechanics to develop, test, and improve injury prevention strategies among youth athletes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rural KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa is considered to be the epicentre of the global HIV epidemic where the level of new HIV infections remains unacceptably high. Utilising one of the largest ongoing HIV cohorts in the world, we will establish the population shift in the pattern of new HIV infections in rural KwaZulu-Natal South Africa (2022-2026). We will quantify the change in the pattern of new HIV infections in the general population following the shift towards Dolutegravir- based regimens (a new cost-effective drug enabling better treatment adherence) as well as the scaling up new of prevention interventions such as the pre-exposure prophylaxis. We will utilize this information to design future combination intervention programs which seek to maximize HIV infection reduction based on the dynamic needs of the most vulnerable sub-populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the advent of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a highly effective HIV biomedical prevention strategy, men who have sex with men (MSM) in the Deep South of the United States continue to face extraordinary rates of new HIV diagnoses. As such, innovative strategies are needed to promote PrEP and increase its uptake and use among those with the greatest need. This project will determine PrEP promotional preferences in order to develop empowering and informative PrEP promotional content that is created by community members.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Stroke is a leading cause of disability in the U.S. and many Veteran stroke survivors live with severe disability. Despite recent advances in rehabilitation treatments many stroke survivors have persistent physical and mental difficulties such as reduced physical and cognitive function and depression. Developing innovative treatments that address these problems is necessary to improve long-term outcomes for stroke survivors. Aerobic exercise (AEx) can improve physical and cognitive function, and reduce depression. Additionally, AEx may enhance physical rehabilitation by making the brain more receptive to, and consequently improving the response to an intervention. Therefore, combining AEx with physical rehabilitation has the potential to improve multiple aspects of stroke recovery. This study will examine the effect of combining AEx with physical rehabilitation on physical and mental function in stroke survivors. By gaining a better understanding of the effects of this combined intervention we aim to advance the rehabilitative care of Veteran stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Minority students are underrepresented in PhD programs and in the biomedical workforce in general. The Rush Initiative for Maximizing Student Development (IMSD) provides an innovative and a well-integrated approach to promote PhD completion by underrepresented minority (URM) biomedical students and provides IMSD participants with the tools to place them in a path of success thereafter. The program involves traditional/classical training activities for scientists including training in grant writing and oral presentations and professional development training activities such as time management and conflict resolution, to name a few. These integrated activities will enhance the skills of URM students to develop into productive scientists and professionals so that they complete the PhD program and become equipped with essential tools to navigate a rigorous career in biomedical research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: IMSD at Rush University
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - C[TWD-C]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Sjögren’s syndrome (SS), a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease that affects ~ 4 million Americans, particularly women, is characterized by hyposalivation and dacryoadenitis with lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. Our research focuses on the cell surface receptors, P2X7 and P2Y2, for extracellular ATP, the chemical form of energy in a cell that when released from injured or diseased salivary and lacrimal gland tissue causes inflammation. The overall goal of these studies is to evaluate whether antagonism of the P2X7R and/or P2Y2R can protect the salivary and lacrimal glands from tissue damage in SS patients by investigating these novel signaling pathways in mouse models of SS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Many deaf children do not acquire age-appropriate spoken language even when they receive cochlear implants at early ages and have no other cognitive disabilities. This project investigates the real-time mechanisms of parent-child social interactions in deaf children with cochlear implants and how these interactions facilitate (or hinder) word learning and language outcomes. Because social interactions may be malleable, the knowledge gained from this project could lead to the development of novel intervention studies aimed at enhancing language development in deaf children who receive cochlear implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for large majority of lung cancer that is often driven by oncogenic alterations that are either not suitable for direct targeting or treatment resistance inevitably occurs. Squalene epoxidase (SQLE), an enzyme that controls cholesterol biosynthesis, is frequently overexpressed in NSCLC and is associated with poor prognosis. The goal of our application is to develop innovative strategies of combining SQLE and ATR/CHK1 inhibition to treat NSCLC, particularly against high-SQLE expressing subsets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE PRPH2-associated disease phenotypes are complex and multifactorial, involving not just photoreceptors, as has historically been reasoned, but also secondary effects on the retinal pigment epithelium and retinal/choroidal vasculature. Understanding the mechanisms of these complicated disease phenotypes is absolutely critical for the development of treatments and for our understanding of disease mechanisms associated with other genes in which the primary defect is in photoreceptors but the disease phenotype affects multiple tissues. These studies use novel mouse models to directly address these issues in unique ways that are innovative and highly suited to our expertise and tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anxiety disorders are the most common form of mental illness, can be highly impairing, and behaviors and brain changes that are precursors of anxiety disorders might start as early as birth. The goal of this study is to measure brain activity in newborn infants in response to sudden unexpected noises and test whether this brain activity predicts which infants are likely to develop problems with anxiety later in life. The results of this study are likely to assist in the early identification of children who might develop problems with anxiety and could lead to the design of interventions that lower the risk for developing anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Transgender and nonbinary people continue to face incredibly high rates of mental health concerns, due largely to minority stress and discrimination, as well as inadequate access to affirming mental health services at most major hospitals in the United States. By assessing a large database of almost 10,000 transgender adults in the Bronx, NY, this study will explore disparities between transgender and non-transgender people’s access to quality mental health care, and will incorporate conextual information from in-depth interviews with transgender patients and affirming providers. This research will contribute to our fundamental understanding of ways healthcare systems reinforce mental health care disparities for transgender and nonbinary people, and will generate solutions to improve access to quality, affirming services at any site.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Fatty liver disease is closely associated with obesity and type-2 diabetes but without available effective drug therapies. This study investigates the mechanisms of Cullin-RING E3 ligases regulation of hepatic nutrient signaling and glucose and lipid metabolism in mouse models of obesity and fatty liver disease. In addition, this study will use pharmacological approaches to study if Cullin-RING E3 ligases can serve as potential therapeutic targets for treating lipid and glucose dysregulation in fatty liver disease and type-2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This study on the role of Shear Stress and Endothelial Pathophysiology in Intracranial Atherosclerosis uses neuroimaging tests routinely performed in patients with symptomatic intracranial atherosclerosis to develop new insight on how mechanical forces on the vessel wall are associated with cellular changes that promote inflammation and clotting that may lead to stroke. These imaging and biological markers may create a new way to prevent such strokes, a leading cause of death and adult disability worldwide. These collaborative efforts that combine unique and established expertise are urgently needed to address the lack of proven invasive or noninvasive imaging tools or treatments for intracranial atherosclerosis and the unmet risk of recurrent stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Surprising or startling events activate the locus coeruleus, a region of the brain that controls arousal and is thought to aid subsequent perception and discrimination through modulation of sensory processing in the cortex. This modulation of the cortex is normally beneficial, but it can become dysregulated in disorders such as insomnia, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder. By exploring the mechanisms through which arousal shapes sensory processing, we hope to better understand the normal and pathological roles of arousal and highlight novel targets for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants in the gene CRX can cause inherited retinal diseases that lead to vision loss and blindness, but many CRX genetic variants are uncharacterized. This proposal aims to apply Deep Mutational Scanning, a new technique for studying many genetic variants at the same time, to comprehensively identify genetic variants in CRX that cause disease. This work will produce a “look-up table” listing all possible variants in CRX by their functional activity and propensity to cause disease, and will be directly applicable to the diagnosis of patients with diseases caused by mutations of CRX.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Age-related conditions are among the most devastating and agonizing diseases worldwide, with age- related declines in fertility being among the earliest and most frequent of these conditions. My proposed research studies the mechanisms by which aging damages the germline of the planarian S. mediterranea, and determines how regeneration reverses this damage and restores the flatworms to youthful levels of fecundity. This research will help us understand why humans and other organisms are unable to reverse germline aging, and could lay the groundwork for new treatments that preserve and restore fertility even into advanced age.

We aim to develop methods that enable the multiscale mapping, functional characterization and exploitation of bacterial DNA methylation towards the discovery of novel mechanisms in individual bacteria and the mammalian gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypofunction of parvalbumin (PV)-positive inhibitory interneuron circuits and imbalanced excitation-inhibition (E-I) ratio in feedforward sensory pathways likely contribute to abnormal sensory processing, including tactile hypersensitivity, in Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs), but the source of PV circuit hypofunction, the molecular mechanisms involved, and the generalizability beyond feedforward circuits remains unclear. I will address these knowledge gaps by asking: (1) Does PV hypofunction arise from defective homeostatic plasticity within PV circuits, possibly related to a broad impairment of cellular homeostasis in ASD? (2) What transcriptional and translational mechanisms mediate PV circuit homeostasis, are these abnormal in ASDs, and can they be rescued by novel CRISPR-based strategies? (3) Do top-down feedback sensory projections exhibit abnormal PV inhibition? Answering these questions will provide fundamental new knowledge about the mechanisms and commonalities of PV circuit deficits in multiple genetic models of ASD, and may lead to new therapeutic approaches to normalize cortical circuit function across ASDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chagas disease is a major vector borne parasitic disease caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, and our long-term goal is to develop a human therapeutic vaccine, to improve the control of Chagas disease. We propose to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a therapeutic vaccine formulation against T. cruzi infection in naturally infected rhesus macaques, alone and in combination with a low dose benznidazole, in a non-inferiority trial design compared with conventional benznidazole treatment. This work will be a major step towards clinical trials, and ultimately will lead to improved patient care and control of this important disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed research investigates the interconnection between the circadian clock and lipid metabolism, and the results will advance fundamental knowledge underlying the molecular and signaling mechanisms that regulate clock function, lipid production, and stress responses. This work will provide novel insights into the molecular process leading to metabolic and physiological dysfunctions associated with clock misalignments and disruptions. This outcome is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately improving human health.

PHR: The Research Innovation in NeuroScience Education for Underserved Populations (RISE UP) program will support our efforts to equip outstanding undergraduate students from diverse and/or under-privileged backgrounds with research, professional, and social-emotional skills to thrive in cutting-edge neuroscience graduate programs. RISE UP scholars will be engaged in a rigorous summer program in neuroscience that will not only allow them to strengthen their research and professional development skills but will also address socio-emotional and cultural issues that may be unique to them. This innovative approach allows us to intervene early on in the educational pipeline and arm our undergraduate scholars with the necessary tools to adjust to the diverse rigors of graduate school.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-exposed infants are at higher risk of adverse birth outcomes such as stillbirth, preterm delivery, small size for gestational age, and neonatal death than HIV-unexposed infants, and untreated co-infection with chlamydia or gonorrhea during pregnancy contributes substantially to these adverse birth outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa, including in Botswana. The proposed research will first use computer simulation modeling to estimate the clinical and economic impacts of chlamydia and gonorrhea infection among pregnant women with HIV in Botswana. We will next evaluate the cost-effectiveness of antenatal chlamydia and gonorrhea screening to improve maternal health; reduce mother-to-child transmission of HIV, chlamydia, and gonorrhea; and prevent adverse birth outcomes in Botswana.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) affects over 12 million people worldwide, typically resulting in kidney failure in the fourth to seventh decade of life. Disease severity is affected by the degree of functional loss of the Polycystin-1 protein encoded by the primary disease gene PKD1. Building on a successful approach in other fields and data supporting dramatic benefit from proof-of-concept studies increasing PKD1 expression, this proposal will evaluate the extent to which blockade of PKD1 upstream open reading frame (uORF) translation can quantitatively increase functional PKD1 expression in vitro and characterize the clinical importance of this intervention on reducing cyst burden in mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Childhood internalizing problems predict future social, health, and academic impairment; the tremendous burden of internalizing problems is disproportionately borne by girls. The proposed study will use multimodal time series data to evaluate how parents respond emotionally and physiologically to their daughters’ expressions of dysphoria and anger, during discussions of experiences of sadness and/or worry. Moment-to-moment parent emotion socialization (ES) processes may be altered by girls’ internalizing problems, constituting maladaptive cycles that reinforce the unusually strong and persistent experience of dysphoria associated with internalizing problems; these ES processes can then be investigated as a prospective risk processes for the onset of internalizing disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While emotional well-being (EWB) promotes positive health across the lifespan, little is known about how to best increase EWB in ways that lead to downstream improvements in health. The goal of this network is to develop research resources and foster a cohesive community of interdisciplinary scholars focused on discovering which aspects of EWB are most tightly linked to physical health, which interventions most effectively increase EWB, and the biobehavioral processes that explain how EWB impacts health. The network leadership team unites three major research institutions (UCSF, Harvard, UC Berkeley), bringing together the infrastructure and scientific expertise in measurement, intervention development, and dissemination, needed to advance the science of well-being and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The enteric nervous system regulates intestinal motility and regulates local homeostatic functions. Defects in enteric nervous system development lead to debilitating conditions such as Hirschsprung disease, in which neurons are gone from regions of the gut, and those who suffer from this anomaly suffer from intestinal obstruction and/or severe constipation. This research proposal will enhance our knowledge of the fundamental genetic and cellular mechanisms that regulate early development of the neural progenitor cells that give rise to the enteric nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High food motivation among children is trait-like and increases risks of unhealthy dietary intake and obesity. Scientific knowledge of how parenting can best support healthy eating habits and growth among children who are predisposed to overeating is surprisingly limited. This investigation will provide the first comprehensive evidence of supportive food parenting approaches for obesity prevention that address the needs of highly food motivated children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is an unmet need to understand the cellular processes co-opted during human coronavirus replication, with an emphasis on identifying mechanisms underlying severe disease and potential therapeutic targets. Our preliminary data demonstrate that the host protein IRE1α plays a critical role in SARS-CoV-2 replication and cytokine responses. This proposal aims to understand how IRE1α contributes to severe COVID-19, and determine whether IRE1α represents a prognostic marker and therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multifactorially inherited neural tube defects (NTDs) are common structural birth defect whose prevalence has been reduced, but not eliminated by folic acid supplementation. Recent work suggests that folic acid non- responsive NTDs may be the result of abnormal mitochondrial folate transport. Our proposed research program will provide the molecular, cellular and genetic relationships of multiple gene networks related to the etiology of folate responsive and resistant NTDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Despite strong gene regulatory mechanisms there are often large cell-to-cell differences in gene expression between genetically identical cells. We aim to study the molecular mechanisms that generate these cell-to-cell differences in gene expression. These mechanisms help diversify cell types during normal development, contribute to chemotherapeutic resistance of cancer cells, and can be harnessed to improve practical applications that require uniform outcomes among cells.

PHR: Improving the care of AD and related dementias is a national challenge, which demands integrated multidisciplinary approaches. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative The VA provides care for approximately 26% of individuals with SCI in the U.S. Treatment costs are 6.5 times higher than the cost of treatment of an average Veteran, and effective therapies for this disorder are lacking. This project aims to evaluate the efficacy of 3D printed biomimetic scaffold, loaded with human neural progenitor cells and implanted sub-acutely, in a long-term clinically relevant, non-human primate model of cervical spinal cord contusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Pyrazinamide is a cornerstone drug used in the treatment of tuberculosis due to its ability to shorten treatment times and reduce relapse rates. Unlike all other antitubercular drugs, pyrazinamide is only active against tubercle bacilli under specific environmental conditions in vitro and in vivo. The focus of this project is to understand the basis for conditional antitubercular action of pyrazinamide in order to develop new approaches for improving its therapeutic activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Pain is a complex sensation realized by most individuals at some point in his or her lives and the opioid receptor pathway has been identified to be involved in the regulation of pain management. The goal of this research project is characterize the opioid G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) N-terminal domains that are postulated to modify the opioid receptor functional response. The impact of the anticipated results on the medicinal chemistry and pain research fields could advance the existing paradigms for ligand design strategies for opioid receptor based therapeutics, GPCR based therapeutics, as well as provide novel tools to probe pain management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use and homelessness are inter-connected public health risk factors that contribute to and exacerbate health disparities. The proposed research, which is a community-based trial of a voluntary smoke- free home intervention to formerly homeless adults in permanent supportive housing seeks to mitigate these disparities by increasing voluntary adoption of smoke-free homes and increasing access to smoking cessation services. The study will assess the intervention’s efficacy and cost-effectiveness, and evaluate its potential for scalability and sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this work is to transform dysphonic voice quality assessment in clinical practice and in research by establishing new psychometric scales that accommodate sustained phonation and connected speech. The multidimensional scales will be designed and evaluated with the goals of high validity, reliability, sensitivity, specificity, and most importantly, the responsiveness to change. These methods also will support development of precise, reliable and automated computational models of voice quality perception.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Incarcerated pregnant women experience numerous sociodemographic and behavioral risks, which can compromise their health and the health of their infants. The proposed project is likely to have high public health impact by identifying key facilitators and barriers to implementing pregnancy and postpartum support programs in prisons, and documenting the outcomes among incarcerated women who receive these services. The project is relevant to the NICHD’s mission to ensure that every person is born healthy and that women suffer no harmful effects from reproductive processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the results will have immediate positive impact for children with neonatal seizures due to early brain injury, their families, and the providers who care for them. Through this study, we will take innovative steps to understand the multifaceted genetic contributors to epilepsy after neonatal seizures. The proposed research is directly relevant to the NIH mission, which calls for the development of methods to enhance health and reduce illness and disability, to seek fundamental knowledge about the brain and nervous system, and to use that knowledge to help all children to achieve their full potential through reduction of the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project with apply novel generalizable methods in algorithmic fairness to examine unfairness among African-Americans in a commonly used predictive algorithm at the Veterans Health Administration and develop approaches to mitigate it. This project will yield an algorithmically fair algorithm that will incorporate data related to social determinants of health into the predictive algorithm. The study will also examine the impact of mitigating algorithmic unfairness on expected African-American enrollment in VA clinical programs targeting high-risk Veterans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of metabolic diseases such as obesity and diabetes has risen to epidemic proportions. Poor muscle growth resulting from intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) contributes to lifelong reductions in muscle mass (sarcopenia), obesity, and diabetes risk. This project will determine the molecular mechanisms responsible for reduced fetal skeletal muscle growth, so that nutritional strategies can be targeted to improve muscle growth in IUGR fetuses and neonates.

PHR: Project Narrative Zoonotic viruses such as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) can cause rare but deadly outbreaks among domesticated animals and human populations. Our proposed work will define critical host factors for virus entry and identify novel targets that will facilitate therapeutic development. Recent outbreaks and the emerging nature of the mosquito vectors for RVFV, coupled with a rising potential of misuse in the form of bioterrorism, underscore the importance of the proposed studies to global health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis and ischemic myocardial infarction (MI) are two critical illnesses with very high mortality. The goal of this research program is to address a unique function of extracellular microRNA in innate immune activation, tissue inflammation, organ injury, and cardiac dysfunction in sepsis and cardiac ischemia. The research supported by this grant will improve our understanding of the mechanism and treatment of these diseases as well as miRNA biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thousands of rare Variants of Uncertain Significance (VUS) exist in transmembrane proteins associated with Mendelian disease, representing a major challenge for genomic medicine. I will deploy integrative phenotyping methods in a large biobank and test the in vitro function of transmembrane variants at multiple levels of scale, from low to high-throughput. This work will establish a pipeline for reclassifying transmembrane VUS's to (likely) benign or pathogenic and result in the identification of many new disease-associated variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The National Drug Abuse Treatment Clinical Trials Network (CTN) conducts clinically relevant research on the treatment of substance use disorders in real-world settings, with an increasing emphasis on conducting studies in general medical settings. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Simultaneous replication and transcription of the same DNA template leads to collisions between the replication and transcription machineries, and to the incorporation of large numbers of ribonucleotides into the genome – both of which may be a significant source of DNA damage in eukaryotes. One project will characterize the mechanisms through which two nuclear RNA polymerases responsible for transcription – RNAP2 and RNAP3 – impede replication, and the molecular basis for DNA damage at conflict sites. The other project investigates how ribonucleotides mis-incorporated during DNA replication impact genome structure and function, and how they are repaired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stuttering is a neurodevelopmental disorder with profound consequences for communication and quality of life. This project will take an innovative multimodal neuroimaging approach to elucidate speech sound processing in children who stutter by combining neurophysiological, functional magnetic resonance imaging, and systems- level computational modeling approaches. A mechanistic understanding of speech sound processing and the ways in which these processes are modulated by task demands will facilitate future development of neurobiologically informed stuttering interventions that target specific neural deficits in children who stutter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke and spinal cord injury are leading causes of chronic disability world-wide. Recent evidence suggests peripheral motoneurons and skeletal muscle are remodeled following central nervous system injury and identifies an understudied area for therapeutic development. This project will investigate how central nervous system injury impacts the neuromuscular system and how the associated mechanisms of disability can be targeted using gene therapy to facilitate functional recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with type 1 diabetes suffer chronic complications and are at risk of life-threatening episodes of hypoglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis. Therapies that increase the number of residual β-cells have been proposed as a strategy to delay or reverse insulin dependence in people with prediabetes or in the “honeymoon” phase of the disease. This research will address whether changes to β-cell metabolism impact the effectiveness of such therapies, opening the possibility for combined drug and dietary interventions to prevent or reverse disease progression.
