IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Staphylococcus aureus poses a significant health burden, thwarting novel drug development, defying hospital infection prevention practices, and circumventing public health measures. The successful development of a universal vaccine will afford the only durable solution to S. aureus infection at a population level. The proposed research will investigate the human adaptive immune response to S. aureus as a function of development and S. aureus exposure in infancy and early childhood and will ultimately inform the approach to vaccine design and implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is still a major cause of death partially because we do not understand how antibodies protect. We recently found that natural killer (NK) cells could kill infected RBCs via antibody mediated cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), and in an endemic malaria cohort, specific NK cells enhanced for ADCC activity correlated with decreased parasitemia and protection from malaria. This proposal builds on our findings to understand how these specific NK cells form and function, as well as understand how antibodies function to protect humans from malaria with the hope to improve vaccine design and efficacy readouts.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Animals interpret complex sensory environments using both instinct and memories of past experiences. In- stinctual odor processing occurs in a region of the brain where the inborn structure of connections among neurons generates meaning, while learned processing occurs in a separate brain area where unstructured neuronal connections gain meaning through experience This project explores how neurons make unpre- dictable connections with one another during the development of an olfactory learning center in the fruit fly brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Peripheral artery disease occurs when impaired blood flow to the tissue results in pain, decreased mobility, amputations, and increased mortality. Supervised exercise is one of the most effective treatments at improving patient’s quality of life, yet the mechanisms for how it works are not well understood. This proposal investigates satellite cells, a muscle stem cell, as the potential mediator of this process and understanding changes in the satellite cell’s biology with exercise will allow us to develop better therapies to treat the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic respiratory disease is a major public health issue that may arise from perinatal environmental metals, a research area that has not been well studied. We will use innovative metal exposure measures in deciduous teeth to determine early life critical windows when lung growth trajectories are susceptible to environmental metals and their mixtures. We will also assess mitochondrial DNA heteroplasmy in nasal epithelium to quantify cumulative oxidative stress, a proposed mechanism underlying our findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Mtb-specific Th1 cells alone do not predict protection against tuberculosis (TB), suggesting that although Th1 cells are required for controlling Mtb replication, other types of immune cells may be needed to prevent infection and eradicate the bacteria. We recently found a distinct subset of CD4+ T cells, IL-9-producing CD4+ T cells (Th9), can mediate protective immunity against Mtb infection, and therefore propose in this application to investigate the effects of Mtb-specific Th9 cells on protective TB immunity; define the roles of IL-9 in vaccine-induced protection against Mtb infection; identify the source for IL-9 in PBMC and BAL cells from BCG vaccinated individuals, the influence and mechanisms of Mtb-specific Th9 cells on bacterial growth in human macrophages. These studies will have a significant impact on improving our understanding of host protective immune mechanisms against Mtb infection, and provide the rationale for targeting Mtb-specific Th9 cells as a new strategy for more effective TB vaccines and/or immunotherapies against Mtb infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this basic science proposal is to answer fundamental questions about how brain networks interact during the course of navigational learning. We are interested in how active decision making during learning offers an advantage compared to passive guidance, particularly when it comes to learning the path connections between locations. Our focus is the prefrontal-hippocampal-striatal (PHS) circuit, which is particularly relevant to mental disorders involving reinforcement and reward learning, including depression, Parkinson’s Disease, drug addiction, obsessive compulsive disorder, and attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) affect nearly 1.5 million people in the US alone. Since many aspects of the disease pathology are not entirely understood, it is no surprise that many patients either do not respond to symptom-focused therapies or suffer a relapse of the disease after initial success. This proposal focuses on an unexplored facet of IBD: the contribution of nitric oxide generated by gut microbiota as a contributor to the pathophysiology of these diseases in the host, and may identify novel therapeutic targets and treatment strategies for IBD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital heart disease (CHD) affects 1% of live births, with one quarter of cases requiring surgical correction in the first year of life. More than 75% of CHD patients receive off-label cardiovascular medications to manage postoperative arrhythmias and low cardiac output. We will investigate the impact of myocardial immaturity on cardiac drug responsiveness, using both large animal models and cardiac tissue procured from CHD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer associated rearrangements of the ROS1 gene produce oncogenic ROS1 fusion proteins that aggressively drive tumor growth, and are actionable with targeted pharmaceutical agents. Some tumors have ROS1 mutations that are another type of cancer-associated genetic aberration, but the impact of these mutations on ROS1 function or its contribution to tumor growth is currently unknown. Our goal is to rigorously characterize ROS1 and its functions in cancer, as this may pinpoint additional biomarkers of drug-sensitivity, and potentially expand the benefit of ROS1 targeted therapy in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intrinsically disordered proteins and regions (IDPs/IDRs) challenge the structure-function paradigm, taking advantage of their disordered state for functional discrete and large-scale associated interactions with numerous partners. Disorder is enriched in regulatory and disease-linked proteins, such as those involved in autism and cancer. The proposed research will develop and apply state-of-the-art computational and experimental methods to elucidate structural ensembles of IDP/IDR dynamic complexes and biological condensates related to regulation of RNA translation and elasticity. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall goals of the proposed Career Development Award (K01) are to investigate the relationship between cognition and health promoting behaviors, clarify the moderating role of positive resources, and to determine the cumulative impact of these interactions on quality of life for older adults experiencing stress while living with HIV. Older adults living with HIV have greater risks for cognitive impairment which can negatively impact the ability to engage in behaviors that benefit health. A greater understanding of the factors that promote healthy behaviors despite cognitive impairment is needed in order to address the needs of the aging population of individuals living with HIV and the corresponding public health burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) causes significant disease in individuals with weakened immune systems. How HCMV can replicate so efficiently in the face of host induced strong antiviral responses is not fully known. In this proposed work we will extend our exciting findings where we have identified specific host directed modification of viral proteins that result in altered antiviral responses. Characterization of the biological mechanisms controlled by these host modifications will provide insight on inhibiting HCMV and potentially other viruses in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WINIFRED MASTERSON BURKE MED RES INST
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because developmental damage to the corticospinal tract in cerebral palsy and after neonatal spinal injuries represents a significant burden to their family as well as a major cost burden to the health care system. For successful diagnosis and treatments, a critical need is to have better approaches that can accurately predict long-term movement disability in babies born with brain damage, a presently unattained goal, in part because of a lack of good mouse models to investigate this problem. Our proposed research will identify early biomarkers to predict long-term disability in mouse models of corticospinal dysfunction that can eventually be applied toward diagnosing and predicting disability, as well as evaluating efficacy of treatments in humans with developmental brain damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Dopamine signaling is key to the rewarding effects of stimulant drugs, but much less is known about the involvement of other neurotransmitters and receptors in response to repeated drug exposure. Whole-brain multimodal imaging will be used to non-invasively measure the interaction between neurotransmitter systems, specifically neuroadaptations occurring at dopamine-glutamate targets. This study will reveal the importance of multi-receptor interactions and the potential role of glutamate and other targets in the treatment of drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The behavioral state of an animal – whether it is active, inactive, mating, or fighting – profoundly influences how it generates behavioral responses to environmental cues. However, because the environment is constantly changing, animals often switch behavioral states in a sensory-driven manner. To understand how sensory cues influence behavioral state generation and how the links between sensory cues and behavioral states can flexibly change, we will examine the flow of information from the sensory periphery to key neural populations that mediate behavioral state control in the well-defined nervous system of the nematode C. elegans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Many mental health disorders, such as autism, depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia, present with sex-biased ratios in incidence, severity, age-of-onset, or prognosis. The goal of this proposal is to understand how gonadal steroid hormones regulate sex differences in gene expression and neuronal connectivity. Understanding the distinct developmental trajectories of female and male brains will therefore advance our knowledge of the basic mechanisms underlying sex differences in psychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have recently identified a new clinical candidate for the potential treatment of Chagas disease, a result of infection of humans and other mammals by the parasite, Trypanosoma cruzi. The work proposed in this application will investigate the uptake and metabolism of this drug by T. cruzi. These studies are expected to provide new insights into the mechanisms of drug action and the potential for failure of this promising treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavioral profiling of zebrafish larvae under the influence of neuroactives is at the vanguard of in vivo neuropharmacology, which has historically been dominated by costly and challenging experiments in rodents and primates. I co-developed a state-of-the-art platform in which drug-induced behaviors of hundreds of thousands of animals can be assessed, cataloged, and compared rapidly and on a scale that far exceeds historical precedents; I have coupled this technology with the recent advances in whole brain imaging to make observations that saliently connect chemistry, neuroanatomy, and behavior. This proposal is focused on new projects directed towards the discovery of substance use disorder pharmacotherapies, including alternatives to addictive opioids for pain management, acute reversal agent interventions, and attenuators of drug self- administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research seeks to understand how genetic and biophysical features of influenza viruses contribute to the spread of virions within infected hosts. Viral spread is central to the medical outcomes of influenza virus infection. It is expected that by understanding how this process works, how it differs between genetically-distinct viruses, and how it impacts the progression of infection, it will become possible to identify new strategies for preventing and controlling influenza.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The innate immune response is one of our most important defenses against viral infection, but we don’t know much about the specific innate effectors that play a role in whether a persistent HIV infection is established. We propose to define these key factors, taking a combined approach of studying this in humans and in biologically relevant cell culture systems using state-of-the-art functional approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants “born too soon” are at increased risk of infections and sepsis with significant mortality and life- long complications. These studies will test two hypotheses that (1) the increased risk of infections and sepsis in premature neonates is due to abnormal myelopoiesis leading to increased immunosuppressive myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and innate immune effector cells, and (2) prophylactic treatment with immunomodulatory agents can induce ‘trained immunity’ by correcting the phenotype of both MDSCs and PMNs in premature neonates.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, I propose a set of genetic, biochemical and bioinformatics studies to understand: 1) the role of ADAR1 RNA editing in regulation of the maternal transcriptome in the oocyte and early embryo in young and old mice, and 2) the effect of ADAR1 RNA editing on RNA stability in oocytes and eggs from young and old mice. These mechanistic studies will advance our basic understanding of how post-transcriptional RNA processing is integral to the oocyte RNA environment, and hence, oocyte quality. The knowledge gained from this proposal could promote a shift in current paradigms and redirect research to accelerate progress in understanding infertility and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project will leverage new computational and hybrid modeling approaches to provide unified knowledge of the assembly, dynamics and function of key complexes in nucleotide excision repair – the most versatile pathway for removal of DNA damage resulting from exposure to environmental carcinogens. Unveiling the interplay of molecular-level mechanisms and disease mutations in these complexes will yield foundational understanding of severe genetic disorders associated with cancer, aging, and developmental defects – xeroderma pigmentosum, trichothiodystrophy, Cockayne syndrome and related diseases. Success of the project will thus impact understanding of the roles of environmental and genetic factors in human disease etiology, opening new avenues to devise effective treatments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cardiometabolic disorders including obesity, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes are highly prevalent among U.S. Veterans and serve as major factors in the development of heart, vascular and liver diseases. We have assembled a multi-disciplinary research team comprised of investigators with expertise in cardiovascular and metabolic disease, clinical and epidemiological research, EHR based research methods, genetic epidemiology, and statistical genetics. We now propose to build upon the momentum of our currently funded project (“Genetics of Cardiometabolic Diseases in the VA Population”) and further elucidate the genetic basis of the longitudinal progression of cardiometabolic traits, thereby informing more targeted genomic medicine-based disease management throughout the course of Veterans' lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV/AIDS is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among children and adolescents, and robust estimates of the HIV burden among these age groups are needed to inform intervention priorities and monitor progress toward global targets. The goal of this study is to address limitations of existing methods by triangulating empirical data sources to produce more accurate and comprehensive estimates of pediatric HIV burden than current statistics, including the first-ever global estimates of new HIV infections among young adolescents, as well as insight into the unique contributions of biomedical, behavioral, and structural factors on the burden of HIV/AIDS in children and young adolescents. We will do so by assembling and triangulating data sources; quantifying the relationship between risk and protective factors and child/adolescent HIV burden; and forecasting the future burden of HIV among children/adolescents through 2040 based on current trends in incidence, prevalence, and mortality, and exposure to risk and protective factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The care for patients with acute kidney injury (AKI) is suboptimal when they transition from hospital to outpatient care, yet challenging to overcome because of poor AKI communication both to outpatient providers and patients. To improve AKI information flow to providers and patients, the proposed study aims to develop and evaluate AKI discharge summary tool in the electronic health records, and text messaging tool that supports patient education and self-management behavior. Improving AKI communication through these tools will improve the clinical care of patients with AKI and reduce morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Specific antibodies that block many strains of HIV are called broadly neutralizing antibodies or bnAbs. Rare people living with HIV (PLWH) develop these antibodies in their blood and others may have early or partially active antibodies. The purpose of this project is to conduct a clinical study of a new vaccine, called Trimer 4571, to determine if the vaccine is safe in PLWH and if it improves the antibody response to HIV. Additionally, the study will see if the vaccine has any impact on the HIV reservoir in blood cells. If successful, this may pave the way toward achieving sustained remission of HIV in the absence of antiretroviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The impaired sensory function that results from lower-limb amputation often causes reduced balance control and an increased risk of falling. Electrical stimulation of the lateral spinal cord in the low back can produce sensations that feel like they come from the missing limb, although currently available electrodes often produce sensations that cover large regions of the missing foot and residual limb. In this project, we will perform large animal experiments and computational modelling studies to develop new electrodes for lateral spinal cord stimulation and we will chronically implant these devices near the spinal cord in pigs to measure their stability and safety over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are approximately 55,000 deaths from breast and ovarian cancer annually in the United States, with BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations found in 5-7% of breast and 6-15% of ovarian cancers cases. PARP inhibitor therapies extend the lives of BRCA1/2 mutation carrying patients; however, drug resistance invariably emerges. DNA polymerase theta inhibitors (Polθi) represent another promising approach, the goal of this project is to identify biological factors that determine Polθi sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative We have found that IgM exacerbated obesity, enhanced inflammation and altered gut microbiota in an AID mouse model and we identified that IgM-bound gut bacteria were elevated in adolescent patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D). We hypothesize IgM antibodies and IgM-bound gut bacteria cause obesity and metabolic dysfunction and we will test the hypothesis in mouse and man, in vitro and in vivo, in three specific aims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Principal Investigators (Last, first, middle): Xu, Huanbin PROJECT NARRATIVE: Despite remarkable advances in prevention of vertical HIV-1 transmission, pediatric HIV infections still occur peripartum rather than through breastfeeding, however, there is little data to guide the optimal early treatment regimens in vulnerable neonates with high risk of MTCT. Our primary findings indicate that infant macaques intravenously infected with pathogenic SIV at birth achieve sustained virologic remission by 9-months of early intervention, suggesting pediatric HIV remission is achievable in a proportion of infants infected with or exposed to HIV. Assessing the impact of early viral reservoir on the treatment outcomes, determining optimal prevention intervention strategies for a sustained state of ART-free viral remission, and exploring the antiretroviral pharmacokinetics and immune alteration in unique infants using early prevention interventions, will accelerate translational treatment towards pediatric HIV remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aim of inter-Institutional cooperative clinical research is to advance our understanding of cancer prevention, pre- cancers, and both benign and malignant processes and, thereby, to improve our ability to treat people at risk or afflicted with them. These aims are accomplished by resolving scientific questions of importance regarding cancer biology and therapy through the cooperation of selected Institutions that can pool their intellectual, technical, and patient resources. The rapid accumulation of clinical data and experience through cooperative group research expedites progress in cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is primarily studied with samples that begin in midlife or later and assess individuals yearly or less often. Furthermore, a premature mortality crisis has ravaged rural communities where economic opportunities and key infrastructures have declined and social disintegration has increased The objective of our set of complementary aims is to develop a new data resource that captures the full arc of a life with intimate detail about living and aging in a rural context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Visual attention is a dynamic process, influencing the sensitivity of visual perception at relevant moments in time. The proposed studies will investigate how attention to moments in time influences sensory-level processing in the visual cortex and will elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying voluntary control of attention over time. Improved understanding of these mechanisms will have clinical applications in disorders linked to attentional timing deficits such as ADHD and neglect, as well as in aging populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury requiring dialysis is a devastating complication among hospitalized patients. There are no current interventions to improve recovery of kidney function. Our study seeks to define better recovery- monitoring strategies and better approaches to outpatient dialysis to enable more patients to have renal recovery and to have it sooner, an unequivocally important clinical and patient-oriented outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescents represent the largest growing population living with HIV and despite ART, HIV infected individuals have increased morbidity and mortality associated with non-AIDS related complications that are likely driven by persistent inflammation and immune activation. In this project, we seek to develop robust models to elucidate the role of trained immunity in NK cells and monocyte populations in chronic immune activation and dysregulation in perinatally acquired HIV infection that will increase our knowledge of the increased risk of comorbidities in youth and reveal potential areas for targeted interventions and vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Vision in mosquitoes plays a critical but understudied role in their attraction to hosts. This project will determine the visual features (colors, size, motion) that mosquitoes find attractive and characterize how odor modulates visual responses. This work will also test new visual lures and identify potential molecular targets that compromise the visual and olfactory behaviors to hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer comprises 70 of all breast cancer cases and primarily metastasizes to bone, but there have not been suitable mammalian models that mimic the progression of this disease, which greatly hinders the research effort to understand this subtype of breast cancer and to develop new and effective therapeutics. In our preliminary studies, we have established novel rat models of ER+ breast cancer that mimic human ER+ breast cancer formation and metastasis. In this application, we will characterize these models in detail and credential them for investigating human ER+ breast cancer development, progression and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Segregating recessive variants are responsible for a substantial health burden. The work proposed here  interrogates the recessive effects of 2.4 million polymorphic sites segregating in an experimental  nematode panel derived from six genomes freshly sampled from the wild. The data will generate  generalizable gene- and variant-scale models that predict whether variants are likely to have recessive  effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human genetics research has found that nucleotide variants can influence traits and diseases. However, the function of these variants and the genes through which they act remains difficult to identify when they do not directly map to a gene. This project aims to identify the genes that these variants influence by developing modular workflows integrating large-scale genetic association studies and genome engineering in cell models, providing insight into the function of these these variants that underly traits and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The enzyme Dot1L drives overexpression of oncogenes that are essential for the initiation and progression of mixed lineage leukemia, an aggressive subset of acute leukemias with no known cure and limited effective clinical treatments. Here we illustrate the molecular basis for Dot1L activity by identifying the interfaces between Dot1L and its nucleosome substrate that are essential for oncogene activation by Dot1L. By establishing the disease-relevance of these Dot1L-nucleosome interaction interfaces in mixed lineage leukemia, this work will inform the development of novel targeted therapeutics to combat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Intraflagellar transport (IFT), originally discovered in Chlamydomonas, is also essential for the assembly and maintenance of most eukaryotic cilia and flagella, and defects in IFT cause several human genetic diseases. The proposed studies will explore the unique roles of the IFT25 complex in construction of the sperm accessory structures that are required for normal sperm function. The proposed studies will not only fill a gap in our knowledge of the process of IFT in spermiogenesis, but also reveal a different role of the IFT25 complex in germ cells and somatic cells during ciliogenesis and build a platform on which to study the roles of other IFT components in male and female reproduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to address the unmet need for computational tools capable of analyzing emerging spatial genomic datasets in particular in complex tissues. We aim to develop interpretable and rigorous machine learning models to propel characterization of diverse cell types, their spatial organization and interactions, and their underlying gene circuitry from combining transcriptomic, proteomic, epigenomic and imaging datasets. Our tools will be impactful in understanding the role of the microenvironment and cell-cell crosstalk in a wide range of normal and disease tissue types.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Department of Pediatrics at Boston Children's Hospital is dedicated to the training of physician-scientists and helping them develop into world-class independent scientists and future leaders in the field. We have a strong track record of training physician-scientists who have gone on to make fundamental discoveries in basic and translational research, which have had a lasting impact on the treatment of pediatric disease. The Child Health Research Career Development Award program has played an integral role in our ability to support the development of physician-scientists at our institution and we propose to continue and strengthen this program over the next five years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 60,000 general anesthetics are performed in the U.S. daily, the majority of which require the administration of intravenous vasopressors to counteract general anesthesia-induced cardiovascular depression and low blood pressure (hypotension). Over the past decade, the harmful effects of intraoperative hypotension, including myocardial injury, stroke and acute kidney injury have been repeatedly observed, and vasopressor therapies to treat intraoperative hypotension, specifically the choice between norepinephrine and phenylephrine, are debated vigorously. The proposed series of studies utilize a multicenter network of medical centers to better understand vasopressor selection and use and conduct a pilot trial to inform development of a future multicenter pragmatic clinical trial to assess the impact of vasopressor selection on end-organ perfusion outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma (MB) is a highly aggressive embryonal tumor of the cerebellum for which safer and more effective therapies are urgently needed. The developmental basis of molecularly and clinically distinct MB subgroups remains ill-defined, hampering the generation of accurate disease models required for mechanistic understanding and preclinical evaluation. This proposal will discover developmental origins of poorly characterized MB subgroups, and experimentally credential transcriptional dependencies defining subgroup identity as a novel therapeutic vulnerability in high-risk patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  In this proposal, we demonstrate that flavin-dependent enzymes are versatile and catalytically promiscuous enzymes, capable of effecting synthetically valuable free radical reactions with high yields and enantioselectivity. This work provides a solution to a long-standing and important challenge in the chemical synthesis and will serve as the bedrock on which new synthetic methods are developed for the construction of medicinally relevant molecules. These new reactions and catalysts will provide biomedical sciences with new tools to expedite the design and manufacture of medicines and biological probes, creating significant benefit to human health.

PHR: A specific modification, named acylation, of the gastric hormone ghrelin is important for its function in the regulation of food intake. The information generated from this project will provide new insights relevant to treatment strategies for liver steatosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal details work to investigate an FDA-approved drug (azithromycin) that has significant promise as a neuroprotective agent, using a ferret model of premature brain injury. As nearly 10% of infants are born prematurely, with outcomes including increased risks of behavioral and cognitive problems, severe disability, and even death, neuroprotective agents for infants born preterm remain a significant clinical need. The ferret has a gyrified brain that develops postnatally and is very similar to the human brain in terms of both development and structure, making it ideal for investigating premature brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the role of Sirt2, a protein involved in regulating metabolism of T lymphocytes that mediate immune responses against cancer. We will explore this problem by analyzing mice deficient in Sirt2 or its partner molecules as well as genetically engineered human T lymphocytes isolated from lung cancer and melanoma patient tumor samples. Our studies may guide development of novel strategies to improve metabolic fitness of T lymphocytes, and thus enhance the capacity of these cells to elicit effective immune defense against cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide new frameworks for the treatment of male infertility, a major public health concern, and identify targets for male contraception. Spermatozoa acquire motility and fertilizing power during their transit through the epididymis, a long tube located downstream of the testis. Our laboratory studies how epithelial cells work together with immune cells to protect spermatozoa against pathogens and autoimmunity and contribute to the immune- privileged environment of the epididymis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to enhancing health and reducing illness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Infants who are exposed to HIV in utero but uninfected (iHEU) are at higher risk for poorer neurodevelopmental outcomes compared to their HIV-unexposed counterparts, yet the role of fetal exposure to differing maternal antiretroviral therapy (ART) regimens and associated biological mechanisms remain underexplored. Here, we propose to leverage prospectively collected data and stored specimens from the Surveillance Monitoring for ART Toxicities (SMARTT) study within the Pediatric HIV/AIDS Cohort Study (PHACS) network to assess meconium microbiome composition and function and systemic inflammation, and associations with neurodevelopment among iHEU with fetal exposure to different maternal ART regimens. This study has the potential to identify biological mechanisms of poor neurodevelopment among iHEU, and to inform novel intervention strategies for this growing, vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Disruption of circadian rhythm, which are biological processes that oscillate with a period of 24 hours, has been linked to increased cancer risk in night-shift workers. Cancer cells can have disrupted cellular circadian clocks that could make them more or less aggressive, or resistant to therapy. This unexplored research area, which is likely to contribute to a better understanding of resistance to standard and immunotherapy, will be the focus of this application, which is expected to provide concepts for better therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Agitation is one of the most common and unmanageable neuropsychiatric symptoms among persons with dementia, affecting 45-83% of this ever-growing population. Pharmacological treatment of agitation often has adverse side effects, and time-constrained caregivers cannot reasonably be expected to monitor the patients and take continuous note of the environment to identify precipitants of agitation. The research and training for this Mentored Quantitative Research Development Award will be centered on identifying digital behavioral markers both during and preceding agitation, identifying environmental precipitants of agitation, and building risk prediction models of agitation using data collected from patients with later-stage dementia and their living environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Leukemia is the most common pediatric cancer and its incidence has increased dramatically in the last 30 years, especially among LatinX. This trend clearly illustrates that environmental factors play a role in the etiology of the disease. To continue and expand research on childhood leukemia and the environment, we plan to support and enrich the infrastructure of four existing environmental epidemiologic studies of childhood leukemia in ethnically- diverse populations of California, Guatemala, Costa Rica and Mexico, and engage public and health professional communities about childhood leukemia prevention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed award for research infrastructure at the University of Colorado Population Center will support population science that contributes important insights of relevance to public health. Findings from research supported by this award inform public health policies and programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this investigation is to examine the influence of feedback timing on learning and brain activity in individuals with moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI), with and without clinical depression. A paired associate verbal learning task will be used to evaluate whether differential neural circuitry, and related dysfunctional changes underlie impairments in learning from immediate in comparison with delayed feedback. We will also quantify the link between standardized neuropsychological measures and beneficial effects of learning through immediate and delayed feedback in our participants as knowing the association between standardized measures and feedback type (immediate vs. delayed) will allow clinicians to identify individuals who are more likely to benefit from a particular feedback type during learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal diseases, which affect more than half of the United States population age 18 and over and nearly three-quarters age 65 and over, are among the most debilitating nonfatal health conditions. The causes of these diseases remain poorly understood, and there is a need for better therapies. The UCSF Musculoskeletal Training Program prepares scientists and physicians for a lifetime of scholarly pursuits that lead to in-depth understanding and improved care for patients with MSK diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: Musculoskeletal;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: UCSF Musculoskeletal Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will use functional neuroimaging techniques and computational modeling to investigate how arousal states and attention independently and interactively influence basic visual responses in humans. Results will provide invaluable information in our understanding of how attention and arousal alter neuronal communication, shaping how we see. By advancing our understanding of such brain functions, results from this proposal could further our understanding of the cortical and subcortical function of people with abnormal arousal levels (e.g., attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, general anxiety disorder), with potential applications down the road in guiding the diagnoses and treatment of disorders that involve atypical attention and arousal levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The earliest cells involved in the immune response to a bacterial infection are the phagocytic cells responsible for internalize, kill bacteria and generate inflammatory signals that coordinate the subsequent immune responses. Recently, we determined that phagocytic cells respond to a sugar that is abundant in the bacterial cell wall and is released when bacteria are degraded and killed. This proposal aims to determine how this bacterial-derived sugar alters the metabolism of phagocytic immune cells and controls the level of inflammation that develops during a bacterial infection in order to better design therapeutics to treat bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative NF-B plays a causative role in the pathogenesis of lung and many other diseases. However, we have been unable to successfully target it for clinical treatment due to its equally important roles in physiology and host defense in particular. The proposed investigations will define the roles and mechanisms by which the ubiquitin E3 ligase PDLIM2 serves as a determinant of NF-B physiological and pathogenic activation in lung infection and pathogenesis. These studies may lead to new clinically feasible approaches to selectively target pathogenic NF-B for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological and pre-clinical data suggest that metformin may be efficacious in endometrial cancer treatment. However, two important questions that need to be addressed are: (1) Will metformin be universally effective in endometrial cancer or be more efficacious in the obese/insulin-resistant patient population? and (2) What role do transporters play in metformin uptake and action in the malignant endometrium? These fundamental questions will be explored in endometrial cancer, a disease driven by obesity and insulin resistance, and key molecular and metabolic biomarkers of metformin responsiveness will be determined, using endometrial cancer mouse models and an ongoing phase 2/3 clinical trial in endometrial cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Late-life depression remains an enormous public health burden, and deficits in motivation and pleasure are particularly devastating and difficult to treat. Using an experimental inflammatory challenge, the current study will evaluate a “two-hit” model of vulnerability and evaluate whether older adults with symptoms of anxiety who are exposed to inflammatory activation are at elevated risk for loss of pleasure, reduced reward motivation, and dysregulated reward neurocircuitry. Through this integrative, multilevel assessment of biological, neural and affective mechanisms that may underlie the emergence of late-life depression, the current study will yield information that can be used to identify individuals at elevated depression risk and to develop novel preventative and treatment interventions that target specific deficits to improve mental and physical health outcomes in older adults with depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to better understand the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. We will dissect defective endosomal pathways, which are common features in many neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias. A fuller understanding of endosomal dysfunction will guide us to identify better therapeutic targets in neurodegenerative disorders and other aging- associated diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Infants whose mothers have HIV, but who are themselves HIV-uninfected, experience more severe disease due to respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection than infants who are HIV-unexposed. This proposal will determine whether dysfunction in particular types of innate immune cells is responsible for more severe RSV disease in these infants, and will explore which in utero exposures contribute to this dysfunction. The results of this study have potential to improve health outcomes for more than 1 million HIV-exposed infants who are born each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is the development of a clinical decision support tool that can be used to predict the risk of drug-induced QT prolongation based on deep learning and genetics. This tool could be used to prevent potentially fatal side effects of medications when alternatives are available, or increase vigilance when safer alternatives are not available. This study is specifically designed so that the models created can be directly applied across other institutional medical record systems beyond the study population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This research is relevant to public health because it seeks to improve the Midlife Black Women’s Stress and Wellness Intervention (B-SWELL), a program co-designed with the community to lower heart disease risk in midlife Black women. This research study leverages choice to increase engagement and minimize the effect of social determinants of health on research participation. Findings from this study have potential to increase sustainability of the B-SWELL and our understanding about preferences of midlife Black women willing to participate in community-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hypothalamic hypocretin (Hcrt) neurons play a central role in integrating sensory and physiological information to tune arousal-related behavioral states, and deficiencies in these circuitries contribute to a variety of neuropsychiatric disorders. In this collaboration between researchers studying arousal-related behavioral states and BRAIN tool developers we will utilize novel interventional tools for changing neural circuit dynamics to elucidate the hierarchical organization of Hcrt circuits with respect to arousal and reward. Our exploratory studies will drive translational progress toward optimization of treatments and potential novel therapeutic opportunities in substance abuse, eating and panic disorders, cognitive disruption and emotion-related disorders, while at the same time addressing basic questions of neural circuit function underlying behavior relevant to both NINDS and NIMH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative. PD1 is an immune checkpoint protein that acts as a brake on signaling proteins that trigger an innate immune response to cancer and ultimately allow tumor evasion. While FDA-approved monoclonal antibodies provided compelling clinical results in various cancer types, the development of small-molecule drugs inhibiting such protein–protein interaction (PPI) is lagging far behind. To bridge this gap, and reignite antitumor immunity to inhibit the growth of these immunosuppressive tumors, we are developing β-hairpin drugs that closely mimic and miniaturize antibody loops while covalently binding to PD1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is a global public health concern, especially in low- and middle- income countries where more than 77% of all suicides occur, disproportionately impacting youth. The Zero Suicide model, comprised of a series of evidence-based approaches, has now been implemented in more than 20 countries, but the feasibility of these approaches in LMICs is unclear. The proposed R21 project leverages an established research collaboration and strong governmental support to examine the feasibility of these suicide prevention approaches for youth in Nepal and to develop strategies for implementation through stakeholder surveys, interviews, and focus groups.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This project examines the mechanisms by which the hormones insulin and insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF1) transmit their signals inside target cells. The receptors for these hormones are linked to human disease: decreased insulin receptor activity is linked to diabetes, while increased activity of IGF1 receptor plays a role in cancer. The structural and biochemical information from these studies could be used to design new therapies to control receptor activity in these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Ultrasound imaging of the coronary and peripheral arteries during procedures like balloon angioplasty or stent placement is known to improve outcomes, but it is infrequently used because of interpretation complexity and added procedure time for exchanging specialized imaging catheters. This project focuses on incorporating this capability on devices like guidewires and catheters that are routinely used in these procedures so that physicians can use this technique before, during and after the interventions without prolonging the procedure duration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Discovery of human metapneumovirus epitopes Our lab has established methods to discover human MHC-I and MHC-II epitopes using HLA-transgenic mice and human PBMCs. We propose to apply these methods to human metapneumovirus (HMPV) to discover HLA-restricted T cell epitopes recognized by CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. These tools will be needed to understand human immune responses to both natural infection and vaccines against this important human respiratory pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypoxia and oxidant stress are important physiological processes that can have significant effects on human health. Red blood cells, the most abundant cell type in the body, play a critical role in oxygen transport, a process that is mediated by hemoglobin and iron. Indeed, 66% of bodily iron is stored in red cells. Dysregulated iron metabolism has been shown to promote oxidative stress. Oxidant stress promotes lipid peroxidation, a hallmark of cell death by a mechanism referred to as “ferroptosis”. Red blood cells not only harbor many of the enzymes involved in the regulation of ferroptosis, but iron-induced oxidant stress is an established regulator of red cell aging and clearance in circulation. In this project we will leverage recently developed genetic and pharmacological tools to mechanistically test the role of ferroptosis on red blood cell aging, both in circulation in vivo and in vitro, during storage in the blood bank for transfusion purposes, a life-saving intervention for ~5 million Americans every year, ranked 1st in the list of historical breakthroughs that saved the most human lives (1 billion).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life sleep disruption is common in autism spectrum disorder and has been shown in animal models to cause lasting changes in brain function and behavior. Treatments for sleep disruption in children are extremely limited, and the basis for vulnerability to early life sleep disruption is not known. Here we will test whether mutation in a known autism risk gene confers vulnerability to the effects of developmental sleep disruption, and whether the developing synapse is a node of vulnerability to the effects of sleep disruption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The generation of memory T cells that remain long-lived in the female reproductive tract (FRT) can enhance host protective immunity from sexual transmission of Chlamydia Trachomatis (C. trachomatis), a causative agent of severe diseases in women and an important global human health issue. Although the local tissue environments of the FRT differentially influence tissue resident memory T cell (TRM) immune surveillance, how regionalization with different parts of the FRT impacts T cell durability to influence the memory responses against Chlamydia is unknown. The goal of this proposal is to determine the mechanisms that imprint memory T cells to preferentially reside in the uterine, cervical, and vaginal FRT mucosae in order to better inform prevention efforts and cell- mediated vaccine designs against sexually transmitted pathogens in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria parasites use numerous invasion ligand proteins to invade red blood cells (RBCs). We propose to globally identify all invasion ligand proteins capable of binding RBCs and identify proteins that interact with RBC host receptors. Understanding such interactions is key to developing a blood stage malaria vaccine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative As cannabis legalization expands, cannabis use and perceptions that use has little-to-no risk are increasing among reproductive-aged women. Yet, we lack information on whether and/or how cannabis use alters holistic human milk composition, frequently the only or primary source of nutrition for infants in their first months of life. Understanding the effects of maternal cannabis use on milk composition will provide needed information for healthcare providers and mothers to make evidence-based decisions that support breastfeeding and the health of the mother and infant.

PHR: Project Narrative Newborn screening detects life-threatening genetic disorders early, allowing for effective treatment. Screening for a disorder is based on an algorithm, that is, a set of tests and rules on how to interpret the test results. We propose to develop a prescriptive optimization framework for designing optimal screening algorithms that will improve the efficacy, equity, and efficiency of current practices, using cystic fibrosis as a model disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We focus on understanding how human cells repair DNA double strand breaks induced via environmental exposures and protect stressed replication forks against attrition mediated by nucleases. Specifically, we will elucidate the role of the dual specificity phosphatase EYA4 in genome repair and maintenance pathways. The results from our endeavors will help fill a major knowledge gap regarding cellular defense against the cytotoxic and genotoxic effects of environmental clastogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Fundamental features of Campylobacter jejuni host-association, such as mechanisms underlying its expansion in the gut lumen during infection, how gut metabolites influence this expansion, and how these metabolites impact expression of fitness traits during disease, are not well understood. Building off solid preliminary data using the ferret as a natural disease model, our proposed work will explore how C. jejuni alters gut physiology during acute infection, and how host derived lactate influences C. jejuni expansion and other traits associated with pathogenicity. The proposed work will provide important new knowledge of C. jejuni infection and guide us in developing new therapeutic targets against emerging multidrug-resistant strains.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Down syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality that is associated with disproportionate deficits in hippocampally-dependent memory (Godfrey & Lee, 2018; Pennington et al., 2003), resulting in a particular difficulty remembering specific details from past events. In addition to making it difficult for individuals with Down syndrome to access and share their past, this overgeneral memory can interfere with mental health (Waters 2014; King et al., 2019; Latorre et al., 2013) and independence (Holland et al., 2016; Sheldon et al., 2011). In the current project, the investigators examine the efficacy of a user-friendly and evidence-based (Martin et al., 2022) behavioral intervention—HippoCamera—in enhancing memory specificity in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The arenavirus Lujo virus emerged in Southern Africa in 2008, resulting in a human-to-human transmission chain and deaths of four out of the five infected. Here, we will structurally characterize the surface glycoprotein of Lujo virus alone and in complex with its cellular receptor, and will discover novel antibodies targeting this critical antigen. This work will illuminate the overall architecture and receptor-binding mode of this divergent arenavirus and provide much-needed therapeutic leads and research reagents.

This study will provide foundational data to understand the alterations observed in the aged brain proteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health relevance Statement CDC reported that among the US population 34.2 million people of all ages—or 10.5% of the US population— had diabetes in 2018. Diabetic patients are known to have a higher incidence of infection, including microbial keratitis, with increased disease severity and higher rate of multi-drug resistance. The causes for increased susceptibility and rapid progression of microbial keratitis at cellular and tissue levels are elusive. Using Pseudomonas aeruginosa keratitis model of normal and diabetic mice in combination with RNA-seq and sophisticated bioinformatic, we propose to investigate biological processes that contribute to the defects in immune response and to identify means that reverse these adverse effects in diabetic corneas. CDC recently reported one death, three with permanent vision loss, and 55 people infected with antibiotic-resistant P. aeruginosa, linked to the use of EzriCare eye drops. Our proposed study is timely, clinically relevant, and will fill a major knowledge gap and lead to better treatment for infectious keratitis for the patients with or without diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is focused on developing a new strategy to combat the incidence of salmonellosis in the US and to reduce the risk of carriage of antibiotic resistant Enterobacteriacea that are an increasingly important health issue. The proposal is focused on optimizing binding activity of type 1 fimbriae in E. coli Nissle 1917 as a probiotic strain that can outcompete pathogenic Salmonella strains for intestinal colonization in chickens. The project should lead to a reduction in Salmonella infectious diseases and provide alternatives to the usage of antibiotics to reduce these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will facilitate and vertically advance the development of critically needed medical countermeasures against chemicals induced skin injuries. The proposed mechanistic studies will facilitate understanding the dynamics of the key processes involved in the chemicals induced injuries that will have an enormous impact on our capabilities to design countermeasure strategies and test them directly on human skin using our novel model system. This whole process will shorten the time for developing countermeasure and increase the chances of success in clinical translation Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH/NIAID/Chemicals Countermeasure Program’s mission to develop new countermeasures and add them to the national stockpile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative During infection, lung sensory neurons play an important role in primary host defense by triggering coughing, but how they modulate inflammation in the lung is incompletely understood. On the other hand, dendritic cells (DCs) play a crucial role in immunity by sensing pathogens and activating T cells. By using a mouse model of helminth infection, the goal of this project is to understand how DCs and sensory neurons cooperate in orchestrating type 2 inflammatory responses in the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS) is a cluster of symptoms associated with immunotherapy that did not show up in pre-clinical studies but has been found in 40-90% of the people undergoing immunotherapy as part of cancer treatment. In this project we will develop technology that will enable frequent automated monitoring of the patients’ cognitive status in order to detect early subtle symptoms of ICANS. If detected early, ICANS can be treated and prevented from progressing to more severe symptoms including brain swelling, coma and, in rare cases, death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and high fat/sugar diet are risk factors of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), which is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. The mechanisms underlying obesity-induced AD are not completely understood. Obesity significantly affects the liver, but the relationship between obesity-induced liver damage and AD pathology is poorly understood. Our proposal explores how obesity-induced liver changes affect the brain to induce and/or exacerbate AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following a randomized controlled trial of a parenting intervention with Congolese mothers of infants/toddlers experiencing significant adversity, we now propose a follow-up study of these participants to evaluate the long- term effect of a parenting support program on child mental health outcomes at school age, and test the impacts of social family, maternal mental health, and child growth factors as predictors of longer-term child mental health. A significant strength of our assessment plan includes leveraging our prior extensive phenotyping of environmental, social, caregiving, developmental, and medical risk/resilience factors (assessed in early childhood) and the new array of questionnaire-based and eye tracking response (to emotion-laden video content) assessments of child mental health. Characterizing how early childhood parenting support enhances child mental health, along with the family social, child growth, and maternal mental health factors driving this process will inform prevention of child mental health problems in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Summary This new R21 application “Respiratory Distress in Sheep with Hypophosphatasia: Etiology, Functional Consequences and Rescue” will provide novel insights into the role of tissue non-specific alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP) on lung development and function. Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is an inherited disorder of mineral metabolism in patients with loss of function mutations in the tissue-nonspecific alkaline phosphatase gene (ALPL). This disorder is associated with high neonatal morbidity and mortality, impaired musculoskeletal development, and respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), yet the in utero origins of the disease are unknown and the ontogeny of development of lung pathology is poorly understood. The PI’s laboratory developed the first large animal model of HPP in sheep, creating an ALPL gene mutation in exon 10 (c.1077C>G) recapitulating the human HPP phenotype. As observed in human patients, but not in mice, neonatal lambs carrying a loss of function mutation in ALPL commonly have respiratory complications as neonates and have an increased incidence of pneumonia compared to wildtype control lambs throughout life. Preliminary findings in HPP sheep demonstrate severe lung pathology on Day 100 of gestation (GD100), suggesting programming of the postnatal lung phenotype during fetal development, and that the known postnatal respiratory complications result from more than insufficient rib cage mineralization. This sheep HPP model will be used to test the hypothesis that reduced TNSALP activity causes lung-specific developmental abnormalities, as well as deficiencies in diaphragm structure and respiratory function that contribute to RDS by the analyses of WT and HPP fetuses on GD130 and in lambs at 4 months of age. Specific Aim 1 will characterize the respiratory phenotype in WT and HPP sheep throughout development (GD130 and postnatal 4 months of age). Specific Aim 2 will determine the impact of HPP on resting lung function in 4 month old WT and HPP sheep by measuring arterial blood gases (pO2, pCO2), bicarbonate, pH, ammonia and lactate, and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). Specific Aim 3 will determine the efficacy of recombinant TNSALP therapy to rescue the developmental respiratory phenotype in HPP sheep using lentiviral GFP control or ALPL-GFP constructs injected into WT or HPP sheep zygotes. This interdisciplinary collaborative team includes a current clinical veterinary physiologist collaborator (an expert on respiratory diseases in ruminants) who will collect arterial blood and bronchoalveolar lavage fluids for assessment of lung pathophysiology. This study will provide the first investigations into the in utero developmental origins of the severe respiratory phenotype in sheep with HPP, and describe contributions of non-skeletal tissues (lung, lung-resident immune cells, diaphragm) to RDS in HPP. These findings will have immediate relevance to the management of RDS in human HPP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative A number of age-related neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s disease is associated with the amyloid aggregation which involves the formation of oligomers that are difficult to study using standard structural biology techniques. Two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy (2D IR) is an emerging technology uniquely suitable for elucidating the structure and tracking the kinetics of toxic oligomers, but it relies on simulations that connect structural models and experimental spectra. The aim of this proposal is to develop and implement methods and algorithms for calculating 2D IR spectra from coarse-grained protein and implicit solvent models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic exposure to airborne particles could lead to debilitating pulmonary inflammation and subsequent development of several chronic diseases, making it important to develop new strategies to resolve lung inflammation and prevent disease development. We propose to study the kinetic production of extracellular vesicles (EV) and their miRNAs cargos in the lung after particle exposure using an advanced analytical system to gain better understanding of how EV can mediate cell-cell communication and contribute to inflammation resolution. Our exploratory work can help reveal the potential roles of the EVs derived from selected pulmonary cells in anti-inflammation, immunomodulation, and/or airway epithelium protection, which could be leveraged for developing effective tools to reduce the burden of chronic airway inflammatory diseases.

PHR: The current pandemic of COVID-19, caused by SARS-CoV-2, has led to tremendous damage to all aspects of our society. The goal of this project is to identify host or viral RNA 2’-O methyltransferases (MTases) that install internal 2’-O methylation in SARS-CoV-2 RNA and to explore the biological functions of internal 2’-O methylation in SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Understanding these fundamental questions will facilitate the development of therapeutic agents by targeting 2’-O methyltransferases and internal 2’-O methylation.

PHR: Vision screening, a key public health tool to identify children at risk for vision problems (significant uncorrected refractive error, amblyopia, and strabismus) is currently mandated in 41 states; however, it is not known which currently used screening test(s) effectively identify at-risk school-age children in need of further eye care. Development of evidence-based school-age vision screening guidelines and policies requires much stronger data on the effectiveness of screening tests than are currently available. This planning grant helps lay the foundation for a future UG1 to perform a full-scale study with side-by-side comparisons between alternative screening tests to determine the best screening test(s) for identification of school-age children at risk for significant vision problems that are common in school-age children and may impede learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE The microcirculation plays a critical role in organ homeostasis and disease pathogenesis, yet developing quantitative methods to assess organ-specific microcirculation remains an ongoing challenge. Our proposal establishes methods to identify and validate measures of the coronary microcirculation from clinical coronary angiography cine imaging data (2-dimensional x time imaging). This project is therefore relevant to the NIH's mission to address an unmet need by developing novel imaging methods to improve the diagnosis of microvascular diseases and accelerate research into this crucial and understudied area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2022, New Jersey became the first U.S. state to enact a law requiring sales of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) in licensed tobacco retailers. The extent to which such a law could further reduce tobacco use, with a positive equity impact, is unknown and the proposed research seeks to examine compliance with the NRT law and its association with community demographics, sales of NRT using retailer scanner data, and engagement with NJ Quitline. Study results may inform public health and tobacco regulatory policies and enhance future longitudinal research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, remains one of leading causes of death from infectious diseases. This program studies the function and mechanism of type II mitochondrial arginase in mediating the expression of host innate and adaptive immunity in response to M. tuberculosis infection. The program will lead to the development of adjunct HDTs by dietary supplementation of arginine and/or ornithine to improve bacterial clearance and shorten the duration of antibiotic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop a microscopic nuclear imaging technique that can provide the 3D distribution of clinical radiotracers (instead of tritiated forms or analogs) in a thick, living biological specimen (instead of a fixed and sliced specimen). The proposed instrument will improve our understanding of how clinical radiotracers are distributed at cellular level in a living, multi-cellular organism, and thereby will help us to better interpret clinical nuclear imaging. It will also allow us to test and select new radiopharmaceuticals using patient-derived organoids for safe and effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asymptomatic malaria infections caused by the Plasmodium falciparum parasite, while not clinically apparent, have significant individual and public health consequences, including chronic anemia, susceptibility to bacterial infections, and maintenance of onward transmission by serving as parasite reservoirs. Such infections can also adversely impact cognitive performance in school-aged children, but the potential mechanisms by which this occurs has not been well-studied. This project will measure blood inflammatory biomarkers and cognitive performance in asymptomatic children naturally infected with P. falciparum before and after anti-malarial treatment to determine whether clearance of parasitemia leads to improvements in cognitive performance by reducing systemic inflammation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The stakes for determining whether the surprisingly resilient infant health advantage observed among U.S. Hispanics has been imperiled by the COVID-19 pandemic are high. Healthy birth outcomes set the stage for the health and well-being across the life course, with poor perinatal outcomes producing enduring effects in later life. If the Hispanic infant health advantage has indeed been threatened, then there are likely long- term consequences for inequality that urgently need to be documented in order to determine where to focus resources, not just at birth, but also at other stages of child development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There is no contemporary, nationwide data about how diabetes is managed among people with diabetes and end-stage kidney disease, and how this affects the risks of health-related outcomes (mortality, readmissions, hospitalizations) and severe hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia crises -common yet potentially preventable events in this high-risk population. This proposal will leverage expertise (secondary data analysis, health- outcomes research) of a multi-disciplinary research team and the most comprehensive nationwide database of patients with ESKD, the United States Renal Data System (USRDS), to characterize contemporary patterns of glucose-lowering therapy and diabetes technologies among patients with diabetes and ESKD; quantify rates of all-cause and cause-specific hospitalizations/emergency department visits (severe hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia), mortality, and readmissions, as a function of each glucose-lowering therapy. These results will have strong clinical and translational impact on the management of glycemia in the setting of ESKD and will be used to inform prospective trials to support safer treatments in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The therapeutic benefits of minor cannabinoids are largely unknown despite the legalization and increased use of cannabis by millions of Americans both medicinally and recreationally. Significant gaps exist in understanding the potential health benefits, risks, dosing, and pharmacology of this widespread and important class of natural products. Our expertise in cannabinoid biosynthesis and lipid receptor biology together with our discovery that the minor cannabinoid cannabichromene (CBC) targets the LPA receptor offer a path to evaluate the >100 natural minor cannabinoids for their unrealized therapeutic potential in chronic pain, obesity, and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a high burden of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors among contemporary adolescents, and current behavioral treatments for this age group are insufficient in terms of both efficacy and population reach. The proposed research will develop and pilot test novel intervention components targeting the core motivational mechanisms of emotion and identity to increase efficacy, and deliver them alongside standard behavioral content using protocolized, remote, and largely self-guided methods to increase scalability. This work represents the multiphase optimization strategy’s Preparation phase and will fully prepare us to conduct a large-scale Optimi- zation-phase factorial trial and assemble a lean, effective, and scalable intervention package for adolescents with CVD risk factors, which directly responds to calls from pediatric guidelines and the NHLBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The present study applies a social-vulnerability theoretical approach to understanding family-household structure, housing condition changes, and household moves as mechanisms associated with elderly disability and chronic morbidity acquisition under extreme coastal flooding events in India. This will contribute to substantive and theoretical understanding of elder health vulnerabilities to climate change more generally, including to coastal cylones/hurricanes, and to riverine and flash flooding, all of which are forecasted to increase in frequency and severity in South Asia and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People that experience prenatal alcohol exposure are at higher risk for risky alcohol drinking as adolescents or young adults. Prenatal or adolescent exposures can independently result in cognitive and behavioral deficits that are driven, in part, by changes in specific cell populations and/or alcohol-induced (neuro)inflammation. The aim of this grant is to develop rat and mouse models to determine whether the “double-hit” of prenatal + adolescent exposure is additive, synergistic, or non-combinatorial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this project is to identify human genes that are important for infection by pathogenic viruses that cause human disease such as Coxsackievirus, poliovirus, and noroviruses. To achieve this, we will first study virus infection in a simple model organism, the nematode C. elegans, and determine whether related genes function similarly in human cells.
