IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the most common cause of severe loss of eyesight in the elderly population. Retinal pigment epithelium degeneration is a hallmark of AMD disease progression, and despite current efforts, no established treatments are available. We will develop a novel treatment using AMD patients’ own urine-derived stem cells to generate new retinal pigment epithelial cells to restore AMD patients’ vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current evidence-based practices for adolescent depression, such as standard cognitive behavioral therapy, are time and resource intensive while still leaving some adolescent depression symptoms, including sleep disturbance and fatigue, unresolved. This study will develop and pilot test a just-in-time adaptive intervention (JITAI) for adolescents seeking depression treatment in primary care, a critical setting for reaching adolescents in need of mental health care. JITAIs are a novel technology-based approach that have the potential to increase the effectiveness of depression care by utilizing in-the-moment smartphone and wearable device data to identify vulnerable periods (e.g., periods of inactivity, poor sleep health) and provide timely, targeted interventions when they are most needed for a particular adolescent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Obesity, a systemic disorder of metabolism, is associated with chronic inflammation and impaired immune cell responses to infection from select viruses, such as influenza and SARS-CoV-2. Interestingly, weight loss achieved by continuous low-fat diet does not improve obesity-associated inflammation or improve survival to influenza infection; therefore, alternative approaches to improve immune responses to viral infection in individuals with obesity are needed. The objective of this innovative R21 proposal is to test if time-restricted feeding can improve immune response to infection in this high-risk population and identify metabolic and microbiome-related mechanisms by which this may occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Accurately assessing obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) severity is essential to improving patient care. In this proposal, we will develop a mathematical model to provide a detailed clinical representation of OSA at various target locations in the body, which will allow for the assessment of tissue hypoxia burden and daytime sleepiness as a potential alternative indicator of severity. The clinically deployable model and resulting pool of data, which will be obtained from simulated cases of OSA and a re-analysis of existing polysomnography studies, will be invaluable to furthering the clinical understanding of OSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Streptococcus mutans is the primary causative agent of dental caries, which affects a vast majority of American adults, and the pathogen’s ability to overcome acid stress is key to cariogenicity. The proposed project will define small RNAs (an important class of gene regulators) involved in acid stress response in S. mutans. The new insights gained from this project are expected to contribute to the development of novel approaches that target sRNA regulatory networks to control dental caries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Our understanding is limited regarding what triggers serious disease flares in patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), a condition responsible for major disability and premature death, which disproportionately affects women, under-represented minorities and the economically disadvantaged. From studies of the microbial communities that reside in the gut of SLE patients, paired with blood RNA-seq libraries in these patients, we identified patients with Lupus Nephritis (LN), often the most severe and unpredictable form of disease, who have intestinal expansions of a specific pathobiont, that correlated with activation of platelets, the sentinels of the immune system. These exploratory R21 studies will break new ground and contribute fundamental knowledge on the mechanistic interconnections between the microbiome and autoimmune pathogenesis, as we test hypotheses that gut dysbiosis leads to platelet-mediated thromboinflammatory pathways, which then contribute to the pathogenesis of SLE, especially in LN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Regeneration of neural circuits requires extension of axons by transplanted neurons and reestablishment of proper synaptic connections onto target neurons. This proposal is focused on understanding the molecular changes that occur within human photoreceptors (PRs) that may be responsible for age-dependent loss of autonomous axon extension. By genetically modifying human PRs, we hope to improve the ability of transplanted PRs to reintegrate into existing circuits within an injured adult retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A hall mark feature of heart failure (HF) is the consistent loss of beta-adrenergic receptor (βAR) function which is responsible for increasing cardiac contraction. There are no drugs that reverses or normalizes the loss of βAR function, as current treatment options only delay the progression of heart failure. Our studies have identified small molecules that restores βAR function and could be suitable for drug development studies to therapeutically target a novel pathway in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Breast reconstruction is becoming an area where reconstructive surgery intersects with regenerative medicine as autologous fat grafting is rapidly evolving to include engineered tissue grafts. However, the tools to quantitatively follow these tissues over time is limited by cost, convenience, consistency and clinical applicability, particularly during the engraftment process. The purpose of this multi-disciplinary mixed methods approach is to develop a novel 3D imaging framework to assess volume and surface characteristics in oncologic breast reconstruction with autologous fat grafting and demonstrate feasibility in an outpatient clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative B cells are key cells of the immune system responsible for producing antibodies, but current technologies is not yet able to control antibody production by B cells with genetic precision. Here, we seek to engineer viral gene vectors that allow us to directly reprogram B cells in vivo, enabling us to precisely control what antibody is to be secreted. If successful, our work may lead to a new approach in engineering immunity as well as sustaining protein-based therapies for a wide range of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Understanding how our genes affect the behavior of individual cells is a fundamental question in many scientific fields ranging from human genetics to developmental biology to cancer biology. In this technology development grant, we will seek to vastly improve how to detect the identify of DNA variants while simultaneously determining their effects on RNA within the same cells. We hope this technology will facilitate more rapid discovery of the effects of genetic variants and cancer mutations to improve our understanding of the human condition and disease conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  Down syndrome (DS), or Trisomy 21, is the most frequent chromosomal abnormality in humans, resulting from a complete or partial extra copy of chromosome 21. Children and adults with DS have a higher likelihood of gastrointestinal disorders affecting quality of life. This proposal addresses critical gaps in our knowledge on GI smooth muscle dysfunction in Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain tumors have surpassed the leukemias as the leading cause of cancer-related death in children. Therapeutic options for pediatric brain cancers have shown little expansion over the past few decades and the prognosis for many tumor types (especially Diffuse Midline Gliomas) remains bleak. The research proposed here will examine the utility of dietary fatty acids in halting the growth of Diffuse Midline Gliomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE. Delivery of siRNA or drug-carrying nanoparticles into the central nervous system by peripheral injection is possible with use of cell penetrating peptides (CPP), however current CPPs are not selective for specific cellular macromolecules limiting their use. This application will determine for the first time if a novel cell penetrating peptide can deliver siRNA into cells and the mouse brain by a specific nicotinic receptor subtype. By addressing these critical gaps in our knowledge, this research will 1) determine the cargo delivery potential of the novel CPP furthering the development of our novel agent as a research tool or potential therapy, and 2) provide key preliminary data for future NIH R01 applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will address whether the proliferation of health insurance plans with high deductibles is exacerbating income-related disparities in healthcare access. While these plans are well-known to reduce spending by reducing use of medical services, questions remain about which types of health care services enrollees forego and how these plans impact individuals across levels of household income. I assess changes in spending and service use among individuals who move from traditional to high-deductible health insurance plans, and compare these changes across household income, to inform health policy discussions about whether high deductibles reduce health spending without harming population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI) patients continue to suffer from severely reduced quality of life and high mortality rates with revascularization remaining an important first line of treatment. Clinical trials of revascularization procedures and medical therapies, like angioplasty or bypass surgery, are associated with some improvement in subsequent amputation-free survival by about 6 months, but the quality of life assessments remain extremely low compared with normal population values. The proposed studies will deliver tip-specific endothelial cells (ECs) derived from pluripotent stem cells to direct the growth of new blood vessels in murine ischemic hind limbs to address this unmet need for patients with CLI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colonization of the small intestine by microbes from the oral cavity has been hypothesized as a key contributor to the pathogenesis of many human diseases, but numerous challenges have prevented this phenomenon from being observed. This exploratory R21 project leverages a unique study design and several innovative technologies, providing a rare opportunity to document colonization of the SI by oral microbes. This study would justify and technologically enable additional studies needed to fill critical knowledge gaps in oral-intestine microbial interactions and how oral microbes affect various interventions (diet, drugs, probiotics, supplements, botanicals, etc.) in the context of human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal focuses on identifying, characterizing, and optimizing small molecules for use as antibiotic adjuvants that inhibit the activity of the chloramphenicol-florfenicol resistance (Cfr) protein. Cfr is a radical S-adenosylmethionine enzyme that methylates adenosine 2503 of 23S rRNA in bacterial ribosomes, conferring resistance to several major classes of currently administered antibiotics across multiple species of pathogenic bacteria, including methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecalis, and Clostridiodes difficile. Successful adjuvant-antibiotic combinations will introduce a new treatment strategy that blocks the acquisition of this form of enzyme-mediated resistance by bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current strategies aiming to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with malaria-in-pregnancy suffer from critical implementation gaps and are increasingly threatened by the emergence of drug and insecticide resistance. The scientific objective of this Exploratory/Developmental Grant (R21) application is to demonstrate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of a focal mass drug administration (fMDA) program for household members of pregnant women to protect against malaria-in-pregnancy. Our hypothesis is that eliminating the parasite reservoir within the household will provide a complementary layer of protection especially when access to care is limited and visits may be delayed or missed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the quantitative relationships between sequential mosquito stages is critical to a better understanding of transmission of the malaria parasite to the human host. This proposal aims to develop automated image processing techniques based on deep learning and super- resolution imaging to accurately determine the number of sporozoites in single oocysts. This methodology will provide new approaches to understanding the most under-studied stage of the malaria parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amblyopia is the second biggest cause of vision problems in children, and negatively impacts their life including reading performance. Adult amblyopes draw distorted percepts of gratings and letters that indicate abnormal development pf orientation processing in cortex, and such distortions would hamper children’s reading and learning, but it is not known when these distortions first occur, how they develop, and if they respond to treatment. Children’s drawings are unlikely to be accurate representations of percepts, so to answer these questions, we will use Generative Adversarial Networks to make perceptograms of the distortions amblyopic children perceive in gratings, letters, and numbers. In parallel we will build neural models of orientation encoding and decoding that provide insights into the development of perceived shape distortions. These tools will transform studies of childhood amblyopia and possibly other childhood visual disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narratives Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive disease characterized by the formation of scar tissue (fibrosis) in the lungs, which reduces their ability to function properly. The proposed research aims to develop an animal model to investigate the mechanical mechanisms underlying the progression of IPF and to use this model as a preclinical platform for developing mechanobiological therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Vascular cells inside the tumor, or tumor endothelial cells, play a significant role in determining tumor aggressiveness and we had previously shown that lower levels of a small tumor suppressor gene, called microRNA-1 in these cells enhances their proliferation and tumor growth. We have recently found that an enzyme called terminal endonucleotidyl transferase, or TENT2, is responsible for microRNA-1 downregulation in tumor endothelial cells. In this study we will determine the molecular effects of TENT2 on microRNA-1 and its pathogenic role in promoting lung tumor growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative A growing body of literature shows a positive association between racial discrimination and substance use among Black college students, mostly measured using retrospective self-report and cross-sectional surveys with an emphasis on alcohol as a substance use outcome. While valuable, prospective studies are needed to identify racial discrimination as a real-time antecedent to various types of substance use (alcohol, nicotine, marijuana, and other drugs) and substance use patterns (e.g., types of use, quantity of use, co-use) among Black college students, particularly those who attend Predominately White institutions. Addressing a health equity issue, the proposed project aims to use ecological momentary assessment to detect fluctuations in Black college students’ substance use behaviors given real-time experiences of racial discrimination while exploring affective, social, and cognitive mechanisms by which racial discrimination confers risk for substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to understand the principles of molecular structure and supramolecular organization underlying how crystallin proteins control the refractive index of the eye lens. Optical and biophysical measurements will be used to characterize the features of the crystallin fold and interactions among side-chains that contribute to these proteins’ elevated refractivity. The insights gained from this project will enhance our understanding of the biophysics underlying lens function and guide the future design of improved artificial lens materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases are systemic in nature, yet few tools are available to quantify chemical and energetic flows at a systems level. The goal of this project is to quantify metabolic fluxes on a whole-body level using in vivo isotope tracing and in silico machine learning. Upon successful completion of this project, we will gain quantitative insights into how metabolism rewires systemically depending on nutrient availability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Post acute-COVID syndrome (PACS, or Long COVID) includes symptoms of severe fatigue, brain fog, anxiety, depression and pain, affects millions of Americans, and can cause significant disability, including loss of employment and inability to conduct activities of everyday life. Patients with PACS living in rural communities, like those in northern New England, face increased challenges due to heath disparities related to physical and social isolation and a shortage of providers with expertise in managing this condition. We aim to develop useful, understandable and relatable information for patients and providers living and working in this environment, in partnership with biomedical and rural libraries, which are often primary hubs of information in this region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: (Note: this section remains unchanged) This research will determine how serum amyloid A (SAA), a protein that cleans up lipids from injured sites, aggregates in vital organs leading to organ damage in inflammation. This research will also determine how SAA and other aggregating proteins interact with amyloid modulators. These interactions play critical roles in ~40 life-threatening human disorders including Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and other amyloid diseases; research such as ours will help design much-needed treatments for these incurable diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: A wide variety of environmental agents, from anticancer chemotherapies to commonly used pesticides, induce proteotoxic stress, causing toxic side effects limiting usage of prescription drugs, and predisposing individuals to diseases such as cancer and neurodegenerative disorders. Here, we will create a comprehensive map of the cytoprotective networks that promote cell resilience in the face of common environmental insults. This map will serve as a major resource for the research community, provide a more complete understanding of cellular environmental stress response programs, and lead to insights into the large variability in the risk of adverse events that arise from exposure to these insults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Although the revolution in DNA sequencing in the last 20 years has transformed our understanding of how life operates, we are still discovering the many ways that healthy and diseased states arise from how cells “decide” to make proteins from DNA sequences. The work proposed here combines experiment, theory, and computation to reveal—across scales—how these “decisions” are made through bursts of transcription in the embryo of the fruit fly, a powerful model system for developmental biology. The proposed investigations will set the stage for the predictive bioengineering of multicellular organisms and future precision therapeutic tools for repairing developmental defects and halting states of unchecked cellular proliferation in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will identify immunogenic antibodies in response to coccidioidomycosis, an endemic fungal infection in the southwestern United States. Using two innovative technologies, we aim to measure antigen-antibody binding events across the Coccidioides proteome at epitope level resolution, significantly increasing the number of diagnostics targets. Our project will generate and validate a diverse panel of novel monoclonal antibodies which can be developed as therapeutic or vaccine targets in addition to improving current diagnostic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The central goal of this proposed work is to understand the integrated role of inflammation and the sympathetic nervous system in mediating increased sodium (Na) reabsorption during hypertension (HTN). Specifically, this work will explore adrenergic receptor activation on renal dendritic cells, and their contribution to cytokine- mediated increases in blood pressure. This study will allow new avenues for exploitation of possible therapeutic options. Reducing Na reabsorption will decrease blood pressure and end organ damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Very Brief Exposure (VBE) -- the presentation of a series of masked pictures representing a person’s fears (e.g., judgmental faces) -- reduces fear and avoidance during in vivo exposure to the real-life situation, and does not induce distress. We will develop VBE from Specific Phobia to target Social Anxiety Disorder (SAD), and acquire preliminary fMRI data to determine if VBE activates the same neural circuits as in Specific Phobia, and that it does so specifically in transition age youth with SAD, 16-22 years old.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will use state of the art tools to directly visualize and functionally analyze the human polyclonal and monoclonal antibody responses to measles virus vaccination for the first time. The information learned will explain how this successful vaccine works and will provide direction for development of next-generation vaccines and novel therapeutics targeting measles and other viruses in its broad paramyxovirus family.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is characterized both by an increased prevalence in depressive symptoms as well as greater salience of friends, with increased intimacy and self-disclosure in friend conversations. The current project aims to explore granular processes that may contribute to depression contagion, by studying how adolescent best friend interactions can influence each other’s depressed and positive affect in daily life using an experience sampling method design. Online and offline communication will be studied as interpersonal mechanisms expected to drive depression contagion to increase insight into targets for preventative intervention, and individual difference characteristics will be included as factors that may moderate risk for contagion.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative An effective vaccine is needed to control HIV infections that are still afflicting millions of individuals worldwide. Our proposed study will evaluate the use of monoclonal antibodies to construct immune complex vaccines that will optimize the induction of antibodies against the HIV envelope. Findings from this study will provide information that could lead to the development of new strategies for designing the urgently needed HIV vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor heterogeneity, the evolution of tumor subclones driven by distinct oncogenes, is a universal phenomenon across solid tumors that is correlated with poor prognosis in patients. In this proposed work, I model tumor heterogeneity by co-culturing cells either overexpressing MYC or expressing oncogenic RAS, to characterize how the unique behaviors of tumor subclones expressing different oncogenes elicit emergent tumor properties and promote tumor progression. Understanding this cooperation will provide key insights into the functional significance of tumor heterogeneity and will be critical towards uncovering future therapeutic interventions to treat heterogenous tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The directed movement of proteins and membranes between different cellular locations is a fundamental process required for the proper functioning of all eukaryotic cells. Many diseases including cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, diabetes, and immune dysfunction can be caused by intracellular protein transport defects. The proposed research will determine how membrane trafficking pathways are appropriately regulated, enhancing our fundamental understanding of this process, which should facilitate the future identification of therapeutic targets for disease intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The following proposal seeks to illuminate the underlying cell-type specific molecular mechanisms regulating the pathogenesis of heart failure. Results from these studies will identify the affected cell-types during heart failure, reveal the molecular mechanisms directing their pathologic outcomes and provide insight into developing precise cardiac diagnostics and therapies that are tailored to affected cell-types, thus optimizing therapeutic efficacy for treating heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) is a public health priority that remains difficult to diagnose and manage due to the lack of understanding of biological mechanisms underlying neonatal drug withdrawal. Utilizing a non-invasive salivary platform, the current proposal seeks to understand feeding difficulty and hyperphagia often seen in neonates with severe withdrawal and identify sex-specific expression of reward and inflammatory genes that may predispose these neonates to excessive weight gain and subsequent cardiometabolic disorders. The molecular approach and objective evidence from this study may identify at-risk neonates and enable personalized strategies that supplant subjective measures in the current treatment paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is becoming clear that many cellular components are localized to non-membrane-bound intracellular compartments and this organization is crucial for functions including molecular processing, storage, signaling, and metabolism. Dysfunctions in the organization of non-membrane-bound compartments are implicated in human diseases including cancer and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Our study will reveal general principles governing the assembly, internal properties, and structural integration of non-membrane-bound compartments within cells, with impacts on our understanding of their roles in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in methionine levels generate remarkable responses in cells and organisms. Methionine affects cancer cell proliferation rates as well as longevity of animals. Understanding the molecular pathways that integrate methionine metabolism with other cellular functions promises new therapeutic strategies for treatment of age-related disorders. This proposal aims to development molecular insight into a fundamental biological process with great potential for therapeutic exploitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Using a mouse model of Huntington’s disease (HD) that permits ~50% lowering of mutant Huntingtin, we found that pre-symptomatic lowering provided greater benefit than later Huntingtin lowering, however, for several HD model symptoms (including motor symptoms) this benefit was attenuated in older mice. In this project, we will examine if a greater level of mutant Huntingtin lowering can extend the beneficial effects of early Huntingtin lowering in older mice. We will also characterize two potential therapeutic targets, DNA damage repair and neuroinflammation, to determine if their activities correlate with either mutant Huntingtin levels or HD model phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While it is well-established that generation of immune responses hinges on the appropriate communication between different cells of the innate and adaptive immune system, a detailed understanding of how this crosstalk occurs in vivo is currently lacking. The proposed research will generate a better understanding of the spatial microanatomy and signaling events involved in crosstalk among innate and adaptive immune cell types involved in the development of distinct classes of adaptive immune responses to vaccines and inflammatory agonists. This will be relevant to public health because in addition to improving our fundamental grasp of the immune system, these studies will promote the development of novel vaccines and immuno-therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative As the opioid epidemic continues to ravage across the nation with ever increasing rates due to the pandemic, we are in need more than ever of more dependable opioid substitution therapies. Mitragyna speciosa (Kratom) may be our key to developing safer opioid dependency medications through engineering the natural alkaloids within the plant, for the primary alkaloid, mitragynine, has been found to be an effective analgesic without producing an abundance of negative side effects experienced with traditional opioid substitution drugs (i.e methadone). This proposal combines methods of natural products biochemistry and protein engineering to develop mitragynine analogs that may be the answer to providing safe and effective opioid dependency medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal will address fundamental biological questions of iron homeostasis during pregnancy. We propose to identify the hepcidin-suppressive factor of pregnancy and define the mechanisms of adverse interaction between maternal inflammation and iron deficiency. Successful completion will transform our understanding of maternal iron regulation during pregnancy and the pathological complications of inflamed pregnancies, with important diagnostic and therapeutic implications in disorders where inflammatory conditions restrict iron and contribute to anemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of binding kinetics in the development of resistance to targeted drug therapy has been underexplored. This proposal will use Abl tyrosine kinase, the oncogenic driver of chronic myelogenous leukemia and target of seminal small-molecule inhibitor imatinib, as a model system to examine how mutations affect ligand association and dissociation rate. Knowledge gained from this proposal will advance our understanding of the drug dissociation process and inform the rational drug design of targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This is a new application for a multidisciplinary T32 training grant in pulmonary disease which builds upon 36 years of pulmonary research training at our institution. The purpose of the program is to support the recruitment and research training of the most promising MD and PhD trainees in lung disease, establishing new pipelines of Pulmonary leaders. Our goal is to train the next generation of highly qualified, interdisciplinary research scientists able to translate new discoveries of basic science into the clinical sphere, to close health equity gaps, and to advance the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of human lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hermansky-Pudlak Syndrome (HPS) is a group of inherited autosomal recessive disorders caused by genetic mutations that alter the trafficking of lysosomal-related organelles/vesicles. In a subset of patients with HPS-1 and HPS-4, pulmonary fibrosis develops in the fourth or fifth decade of life, and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Experiments proposed in this project will define the cellular and molecular mechanisms of CHI3L1 receptor system, and whether CHI3L1 and its receptor systems are plausible targets to treat HPS-associated lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This work addresses the difficulty that many people experience when trying to understand what someone is saying in noisy social settings where other voices compete. This difficulty is most profound in people who have hearing loss, including older people, and thus the findings have the potential to impact a large section of the population. The work explores new avenues for improving the performance of hearing aids in these common, but acoustically complex, listening situations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research will provide critical insight into the neural basis of selective visual attention, one of the most fundamental cognitive abilities for guiding behavior. Impairments of selective attention have devastating consequences on human health and are frequently observed, for example, in visuo- spatial hemineglect associated with stroke, and in neurodevelopmental disorders, such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Progress in understanding the neural basis of visual selective attention is a necessary step toward developing effective treatments for attentional deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For memory disorders like Alzheimer’s Disease, not all images are created equal; based on their perceptual features, some images degrade rapidly in memory while others persist (Bainbridge et al., 2019a). The primary goal of the proposed project is to determine the mechanisms that underlie changes in neural representations from perception to memory. This research will inform the mechanisms underlying memory impairments such as Alzheimer’s Disease and aphantasia, and in turn have potential to aid in the development of effective early diagnostic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation disproportionately impacts patients with cirrhosis, yet little is known about the comparative effectiveness and safety of oral anticoagulants (OAC), in this high-risk population. The proposed study will provide robust and timely evidence regarding the effects of specific OAC strategies in patients with cirrhosis and atrial fibrillation, to better inform clinical care and optimize OAC prescribing and stroke prevention. This work will also yield a highly flexible and generalizable infrastructure for assessing therapeutic drug effects in vulnerable patients with cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will be the first to longitudinally examine the brain basis of preschool language development in typical children and late talkers. Children with language delay are at risk for a host of later academic and socio- emotional problems, but we do not have good predictive models of who will have negative outcomes. Elucidating the drivers of development has implications for the screening of language delay with objective biomarkers to mechanistically inform early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Secretory diarrhea remains a leading cause of mortality and morbidity among children worldwide with limited treatment options. This proposal employs rotavirus, the most common cause of fatal infectious diarrhea, to investigate the role of the volume-regulated anion channel in mediating secretory activity in the intestinal epithelium. This will unveil novel signaling pathways in the epithelium and identify potential targets for anti- diarrheal therapeutics, contributing to the NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge and apply it to reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Cells in the same tissue can express the exact same gene at different levels, and these deviant differences increase with age. In this project I will determine what causes gene expression variation to increase with age using C. elegans and human tissue cultures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We have discovered that an innate immune signaling pathway, mediated by the cGAS and STING proteins, is necessary to elicit natural killer cells to reject tumors, and that the two proteins act in different cells: cGAS in the tumor cells and STING in non-tumor cells. Our results suggest that cGAMP, an intermediary molecule that is made by cGAS and activates STING, is made in the tumor cells and transferred to other cells to induce the response, and we have identified transporter molecules that may be responsible for transfer of cGAMP from cell to cell. We propose to investigate the role of the cGAS-STING pathway, cGAMP transfer and the transporters we have discovered, in T and NK cell responses to cancer and viral infections in vivo. 1

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This project aims to unravel the mechanisms of impaired walking automaticity in PD in order to develop, in the long term, more effective rehabilitation interventions or pharmacological trials to restore gait automaticity during normal daily activities. Gait automaticity, or the ability to multitask while walking, is a critical functional skill that may be improved with the addition of appropriate rehabilitation, such as cueing on top of the standard pharmacological treatment with levodopa. Our outcomes, mobile imaging (fNIRS) and inertial gait measures in the laboratory will elucidate the mechanisms underlying walking automaticity deficits in people with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Relevance Statement The proposed novel strategy for how the synthesis of natural products is approached will accelerate their exploration as new avenues for small molecule intervention against cancers of the brain and breast, Alzheimer’s, inflammation, and both cardiovascular and infectious disease. The structure-activity relationships derived from biological studies of simplified derivatives identified in route to the targeted natural products through our approach, along with derived cellular probes, will lead to identification of novel therapeutic targets impacting the treatment of human disease. The identification of novel small molecule-protein interactions is critical for the development of the next generation of human therapeutics and the proposed research will contribute significantly to this arena.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subsequent malignant neoplasms are the leading cause of mortality in childhood, adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors. In particular, the risk of colorectal cancer is elevated in this population, and it is critical to identify risk factors associated with colorectal cancer development in order to identify high-risk survivors for screening and prevention. The proposed study pools individual participant data on 51,309 survivors from 8 international childhood and AYA cohorts in order to comprehensively examine risk factors of, and mortality after, subsequent colorectal cancer.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Endothelial cells regulate arterial contractility. Dysfunctional control of contractility by endothelial cells is a hallmark of several cardiovascular diseases, including hypertension, but pathological mechanisms involved are poorly understood. We will investigate the novel hypothesis that TMEM16A channels regulate arterial contractility, investigate signaling mechanisms involved and test the concept that vasodilation mediated by these proteins is dysfunctional during hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Modern studies collect complex patient level information over serially administered tasks of a biobehavioral modality, across multiple modalities and at potentially multiple longitudinal visits. Our proposal characterizes recorded data as high-dimensional highly structured functional objects, and develops a principled statistical framework for its joint analysis. The proposed methodological framework will provide interpretation and rigorous inference from these data structures, which will help guide medical and health care decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Centrioles are core components of centrosomes, which organise the dynamic microtubule cytoskeleton, and primary cilia, which enable many signalling pathways. Plk4-mediated centriole amplification results in tissue hyperplasia and increased susceptibility to tumorigenesis in the mouse providing a model for the supernumerary or defective centrosomes found in a high proportion of human tumors. This research will advance our understanding of cellular responses to supernumerary centrosomes and identify pathways that can be targeted for restoring centriole numbers or cell cycle regulation or for directing such cells to cell death, thereby finding translational application in the development of multiple drug strategies for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Men and women over the age of 65 are the most vulnerable population during severe environmental heat events, experiencing significantly worse health outcomes than any other age cohort. The global population of aged individuals is growing rapidly, resulting in an increasingly larger vulnerable population as the frequency and severity of heat waves continue to increase. While there is a vast literature detailing age-related declines in physiological responses to environmental heat stress, the significant question remains: In what specific environments does this age disparity begin to occur? Our laboratory originally developed, and has a long history of using, a unique, rigorous, and reproducible approach to identify critical environmental limits to prolonged heat exposure specific to older men and women. This research approach combines physiological and biophysical approaches to delineate safe from potentially unsafe environmental conditions for older adults from a human heat balance standpoint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease is a chronic debilitating condition affecting 3 million Americans. Its cause is not known but genetics are a risk factor, and my prior work has uncovered that cells with endocrine and neuronal properties that inhabit the gut wall play an important role in this condition. This proposal aims to characterize the role of these cell populations in chronic intestinal inflammation, which ultimately may open the door for novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continued tobacco use among cancer survivors is a cause of second primary cancers and increased overall mortality, thus, there is an urgent need to develop novel smoking cessation interventions that particularly target cancer-specific risk factors of smoking relapse in real-time given chronic levels of high stress and unique cessation barriers in this population. We propose to develop a mindfulness-based intervention for smoking cessation tailored for cancer survivors, that delivers intervention content via smartphone application in real-time when risk of smoking relapse is high. This project will result in a highly scalable and cost-effective intervention for cancer survivors ready to be tested in a large-scale clinical trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of epigenetic gene regulatory mechanisms, including DNA methylation, has been linked to human neurodevelopmental disorders, intellectual disability, and craniofacial abnormalities. The TET family of DNA demethylases have also been implicated in these disorders. This proposal investigates how TET enzymes regulate neural stem cell biology and embryonic neurodevelopment. Findings from this study will enhance our understanding of the epigenetic regulation of neurodevelopment and could facilitate the identification of new therapeutic targets to improve treatment of neurodevelopmental disorders.

Results from this study will contribute to scientific knowledge that will inform the design of health insurance programs in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 3 million people in the United States have been diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), a chronic and incurable condition of unknown cause that carries with it significant morbidity and healthcare costs. It has been recognized that the composition of the intestinal bacteria is abnormal in IBD and this contributes to the development of disease, but the specific mechanisms by which the intestinal bacteria become abnormal and how this causes IBD are not fully known. The proposed research will explore how adenosine produced in the gastrointestinal lumen regulates intestinal inflammation through its action on the intestinal microbiota and how these host-microbe interactions can be targeted therapeutically to treat IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid overdose remains one of the biggest challenges we face in public health, with over 70% of nearly 71,000 drug overdose deaths in 2019 linked to opioids and it continues to surge. To address this crisis, we need a better understanding of the fundamental reaction and adaptation of the brain in response to opioids. Our goal is to develop genetically encoded, fluorescent sensor proteins that detect opioid receptor activation downstream by monitoring secondary increases of reactive oxygen species levels that could reveal adaptation of opioid signaling in real time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have performed a genome-wide screen for gene modifications that protect beta cells against immune- mediated killing in a mouse model for type 1 diabetes. This powerful and stringent screen identified the type 1 diabetes-associated gene RNLS that we have now extensively validated for its effect on beta cell resistance in both mouse islet cells and human stem cell-derived beta cells. This research aims to further understand how RNLS deletion protects beta cells against autoimmunity and whether targeting this gene pharmacologically could provide a new avenue for the prevention of type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Sport-related concussion (SRC) is a significant public health problem resulting in over 200,000 annual trips to the Emergency Department (ED) in the United States. Mounting evidence from human studies has demonstrated that repetitive head impact exposure (HIE) may contribute to decreased SRC tolerance in contact sport athletes. The goal of this project is to utilize modern machine learning and statistical methods and use head impact characteristics, player and team information to determine the SRC risk factors and factors influencing post-SRC recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it supports the National Institute of Aging mission to accelerate the translation of treatments for human aging. This project seeks to further determine if a population that is not already burdened by chronic disease can benefit from metformin treatment. Successful completion of the study will help inform which subjects could benefit from metformin treatment to slow aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicidal ideation and behaviors are common across the psychosis continuum, particularly among youth experiencing the earliest signs and symptoms of a psychotic disorder. Despite the high risk for suicidal ideation and behavior in this group, there are currently no suicide prevention approaches specifically designed for youth at clinical high-risk for psychosis. This project will adapt the evidence-based “Youth-Nominated Support Teams” intervention, tailoring it for transition-aged youth and young adults receiving clinical high-risk for psychosis mental health services. Using client, family, and stakeholder input, we will develop, implement, and revise the intervention, and then test its impact in a preliminary randomized trial at four psychosis-risk clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our published and preliminary data have shown for the first time that purified B lymphocytes from blood or spleen delivered within 6 hours at the site of a contusion traumatic brain injury (TBI) significantly reduced learning and memory deficits, and reduced lesion volume, gliosis, and microglial activation. The present proposal aims to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms of B cell-mediated neuroprotection after this type of injury, ultimately positioning this novel cell-based therapy for clinical use in the context of contusion TBI. Since purified mature B cells can be readily accessed from peripheral blood in donors, without pre-treatment, the long-term benefits of this research would include establishing a rapid, minimally-manipulated B cell therapy that could be given to patients to improve outcome after TBI.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Conformational dynamics plays a fundamental role in gene regulation by many regulatory non-coding RNAs, such as riboswitches that are widely found in bacteria, including some important pathogenic bacteria. The proposed structural, dynamic, and functional studies of co- transcriptional regulation of riboswitches will bring new insights into the molecular understanding of their regulatory mechanisms, hence providing basis for developing riboswitch-based regulatory tools for synthetic biology and riboswitch-targeted antimicrobial therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: This proposed project focuses on a unique population of regulatory T cells that is located in skeletal muscle and regulates local repair/regeneration after acute or chronic injury. The identification of factors that promote the expansion and survival of these populations, or reparative factors that they produce, should deepen our understanding of and eventually aid our treatment of muscular dystrophies, autoimmune myositides and chronic muscle infections. There should also be applications to age-associated deficiencies in muscle mass, function and repair – a growing health problem with our aging society – as well as to battle and other severe wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The objective of this project is to fill the knowledge gap of how an FDA-approved oral formula of small molecules, tRES+HESP, can enhance the new blood vessel formation in treating non- healing wounds in diabetic patients as a topical application. We will evaluate the therapeutic potential of tRES+HESP and its underlying molecular mechanisms in human vascular endothelial cells in Aim 1, and in a newly developed diabetic chronic wound animal model in Aim 2, using a combination of cell culture and animal studies (for causal mechanisms in vitro and in vivo) and cutting-edge proteomics studies (for global analysis of cell signaling & unbiased discovery). The outcome of the proposed research will determine the efficacy of topical application of this formula, tRES+HESP, in diabetic wound healing, and will unveil underlying molecular mechanisms for its beneficial effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to leverage several research studies of persons with HIV (PWH) that measured phosphatidylethanol (PEth), a biomarker of how much alcohol someone has consumed over the past month that is found in the blood, to investigate key questions about how alcohol use affects the health of persons with HIV and how to reduce alcohol use. We will also use these data to explore other ways to measure alcohol use via common blood tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative. Medicaid expansion increases health care access and reduces food and housing insecurity thus improving health and providing a tool to reduce health disparities. This project links Medicaid member claims, pre-post survey data, and community-level public health data to examine how access to primary care during the first year of enrollment is modified by sociocultural, built environment, and health care domains of influence as well as whether primary care use reduces social needs one year after enrollment. Results will help state Medicaid agencies formulate policies to reduce social needs and more equitably improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO HUMAN HEALTH Alcoholism and drug addiction are chronic diseases with limited treatment options, creating a significant legal, social, and public health burden. Historically, these and many other complex diseases have been investigated using mouse genetic approaches, but extrapolation of results from mouse studies to human populations remains a challenge. The Mouse Phenome Database is a widely used database platform that meets this challenge through sharing of well-documented mouse data and tools, that in turn enables researchers to integrate and analyze information across studies, and translate mouse results into human health relevance. The MPD therefore provides a unique platform for investigation of addiction and other complex human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide novel insights into the role of long-range inhibitory neurons in different states of cortical activity that occur during sleep and wakefulness. This research will be significant because it will clarify the mechanisms by which the firing activity of a specific type of long-range inhibitory neuron influences cortical states in health and in disease. This is relevant to the NIH mission to seek fundamental knowledge of the visual system and to use this knowledge to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The neuromodulator dopamine is important for normal brain function, and defects in dopamine signaling are associated with brain disorders, for example with neurodegeneration in Parkinson's Disease. We will generate precise understanding of the regulatory and signaling mechanisms of dopamine in the striatum, a brain structure essential for movement control. Our studies will provide new insight into dopamine neuron cell biology, may uncover general principles for neuromodulation, and may reveal new targets for developing treatments for neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of urine proteomic biomarkers could shift the management strategy of lupus nephritis to prevention, potentially leading to earlier, more effective, and less toxic treatment. This R01 explores three new outcomes: 1) development of a urine biomarker panel to identify new lupus nephritis (biopsy confirmed) BEFORE proteinuria; 2) development of a urine biomarker panel to predict renal flare when tapering immunosuppression in patients with treated nephritis (and no proteinuria); and 3) leverage omic data from the SLE AMP program to identify predictors of chronic kidney disease trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE As the most abundant cell type in the intestinal epithelium, enterocytes build specialized structures known as ‘brush borders’ on their surface to enable nutrient uptake from the gut lumen. Despite occupying a critical physiological interface, our understanding on how enterocytes assemble and organize brush borders, or how they coordinate their function at the tissue-scale remains unclear. This proposal will investigate mechanisms underlying the assembly and organization of apical brush borders, and on a larger scale the nutrient absorbing luminal surface of the gut; this work will generate insight on processes underlying normal gut function as well as human diseases characterized by perturbation to enterocyte structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Nine out of 10 adults with an addiction disorder started using by early adolescence, a developmental period defined by increased peer-centric social interactions, risk taking, and drug use. We have demonstrated the refinement/“pruning” of dopamine receptors within the brain by the primary immune cells of the brain, microglia, during adolescence in rats; this proposal will test the significance of this pruning for addiction later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal plasticity is how neurons change their connections with other neurons and is essential for normal brain development and function. However, plasticity also underlies addiction and is misregulated in disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. We propose to identify and study novel molecular mechanisms of neuronal plasticity, using circadian clock neurons as neurons with highly predictable plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to foster innovative research strategies and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health. Children with septic shock face exceptionally high rates of morbidity and mortality as well as high rates of red blood cell (RBC) transfusion, which may contribute to poor outcomes. This R01 proposal seeks to provide crucial information on patient- specific and blood product-specific factors that influence transfusion-related risks to inform the design and evaluation of precision-medicine based transfusion strategies to improve outcomes in these extremely ill infants and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will elucidate and model the effects of nonlinear outer-hair-cell based ampliﬁcation—whose impairment underlies the most common forms of sensorineural hearing loss—for the representation of complex sounds in the healthy cochlea. Motivated by the discrepancy between the experimental data and the common understanding of the role of the auditory periphery for central auditory mechanisms, the goal of this project is to understand the cochlear mechanisms responsible for the outstanding performance of the healthy ear in acoustically adverse situations. Results of this project will ﬁnd direct applications to improving models of hearing loss and to developing new sound processing paradigms for assistive hearing technology.

PHR: Project Narrative The flavor of food is largely determined by its taste features, such as salty and sour tastes that are elicited by salt and acid respectively. Abnormal oral perception of salt and acid can lead to inappropriate consumption of salt and acid, leading to many nutrition-related health concerns. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is almost universally fatal. We previously identified the DCLK1-expressing metaplastic tuft cell in metaplastic and neoplastic lesions early in disease progression where they are hypothesized to act as tumor progenitor cells, but also have a chemosensory function that they utilize to modify the fibroinflammatory response. In this proposal, novel genetic models will be employed to explore the origin and definitively determine the functions of the metaplastic tuft cell in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative Little is known on the regulatory pathways mediating transgenerational epigenetic inheritance. Our results provide genetic evidence for a novel pathway in mice that regulates high fat diet response in the next generation and that is governed by the E3 ligase Rlim in paternal testicular Sertoli cells. Investigating this Sertoli cell --> sperm --> offspring pathway, our research will uncover novel epigenetic mechanisms and establish our conditional Rlim KO mice as a new paradigm for transgenerational epigenetic regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In this grant we are studying a genetic autoimmune disease called COPA syndrome which has similarities to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Using an animal model of COPA syndrome, we are trying to understand why patients with COPA syndrome develop inflammation in their lungs, joints and kidney. We will test whether we can use new drugs called small molecule inhibitors to reverse inflammation caused by one of the proteins that is abnormally stimulated to understand whether the drugs might be beneficial in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative About 90% of people with alcohol use disorder (AUD) do not receive treatment, with even lower rates among women, Black/African American individuals, and people from other under-represented groups. Care for AUD has typically focused on referrals to specialty addiction treatment programs, which have barriers to accessibility and are stigmatized, thus not widely appealing. To address this gap, this project will use a sequential, multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) design to examine a novel virtually-delivered engagement and treatment delivery model that can be integrated in healthcare systems to substantially improve utilization and outcomes and reduce disparities in care for this chronic condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 7. Project Summary/Abstract Girls and women are diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) much less frequently than males and females have been under-studied in autism research. The overarching goal of this research program is to rectify the historical underrepresentation of females in ASD research by evaluating a large, longitudinal cohort of girls from early to middle childhood. As in so many other areas of medicine, the optimal treatment of girls and women with ASD will only emerge when sex-related autism attributes and problems are adequately understood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Elevated stress is known to enhance risk for opioid use disorder (OUD), a significant problem given the broad use of opioid analgesics in both acute and chronic pain management. This project will test an innovative model in which low endogenous opioid (EO) and endocannabinoid (EC) activity associated with elevated stress both contribute to increased OUD risk via their association with heightened reinforcing effects of opioids (e.g., drug liking). Results will provide important new mechanistic understanding of how stress increases OUD risk, and may identify a novel and clinically-pragmatic marker of risk-enhancing differential opioid responding.

This proposal is designed to study the hypothesis that dysfunction of the pulmonary vasculature plays a critical role in the progression of lung fibrosis. Experiments of this grant will investigate the contribution of molecular abnormalities we have discovered in the lung vasculature toward our long term goal of identifying novel targets for the treatment of IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative There is a shortage of researchers with the high levels of interdisciplinary skills needed to make progress in understanding the etiology and improving clinical treatment of alcohol use disorder (AUD), a major public health problem. The objective of this training grant is to educate the next generation of researchers focused on i) elucidating the risk factors for and outcomes of problem alcohol use, ii) understanding the behavioral and molecular causes and consequences of problem alcohol use, and iii) contributing to the translation of these basic findings into improvements in both treatment and prevention of AUD. The training in this program aims to educate an interdisciplinary diverse work force of researchers with a solid knowledge of multiple relevant areas, including genetics, behavior, neurobiology, data science and clinical treatment who will be prepared to have an impact on the health of millions of individuals affected by AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Impaired astrocyte coupling is associated with epilepsy, but there is no consensus on whether reduced coupling promotes or counteracts abnormal neuronal activity, which precedes seizures. Targeting astrocytic Cx43 might be an option, but the first step towards therapy is determining when reduced coupling is adaptive and when it is maladaptive. This proposal uses new tools and technology to determine if the timing and duration of reduced astrocyte coupling may determine if seizures are promoted or counteracted, and will identify critical upstream signaling causing reduced astrocyte coupling as a foundation for future therapeutic targeting.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is a sensitive period for the development of addiction. With many physical and emotional changes occurring during this time of life, it is crucial to identify the underlying factors that affect adolescents’ enhanced vulnerability. Building upon preliminary data that suggests adolescents are more sensitive to the behavioral consequences of gut microbiome manipulation, this proposal will examine the contribution of gut-derived metabolites to adolescent opioid self-administration and epigenetic chromatin alterations in prefrontal cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal waves are highly correlated spontaneous firing patterns detected in the developing retina prior to maturation of visual responses, and they provide a critical source of activity to drive the refinement of connections throughout the developing visual system. Retinal waves are a robust phenomenon detected in many vertebrate species, and they persist through the changing circuits of the developing retina. Our work will determine the cellular and synaptic basis of these waves with the goal of understanding their spatiotemporal features that are critical for development of visual circuits. Moreover, we will determine the relative contribution of waves and light-activation of intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells in the regulation of dopamine levels, a neuromodulator critical for development of the retina and surrounding tissues. This work with will contribute to a detailed understanding of the organizing principles that govern the normal development of retinal circuits, contributing to our understanding the origin of some neurological birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The University of Washington Practice-Based Suicide Prevention Research Center will improve suicide care in outpatient medical settings through enhancing therapeutic alliance and increased self-efficacy of providers, patients and families to manage suicide risk. The Center's approach to improving outcomes across the suicide care pathway from identification of suicide risk through assessment to decision making and risk management, crisis response, treatment of suicidality, and long-term surveillance and follow-up is consistent with the recommendations of the Joint Commission, Zero Suicide, National Action Alliance for Suicide Prevention, and the Surgeon General as well as the Biden Administration's 2021 proclamation on mental health. Over the five year time frame, the team will conduct one full size optimization trial, three human centered design exploratory studies, and eight pilot studies co-designing interventions with health care providers, patients, and families to make coordinated improvements across the suicide care pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As a novel approach to the treatment of HIV, this proposal seeks to provide a solution to eventually eliminate the pool of cells harboring latent virus. We will express surface-bound and soluble broadly- neutralizing antibodies targeting HIV that are highly effective against a diverse range of HIV strains. As the surface-bound antibodies recognize viral proteins on infected cells, this recognition will lead to its killing, while soluble antibodies neutralize free virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance: Project summary: Relevance to public health. As Type II Diabetes Mellitus rates continue to reach epidemic proportions, driving health and economic costs higher, the need to find safe, effective, and economically achievable therapies for the treatment of this disease is ever increasing. For this reason, much attention has been devoted to investigating pharmacological drugs based on the hormone GLP-1 for diabetes treatment, as it lowers blood glucose concentrations. Unfortunately, nausea and vomiting are the major side effects of all GLP-1-based drugs on the market, with ~25% of patients unable to tolerate effective doses. Novel research proposed here fully analyzes the effects of chemical attachment of vitamin B12 with an FDA approved GLP-1 based drug, the result of which is the complete elimination of all nausea and vomiting side effects, but retention of the desired blood glucose lowering profile – in essence creating a new second generation of improved GLP-1 therapeutics for diabetes treatment, which improves patient quality of life and expands the population that can benefit from such important therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) affects more than 16 million US adults, many of whom experience high rates of acute care revisits after initial COPD hospitalizations due to transitions of care (TOC) failures. My current NHLBI R01 aims to address gaps in effectiveness and implementation of COPD TOC programs by testing COPD TOC intervention bundles across 20 diverse US hospitals, utilizing rigorous implementation science (IS) and human-centered design (HCD) methods. This K24 will allow me to work with my team of mentees to address methodology gaps by developing, testing, and disseminating two innovative tools, including the "CHIMERA" crosswalk, which will optimize qualitative data collection to inform intervention design, and the "SMART COPD" framework, which will standardize data collection and reporting metrics across COPD TOC programs and allow for inter-program comparisons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The focus of this project is on deciphering the molecular mechanisms of compensatory hepatocyte proliferation in liver regeneration following hepatic damages. Our preliminary data have suggested a new function of CD133, a well-known biomarker in stem cells and cancer stem cells, in mediating intercellular communication to compensate deficit in intracellular proliferative signaling. Success of this project will elucidate a previously unappreciated inherent function of normal and cancer cells, which may be implicated in drug resistance of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Slowing muscle loss and increasing strength and physical function may be important to increasing health- related quality of life among individuals undergoing chemotherapy for advanced upper gastrointestinal cancers. We aim to test the feasibility, safety, and acceptability of a home-based, “tele-resistance training” program in which patients will engage in exercise sessions via video conferences with certified trainers. We will compare changes in fitness, muscle health, health-related quality of life, fatigue, and physical functioning between patients participating in tele-RT and patients who have no exercise program to better understand the value of exercise in this context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stochastic fluctuations in gene expression impact cell-fate specification decisions from embryogenesis to viral infection creating barriers for effective treatment interventions. Based on therapeutic precedents in neuroscience that use fluctuations to improve sensorimotor function, this project will identify centralized molecular and cellular mechanisms of noise modulation, that can be therapeutically targeted, in embryonic stem cells (ESCs). The proposed research will lead to development of new broad-spectrum noise modulators, and propel clinical translation of noise-modulating molecules to guide new therapeutic approaches that overcome barriers to precise cell-fate control in diverse mammalian systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many genetic risk factors have been found for the various neurodegenerative diseases, but few of them have been functionally characterized in a way that is likely to lead to therapies for the millions of people who suffer from Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson’s Disease, Frontotemporal Dementia, and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. We seek here to understand how one genetic risk factor, TMEM106B, confers risk for neuronal loss, through lysosomal pathways that may affect a spectrum of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although current clinical evidence suggests that the potential benefits of tube feeding do not exceed considerable associated treatment burdens in older adults with advanced dementia, rates of tube feeding remain disproportionally high among Chinese-American older adults with advanced dementia. This proposed project will culturally adapt an existing decision aid intervention to improve decision-making about feeding options for Chinese-American dementia patients. If effective, this intervention will indicate the utility of decision aids as a methodology with broader applications to decision-making in end-of-life care in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial infections among young infants, including sepsis, meningitis, pneumonia, and others, continue to have a substantial burden in developing countries and are estimated to cause ~33% of neonatal deaths. The proposed randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial will examine whether zinc supplementation combined with standard antibiotic treatment improves survival and treatment outcomes for Tanzanian young infants 0-59 days with clinical severe infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Biological membranes are self-assembled molecular walls that are found within and around the cells of all living organisms. Rather than serving simply as barriers to establish boundaries however, these essential dynamic structures provide a unique environment for organizing steps in biological pathways. This work will elucidate whether proteins in membrane- associated pathways that elaborate sugar structures perform their function, as isolated entities or as collaborative teams. Ultimately this work will provide insight into fundamental biological processes including bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Wisconsin Comprehensive Cancer Center (UWCCC), in collaboration with the National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN), seeks to bring innovative cancer treatment trials to the population of Wisconsin and its neighboring regions to reduce the burden of cancer. Through leadership in the NCTN Cooperative group program, the UWCCC faculty are working to design the next generation of genomically-directed clinical trials, as well as those that utilize advanced imaging techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The supply-to-demand ratio of tRNAs relative to the codon usage in a cell determines the fitness of the cell. While most studies show that the supply in the form of tRNA abundance correlates with the codon usage, little is known about the supply in the form of tRNA post-transcriptional modifications. We will use E. coli as a starting point to elucidate the principles of how the status of tRNA post-transcriptional modifications influences the translation of a specific codon usage pattern to the proteome, test the predictive power of the principles in the human proteome, and evaluate the principles in a mitochondrial disease.
