IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While personal cannabis use and secondhand cannabis smoke exposure is prevalent among youth, the influence of these on adolescent cognitive development remains understudied. Cannabis product complexity and limitations of self-report may obscure important relationships between delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and neurocognitive development/outcomes. Here we propose using quantifiable toxicological information of personal and secondhand cannabis exposure from hair to predict cognitive functioning over time in adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a major public health concern both in terms of its impact on personal and family relationships and its tremendous economic costs due to lost productivity and health-related impairments. Improving the effectiveness of treatment of AUD requires improving our understanding of the neurobiological basis of addiction and the limitations of currently available intervention approaches. The proposed project will provide advanced training to both clinical and basic science researchers that will provide them with the knowledge base and research skills to investigate the neurobiology of addiction and develop improved therapeutic strategies to treat AUD.
PROJECT_TERMS: alcohol research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Alcohol Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Parkinson disease (PD) is a common neurodegenerative disorder affecting at least 1% of the population above the age of 60. There is no effective treatment for dementia and falls, leading to residential care placements, substantial morbidity and mortality. This study utilizing non-invasive imaging techniques will investigate novel brain pathways to identify at-risk PD patients before these disabling symptoms manifest and ultimately help develop effective, targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many individuals with substance use disorders (SUDs) do not seek treatment in specialty SUD treatment programs, particularly those in rural settings and those with co-occurring medical and mental health conditions. The integration of SUD treatment into healthcare settings under the ACA-driven healthcare reform requires research to identify, engage, and treat individuals with SUDs more effectively within primary and acute care settings, using electronic medical records to identify individuals at risk and utilizing novel treatment and technology approaches to address their substance use disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative:  Noise trauma is a leading cause of hearing disorders for which there are no cures, underscoring the need for prevention, but there are no FDA-approved pharmacological interventions to prevent hearing loss. We have shown that specific neurotransmitter receptors in the cochlea can be antagonized to prevent noise trauma while others remain active to mediate hearing, however, local delivery of drugs to a healthy cochlea is too invasive and systemic dosing is only tolerated if side effects can be avoided. This proposal investigates the precise molecular composition of AMPA-type glutamate receptor pore-forming and auxiliary subunits in the cochlea, so that they may be specifically targeted with systemic pharmacology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Circadian Effects in the Stroke Penumbra Almost all stroke experiments in rats and mice are performed during the day-time. For nocturnal rodents, this is their inactive phase. Almost all stroke patients are also recruited to neuroprotection trials in the day-time. But for diurnal humans, this is their active phase. Recently, we proposed that this “circadian mismatch” between rodent models and clinical trials may contribute to translational failure for neuroprotection. In this project, we will dissect the mechanisms that mediate circadian effects in the stroke penumbra, focusing on neuroprotection, blood flow regulation, cell death, and the exploration of novel targets in active-phase strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE:  Loud sounds can damage both middle- and inner-ears and cause temporary or permanent hearing loss, however, little is known of how the middle ear transmits these harmful sounds to the inner ear. Ear surgeons can repair damaged middle ears with reconstruction surgeries, but how well these reconstructed ears work at high level sounds has not been well described. Understanding responses of normal and reconstructed middle ears to loud sounds can help better predict noise-induced hearing damage, develop new strategies for ear protection and improve the repair of sound-damaged middle ears.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The goal of this grant is to train alcohol research scientists. Training scientists in alcohol research methods is essential to understanding the complex nature of binge drinking and alcohol use disorder. Multi-disciplinary training in molecular mechanisms of alcoholic pathology will cover fetal, brain, genetic, behavioral and other pathologies involved in long-term drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance The epidemic of obesity is affecting more than one third of the adults in the US. Common obesity is usually accompanied by elevated circulating levels of leptin, the primary adipostatic factor in mammals, however resistance to leptin develops, preventing the maintenance of normal body weight. This application explores methods for augmenting leptin sensitivity, which may represent a safe and effective means of treating obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to robustly, selectively and flexibly encode visual information is fundamental to our sense of vision. We will bring state-of-the-art imaging approaches to reveal how functional convergence of distinct sources of inputs may reinforce the computation of select channels of visual information. Our studies will contribute to the understanding and treatment of various neurological and psychiatric disorders that involve inappropriate connectivity pattern formation and abnormal signal integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Lay Language Description Trachoma is the leading cause of infectious blindness worldwide and has been targeted for global elimination as a public health problem by 2030. Population-level assessment of trachoma through antibodies in blood is a promising approach to monitor transmission as countries approach and achieve elimination. We will combine information across 19 separate field studies (>100,000 people, mainly in Africa) to develop summary methods that translate antibodies in blood into population-level measures of trachoma endemicity, and determine if using spatial information in the design and analysis of serologic surveys could improve their usefulness to trachoma control programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only a minor fraction of immunocompetent humans develop tuberculosis with massive necrotic granulomas and cavitation in their lungs, but the host mechanisms causing this vulnerability are poorly characterized. We will use a well characterized mouse model that recapitulates the formation of organized necrotic pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) granulomas to examine the interplay of host mechanisms of susceptibility with the necrosis-inducing factor of virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). Because necrosis of TB granulomas is a major obstacle to the sterilization of TB lesions with antibiotics, this study will lead to host-directed therapies that will synergize with antibiotics to shorten and improve TB chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-translational modification of proteins by methylation regulates diverse signaling pathways that play important roles in human health and disease. We propose to investigate the molecular mode of action for several key protein methylase enzymes in mammalian cells. This proposal will provide insights into how protein methylation regulates fundamental cellular functions, including chromatin dynamics, and has the potential to identify new and clinically actionable targets to treat cancers and other pathologies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is a leading cause of illness and death for children under five years of age globally, with most of these deaths resulting from infection by the Plasmodium falciparum parasite. The goal of this application is to improve our understanding of how the transmission stage of malaria parasites develops. By understanding the unique features of transmission stage development, we can identify proteins and processes that can be targeted by future therapies to block malaria from spreading.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developing culturally responsive, acceptable and feasible interventions to promote school readiness is key to reducing the disparities that exist in educational attainment of Latino children living in poverty. The studies described will develop and pilot test a school readiness program based in primary care for Spanish speaking parent-child dyads that is centered on the preferences of Latino parents, their pediatric providers and early childhood educators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In recent years there has been a significant interest in developing anti-checkpoint inhibitors such as anti-PD-1 and anti-CTLA-4 for the treatment of breast cancer. Although some triple negative breast cancer patients respond well to these treatments, most women are resistant to this therapy. We are proposing to develop a safe and effective virus in combination with anti-immune checkpoint inhibitors for the treatment of triple negative breast cancer. This will lead to future combination therapy trials with anti-PD-1 and anti-CTLA-4 in breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal describes the improvement and adaptation of a high throughput single cell analysis technology for simultaneous and multiplexed measurement of proteins, protein complexes and mRNA in thousands of individual cells, and studying key hypotheses on the development and signaling in hematopoietic stem cells and germinal center B cells. We will characterize thousands of key protein species regulating pro- inflammatory signaling responses and development in cells from the hematopoietic lineage and the germinal center, and combine this data with mathematical modeling and live-cell imaging to understand mechanisms underlying signal-specific gene regulation, variability and dynamics. Our practical and broadly applicable technology will rapidly and quantitatively evaluate a vast space of proteomic states, generate improved insight on the signaling and evolution of immune networks, and make a substantial impact into understanding and modeling of infection, autoimmunity, immune development and emergence of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: As animals navigate their environments, their nervous systems transition between a wide range of internal states that influence how sensory information is processed and how behaviors are generated. While virtually all animals organize their behavioral outputs in this state-like fashion, it remains unclear how internal states are generated and how they are able to influence behavior. Here, we propose to examine how brain-wide activity encodes the diverse motor programs of C. elegans across a range of aversive internal states, which should enhance our fundamental understanding of how the nervous system encodes behavior and how internal states influence the neural circuits that encode behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The DEK oncogene is over-expressed in ~60% of breast cancers as well as in all other solid tumors tested to date; however, the mechanisms by which it promotes tumor formation and growth are very poorly understood. We have recently identified that one potential mechanism of DEK-induced oncogenic phenotypes is the upregulation of Wnt expression and downstream pathway activation, which is a common occurrence in triple negative breast cancer. Importantly, we are the first to investigate how Wnt proteins may induce an M2-like polarization of tumor associated macrophages in order to convert the immune system into a tumor-promoting role rather than a tumor-fighting one. Understanding how DEK promotes tumorigenesis, including the potential relationship between Wnt signaling and anti-tumor immune responses from TAMs, will better inform treatment decisions and potentially maximize the therapeutic effect of combining immunotherapies and chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A fundamental challenge to finding effective treatments for neuropsychiatric disorders is the paucity of biomarkers that can gauge whether a potential intervention affects abnormal circuitry early in the treatment development pipeline, before embarking on expensive and lengthy clinical trials. This research proposal will develop novel physiological assays of sleep-dependent memory consolidation in humans and rodents that can be used to predict the efficacy of newly emerging treatments. These assays will enable the efficient screening and identification of treatments that can alleviate highly disabling cognitive deficits in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of sleep is a pervasive societal issue that leads to both off- and on-the-job accidents and lost revenue from performance deficiencies. Poor sleep and sleep insufficiency are even risk factors for five of the eight leading causes of death in the US. Exactly how inadequate sleep affects the brain is enigmatic; therefore, in this project we will investigate key mechanistic pathways that underlie the negative impacts of poor sleep and sleep insufficiency on cognitive functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We have discovered that Notch4 has distinct pro-angiogenic and inflammatory function that differ significantly from the negative angiogenic regulation mediated by Notch1. Endothelial Notch4 acts to promote ocular disease and tumorigenesis and may act primarily by influencing both endothelium and adjacent stromal cells. We will study how endothelial Notch4 facilitates formation of blood vessels and inflammatory responses, allowing us to understand how angiogenesis occurs in healthy individuals and human disease. Our goal is to develop Notch4 inhibition as a candidate strategy to inhibit tumor growth and control ocular inflammatory disorders such as retinopathy and corneal neovascularization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Social and behavioral determinants of health and Alzheimer’s Disease: Cohort study of the US military  veteran population Veterans are particularly susceptible to Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) due to demographic, clinical, and economic factors. Social determinants of health are the conditions in which people are born, live, work, and age. Adverse social determinants of health include job loss and financial and food insecurity. Together with behavioral health factors (e.g., smoking and substance use) and mental health, adverse social and behavioral determinants of health (SBDH) contribute to AD. Natural language processing approaches can be developed to automatically extract SBDH and their attributes to study the associations between SBDH and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The vaginal microbiome is linked to important health conditions including bacterial vaginosis (BV), preterm birth, HIV, and cervical cancer, but reasons for these links are unclear and current BV-directed therapies do not work well. We will study how metabolites in vaginal fluid, including the potentially harmful molecules putrescine and imidazole propionate, are produced by the microbiome, how they cause inflammation in the vagina, and whether they can be blocked by pharmacological agents. The results will provide important new knowledge about causes of BV and vaginal diseases and will help to find new therapies for preventing and treating these diseases in women globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative The olfactory cortex plays key roles in odor processing, perception and memory, but the molecular mechanisms underlying olfactory cortex cell type specification remain unknown. Here, we propose to determine the gene expression and chromatin accessibility states of piriform cortex neurons in the adult mouse, and to characterize the dynamic interaction of regulatory chromatin and transcription factor activity that drive cell lineage specification during development. Our central hypothesis is that olfactory cortex cell types and their functional properties are specified by olfactory cortex-specific gene regulatory network mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of prostate cancer mortality is due to failure of endocrine therapies to maintain suppression of androgen receptor activity. The proposed studies are focused on understanding how genome structural alterations in prostate cancer cells promote persistent androgen receptor activity during endocrine therapy. This project will study and model these genome structural alterations to understand their role in supporting endocrine therapy resistance, and develop new therapeutics that eliminate tumor cells harboring these alterations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Meniscus tears are the most common injuries of the knee, and can lead to osteoarthritis in both young and aged populations. By taking advantage of multiple animal models, this project will investigate a novel signaling mechanism in meniscus metabolism and design an innovative drug delivery therapy to treat meniscus injury and thereby prevent osteoarthritis progression. Information garnered from these studies will be important for advancing our knowledge of joint biology and designing novel therapeutic strategies for meniscus repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Enteroviruses are a major source for disease and hospitalization, but currently little is known about their mechanism of infection and there is no available treatment. Using recent advances in single-cell transcriptomics and ultra-deep virus population sequencing, we will explore the dynamics of in vivo enterovirus infection and the host response to it across cells and tissues. Combining these strategies with animal models defective in specific antiviral pathways, we will gain mechanistic insights into viral spread and pathogenesis, which is critical to develop effective antiviral drugs and vaccines.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Defects in implantation are a major cause of early pregnancy loss, can underlie serious pregnancy complications, and predispose the development of disease after birth. A lack of understanding regarding the mechanisms regulating the embryo implantation and the establishment of pregnancy represents a major barrier toward the discovery of new diagnostic tools and therapeutic intervention. The goal of this proposed project is to investigate the mechanisms by which local glucocorticoid signaling regulates the establishment and maintenance of pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: We our applying our new approach to control the cellular composition of specialized fats called membrane lipids within the membrane shell that surrounds cells to understand how membrane lipids and proteins are organized to control membrane function. Studies concentrate on membrane protein receptors (including insulin receptor) that control the response of cells to their environment, and on viruses for which controlling lipids may alter their ability to enter cells and their immunogenicity. The studies may lead to new methods to control membrane protein function to ameliorate disease and optimize vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Asthma and allergic diseases are increasing in developed countries, and as adults, women have more asthma compared to men. IL-33 and its receptor, ST2, increase airway inflammation in patients with asthma, and our preliminary data suggest that testosterone and androgen receptor signaling decrease IL-33 release and allergic airway inflammation while increasing suppressive function of T regulatory cells. Findings from this proposal will provide the foundational research necessary to develop future asthma therapeutics for women and men with asthma and potentially other diseases with increased IL-33.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative World Trade Center (WTC) responders were exposed to a mix of tiny dust particles as they participated in rescue and recovery efforts at the WTC in the aftermath of 9/11/2001, and a large number may have developed cognitive impairment, a symptom consistent with some neurodegenerative diseases. Given the magnitude and scale of events surrounding 9/11 and the level of exposure within a young civilian population, prior studies are insufficient to identify the etiology of neurocognitive and neuromotor symptoms evident among responders with PTSD. The proposed study will examine Beta-Amyloid and Tau burden using positron emission tomography (PET) combined with magnetic resonance neuroimaging (MRI) on a subset of individuals recruited as part of an existing NIA- funded study of cognitive aging to measure in order to determine whether there is evidence of Alzheimer’s disease in the brains of WTC responders with symptoms consistent with Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Speech-language disorders occur in 40% of very preterm infants, while 10% have permanent hearing loss. Neonatal hearing screening and cochlear implantation within the first few months have demonstrated the extreme plasticity of the developing infant brain, but speech-language disorders are typically not detected or treated before 3 years of age. The goal of this study is to use advanced measures of brain connectivity, sensitized hearing assessment, and speech evoked EEG at birth to predict infants at risk for speech-language disorders so they can start receiving intervention within the critical first year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will produce mouse models to study two blood proteins called MASP3 and MASP2 which are part of the body’s natural immune system but could also participate in certain autoimmune and inflammatory diseases such as arthritis and kidney disease. The proposed studies will use mouse models in which these two proteins are experimentally eliminated so that their deficiency can be evaluated to see if their absence will make a difference in arthritis and kidney disease. We will also develop antibodies to these proteins and test such antibodies as drug prototypes to see if they will be effective in treating arthritis and kidney disease. These studies may lead to the development of novel therapeutics for unmet medical need in the area of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PI: Manu Ben-Johny, PhD Increased late Na current is a common pathophysiological mechanism for many cardiac ailments including congenital long QT syndrome and heart failure. In this collaborative project, we dissect the physiological role and molecular mechanisms of cardiac Na channel modulation by fibroblast growth factor homologous factors (FHF) in inhibiting late Na current in cultured adult ventricular myocytes and in induced pluripotent stem cell derived cardiomyocytes. We leverage in depth mechanisms to develop a novel peptide inhibitor of late Na current.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Macrophages represent an understudied component of the blood stem cell niche. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The nerves that sense light in the eye, the photoreceptors, and the cells of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) form a critical partnership necessary for vision. We want to understand how the RPE’s response to reduced output from its powerplants, termed mitochondria, causes adverse effects on the adjacent photoreceptors. Success of this project may provide insight into the causes of age-related macular degeneration and could suggest new avenues for therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative About 10% of prostate cancers have mutations in the SPOP gene – roughly 20,000 men will be diagnosed with SPOP mutant prostate cancer in the US each year. These cancers show distinct molecular features, and activation of specific signaling pathways. Successful completion of this project will provide insights into the biology underlying this subclass of prostate cancer, define the ability to specifically target these cancers, and identify novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches across prostate cancer classes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mayo Clinic has a long tradition of clinical research and has been a supporter and active participant in the National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN). With over 1.3 million unique patients seen each year (of which over 120,000 are patients with cancer), Mayo Clinic is committed to making clinical trials available to all patients regardless of their racial, ethnicity, or socioeconomic background. A major factor in allowing this to occur is through Mayo Clinic's commitment to making NCTN trials a prominent part of its portfolio of clinical trials for cancer patients or patients at-risk for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Cranial neural crest cells are essential for the formation of diverse craniofacial structures including bones and cartilage as well as portions of cranial ganglia; as such, defects in cranial neural crest specification, epithelial- to-mesenchymal transition, and differentiation are root to many craniofacial birth defects including craniosynestosis, Treacher Collins and CHARGE syndromes. This project will identify the mechanisms that control BMP signaling during its essential roles in cranial neural crest specification and will determine the molecular function of BMP signaling during cranial neural crest epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition. The results will provide significant and novel avenues for translational approaches to prevent and treat neural crest-derived craniofacial birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The goal of this clinical trial is to improve current functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) language mapping practices for diagnostic neurosurgical planning, including for patients with pre-existing language deficits. The movie-watching language mapping test that will be developed uses naturalistic stimuli predicted to engage more completely the neural networks supporting language in real life. Our goal is to test and publicly share a novel method of comprehensive language mapping which is applicable in more neurosurgical patients, especially those with language deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Release of calcium ions from their intracellular storage location in skeletal muscle due to physiological muscle fiber depolarization is a prerequisite for all skeletal muscle activity, including that involved in locomotion and breathing. Here we first study how individual regions of the voltage sensing molecule for muscle activation function to turn on muscle calcium release in normal muscle during normal activation. We then study how disease mutations of the voltage sensing molecule alter its functional properties, thereby contributing to the disease status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Aphasia is an acquired speech/language deficit most commonly resulting from left-hemisphere stroke and is a leading cause of communication disability in the United States posing a significant barrier to professional, social, and family participations. Our proposed research meets public health needs by providing unique insights into the neural bases of vocal sensorimotor deficits that underlie impaired communication in aphasia. This knowledge will inform targeted treatment of sensorimotor mechanisms to help enhance communication ability and improve the quality of life in affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses several issues of central importance to the understanding of congenital and acquired arrhythmias, significant causes of morbidity and mortality. This proposal tests the hypothesis that Wnt signaling transcriptionally regulates the expression of ion channel subunits that regulate cardiac conduction. The results and broad conclusions will be directly relevant to understanding the genetic basis of cardiac arrhythmias, and will aid in designing more effective diagnostic and therapeutic options for ventricular tachycardia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune responses in children are known to be distinct, setting the stage for a lifetime of health or disease. This proposal is designed to explore the hypothesis that pediatric T cell responses are shaped by factors inherent to the cell, its tissue environment, and the individual's infection history. The knowledge gained by this study will provide novel insights into early life immune development which will improve our ability to prevent and treat childhood and lifelong diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ventricular arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death is a consequence of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) especially in young adults. Although SCD can be effectively managed by implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD), these devices cause lifestyle and occupational restrictions and negatively affect quality of life. Since the risk of SCD is variable and poorly understood, there is a critical need to understand the underlying mechanisms. A mechanistic understanding will aid in developing tools to predict SCD risk so that only those patients in need receive ICDs and to develop therapeutics that might be more effective than current options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project is relevant to public health because defects in astrocyte development, especially those affecting astrocyte numbers or patterning, have been linked to disorders of retinal vascular development such as reti- nopathy of prematurity. Further, death by phagocyte may mediate neuron loss in certain neurodegenerative disorders. Therefore, by pinpointing the mechanisms underlying death by phagocyte, the proposed research is expected to reveal mechanisms that one day may be manipulated for therapeutic benefit – to promote normal retinal angiogenesis or to inhibit neuron loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a complex, multifactorial condition that involves multiple aspects of the intestinal mucosa, microbiome, and immune system. We propose novel experimental and mechanistic studies to determine the role of heterogeneous chemosensory tuft cells in suppressing ileal inflammatory disease. These studies may provide a greater understanding of microbiome-host crosstalk in the intestine while also broadening the small pool of therapeutic targets in IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative In recent decades, the prevalence of cannabis use has significantly increased among older adults (≥65 years), a population that is particularly vulnerable to cognitive impairment associated with cannabis use. This proposed project leverages existing nationally representative data and digital epidemiology tools to identify detailed patterns of cannabis use and the associations between those patterns and residual cognitive impairment, across several domains, in older US adults. Findings from this project will inform clinicians, researchers, and policymakers about the risks of cognitive impairment in older adults with different patterns of cannabis use, and subsequently, about the development of harm reduction strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is known for causing progressive muscle wasting and death. It is less well known that DMD patients also have intellectual disorders that arise from problems in brain development. My aims are designed to determine the role of the DMD gene in brain development to assist in discovering therapeutics that address the causes of the abnormalities and improve outcomes for individuals with DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human babesiosis caused by the hemoparasite Babesia microti is an emerging infectious disease in the United States. Current prophylactic measures aim at reducing exposure to the Ixodes scapularis tick, the vector that maintains Babesia microti in its enzootic cycle and incidentally feeds on humans. Using mouse strains that model severe Babesia microti infection caused by old age or severe immune suppression, the proposed research will seek to identify tafenoquine regimens that confer post-exposure prophylaxis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Asthma is a major health care burden to patients, families, and societies. The management of asthma is far less than ideal, in part due to our incomplete understanding of cellular and molecular processes of asthmatic inflammation. This proposal seeks to determine the novel mechanism of the resolution of allergic inflammation, specifically focusing on a specialized cell type that is responsible for clearing inflammatory cells and their debris to facilitate the resolution of inflammation. The proposed study would lead to a better understanding of pathogenesis of asthma, eventually improving the management of asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is to establish a Boston University Kidney and Medical Engineering Program (BU-KIDMEP). Our program's focus is on providing undergraduate and graduate students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics the opportunity to engage in kidney technology development research. Our ultimate goal is to inspire talented young scholars to improve the lives of individuals with kidney disease through innovative technology solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will utilize the ongoing people with people who inject drug (PWID) cohort in Puerto Rico and the information being collected on inflammation, microbial dysbiosis and HIV disease progression to determine the prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in the cohort and its effects on HIV disease progression. The PWID is a high-risk group for infectious disease, but the effects of SAES-CoV-2 infection on HIV in this group has not been investigated, in either Puerto Rico or anywhere else. The results generated by our study can be translatable to the PWID in other parts of the U.S and may lead to the development of strategies to prevent HIV and COVID-19 disease progression in HIV+ PWID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative RELEVANCE: Benign epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS) is the most common childhood epilepsy syndrome, and recent findings indicate that BECTS is a disorder with a wider range of severity than previously appreciated. In addition to seizures, children have cognitive deficits that range from mild to profound, overlapping clinically, electrophysiologically, and genetically with severe epileptic encephalopathies. This project will determine whether abnormal thalamocortical circuitry mediates the cognitive symptoms in BECTS, thereby increasing our fundamental knowledge of the cause and treatment for this common developmental disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of individuals suffer from skeletal muscle atrophy and contractile dysfunction (i.e. muscle weakness), a hallmark of several physiological and pathological conditions, including sarcopenia and cancer cachexia. Despite the significance of myopathy on quality of life and healthspan, no pharmacological therapies are currently available to mitigate the loss of muscle mass and function. The experiments in this proposal will test the impact of unacylated ghrelin on skeletal muscle weakness in aging and cancer cachexia with a high chance of translation based on its excellent safety profiles in humans and no effects on cancer cell growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will explore the specificity and function of the VNAR nanobody repertoire elicited by sarbecovirus and merbecovirus spike ferritin nanoparticle immunogens in nurse sharks. Combining binding studies, competition mapping assays, viral neutralization, and in vivo protection studies with high-resolution structural biology, we will utilize these shark nanobodies to provide extensive and detailed information on highly conserved, neutralizing viral epitopes. Such information is key for the design of new immunogens that will elicit pan-sarbecovirus and pan-merbecovirus protective immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will allow us to test neurobehavioral mechanisms of a mindfulness-based intervention to target mood lability in early adolescents at high risk for developing mood disorders. Mood lability is an important transdiagnostic problem that is associated with poor psychosocial function and suicidal thoughts, and is a predictor of mood disorder onset, especially in youth at familial risk. Through this randomized controlled trial, we will better understand how and for whom mindfulness interventions work, which will lead to more targeted interventions to improve emotion regulation during this key developmental period.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: The Partnership for Research in Implementation Science- Mozambique (PRISM), a collaboration between the Faculty of Medicine at University Eduardo Mondale (UEM) in Maputo, Mozambique and the Vanderbilt Institute for Global Health (VIGH) at Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC), will build upon successes of its first five-year period to continue developing HIV implementation science research capacity at UEM. The present proposal has been developed jointly with the leadership of UEM to respond to their current desire to evolve the institution's pool of Master´s level researchers to the doctoral level, as well as continue further development of the newly created Implementation Science Unit formed to create new opportunities for the conduct of meaningful and high-quality HIV implementation science research at UEM at beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative High-risk alcohol use is one of the most common risk factors for surgical complications among elective surgical patients. There is a pressing need to identify scalable intervention strategies that promote short- and longer- term alcohol use reductions in surgical settings. This sequential, multiple assignment, randomized trial will address this need by identifying the most efficacious adaptive intervention approaches to reduce alcohol use before and after surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is associated with a progressive accrual of body fat and loss of skeletal muscle mass that causes a vicious cycle of increasing metabolic disease risk and loss of functional capacity. Intentional weight loss improves metabolic health but loss of skeletal muscle during weight loss may cause the development of sarcopenia. The proposed K01 research will use an pilot Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial to begin investigating the separate and combined effects of a higher protein diet and resistance training on the retention of fat free mass during weight loss in adults ≥50 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A stem-mesenchymal phenotype of the tumor epithelium, and its associated immunosuppressive and desmoplastic stroma, are fundamental characteristics of the most aggressive and poor survival type of colorectal cancer. Here we will test the hypothesis that the PKC/ deficiency in the intestinal epithelium underlies the upregulation of epithelial CD44 whose activation by its stromal ligands contributes to the development of this type of CRC. The successful completion of this proposal will have a high impact because a better comprehension of the signaling mechanisms that govern the mesenchymal characteristics of intestinal cancer cells is critical for the design of new and more selective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neurodevelopmental disorder Dup15q syndrome is caused by duplication of a chromosomal region containing the UBE3A gene, whose overexpression in the brain appears to be a major driver of disease pathology. Accordingly, reversing the overexpression of UBE3A represents a rational therapeutic strategy to treat Dup15q syndrome. We will optimize an approach to reduce brain UBE3A levels dose-dependently as a potential treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Generalized seizures are brain-wide events and occur in several types of epilepsy. Asking a patient to hyperventilate is a reliable strategy to diagnose generalized absence seizures – rapid breathing triggers a seizure in nearly 100% of patients. Identifying the biological processes that intimately link respiration and generalized seizures will lead to a better understanding of how the brain triggers seizures and will pave the way forward in developing better treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE While inadequate systemic exposure to oral 6-mercaptopruine (6MP) during maintenance therapy (~2y) for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is associated with an increased risk of relapse, the underlying determinants of systemic exposure to 6MP in adolescents and young adults (AYA) have not been examined. Within a 14-site national consortium focused on AYA ALL, this proposal will examine factors which may influence systemic exposure to 6MP in AYA ALL, including those related to both the AYA patient (6MP adherence) and healthcare, as well as the barriers and facilitators within these domains. By identifying actionable targets in both domains, this proposal sets the stage to develop meaningful interventions which can mitigate outcome disparities in AYA ALL, where outcomes have lagged behind those in children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement/Project Narrative tRNAs are the link required to translate genomic information from RNA copies of the genome into the amino acid sequences that make up proteins. Interestingly, tRNAs are among the most heavily-modified RNAs in the cell, and tRNA-modifying enzymes have been linked to an ever-increasing range of disease processes. In addition, tRNAs often cleaved in response to changes in environmental conditions, and the resulting fragments are increasingly understood to play underappreciated roles in the cell. In this proposal we will systematically investigate the biology of tRNA modification in control of tRNA cleavage and control of protein translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to understand the long-term aging process of the growing population of older cancer survivors. The goal of this proposal is to identify long-term memory trajectories of older cancer survivors in the US and England, evaluate socioeconomic disparities in this relationship, and identify modifiable Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) risk factors. This study’s findings will enhance our understanding of the long-term aging process of older cancer survivors and identify potential intervention targets to promote healthy aging in this growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal describes an innovative, collaborative, inter-institutional mentoring program between Case Western Reserve University and Hampton University to support underrepresented minority (URM) students in communication sciences and disorders (CSD). The purpose of this program is to enhance the diversity of the CSD workforce to better serve all people with communication disorders by successfully transitioning URM students to CSD graduate programs and by developing strong networks of mentors to foster long-term success. Over the course of the annual programming, students will advance their professional development skills, build a diverse professional network, increase their sense of belonging in the field, particularly research, increase their knowledge of CSD professions, and enhance their self-efficacy, resulting in increased URM student achievement and retention in CSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to unify and improve simultaneous diffusion-based magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spinal cord in order to study the complete motor pathways in vivo and to study their involvement in patients with multiple sclerosis. Previously, the brain and spinal cord have been studied in isolation due to challenges associated with long image acquisitions, different demands on resolution and acquisition paradigms, tissue modeling, and connectivity analysis. The proposed studies will provide a basis for understanding the role of the motor pathways in normal and damaged white matter microstructure in multiple sclerosis, and provide a foundation for further applications in diseases that involve both brain and spinal cord tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Higher levels of serum urate are associated with slower disease progression and improved survival in several neurodegenerative movement disorders, suggesting that urate levels may have prognostic utility in Parkinson’s Disease or Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. Despite this, urate elevation therapy does not slow clinical disease progression. In this proposal we suggest an alternative fate of urate that may better explain why urate levels are low early in the disease diagnosis, and we propose to develop tools to better characterize this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer patients remain at elevated risk for relapse following conventional treatment and recent studies of lung cancer biology provide compelling evidence that lung cancer is initiated by a small population of malignant cells called cancer-initiating cells (CICs); currently available cancer treatments may be ineffective against lung CICs. Our preliminary work using a vaccine consisting of exosomes derived from mouse embryonic stem cells (ES-exo vaccine) has provided validation that immunization with ES-exo vaccine prevents lung cancers in mice and our goal in this proposal is to investigate whether our novel cell-free ES-exo vaccine is effective in depleting lung CICs and preventing lung cancer onset and recurrence. Such a cancer vaccine will reduce health care costs and loss of life from a disease that is now a major health problem worldwide.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The UC Davis T35 Students Training in Advanced Research (STAR) program is a primary means of providing DVM students a balanced experience to hands-on hypothesis driven research that builds broadly applicable skills in critical thinking and problem-solving. The proposed training program is consistent with recommendations to give federal agencies more control over the number of trainees, the quality of their training, and the appropriateness of training to meet pressing societal needs. Funds are requested to provide 10-week stipend support for each of 15 DVM trainees annually who will receive a combination of didactic and experiential training to promote understanding of how students progressing through their professional clinical curriculum can incorporate rigorous research training into their career goals, and the benefits of doing so.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine is the second highest abused drug in the United States, resulting in users responding with less immunological severity to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-1 then non-users. Long-term cocaine exposure, especially in comorbidity with HIV-1, promotes neuroinflammation-associated toxicities as a result of unmanageable inflammatory responses and decreased antiviral immunity. This project addresses the pathogenic chronic inflammatory states, initiated by cocaine's impact and activation of MAVS and AIM2 inflammasome signaling in HIV—1; that ultimately results in decreased antiviral immunity and heightened inflammation, thereby fueling disease progression and tissue injury in HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defining early ‘triggers’ that exist within the mammary tissue of non-tumor bearing individuals and establishing how these triggers enhance long-term risk for metastatic hormone receptor positive breast cancer would have a substantial impact on reducing the mortality associated with this disease. We have identified that gut commensal dysbiosis is an early trigger that induces specific immune changes in the normal mammary tissue that lead to enhanced long-term risk for metastatic breast cancer. This project will establish how the gut microbiome distally regulates normal mammary tissues to enhance early tumor dissemination, the impact of which could lead to therapies that modify the gut microbiome, host metabolism, or tissue microenvironment for the long-term prevention of metastatic breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The success of hematopoietic cell transplantation to treat hematologic cancer is significantly limited in those with poor exercise tolerance, but current methods to measure exercise capacity in these patients do not identify the reasons for their exercise intolerance. To better understand and ultimately address the causes of exercise intolerance, we will directly assess the relationship between heart function (using noninvasive cardiac magnetic resonance imaging during exercise) and its contribution on exercise capacity in hematopoietic cell transplant patients before and after transplant. This K23 project will allow training of an early-stage investigator to become an independent clinical researcher in cardio-oncology and develop expertise in exercise magnetic resonance imaging to understand the reasons for exercise intolerance—ultimately leading to future study of targeted treatments to improve outcomes among those receiving hematopoietic cell transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) is one of the most common genetic disorders in the world. It is characterized by many acute manifestations most notably the acute chest syndrome (ACS), a severe lung complication that causes premature death in SCD. Currently, there is no specific treatment for ACS, and so it continues to be a major clinical problem globally. We have identified a potential reason that might explain why children survive ACS 10-times better than adults. This project will help us understand the protection in children, and to see if we can exploit it to develop a new and specific treatment for ACS for all patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent work from our group has demonstrated that PRDM15, a member of the PRDM family of transcription regulators, is essential in early embryogenesis leading to defects in growth, Anterior/Posterior patterning and Forebrain development. Here we propose to further investigate the function, at the mechanistic level, of PRDM15 at different stages of development and to identify its relevant downstream targets. Our work will not only expand our knowledge on basic developmental processes, but given mutations of the PRDM15 gene and of PRDM15-transcriptional targets in the NOTCH and WNT/PCP patways, detected in patients with Holoprosencephaly (HPE) and microcephaly, will also have a potential diagnostic and therapeutic impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Data suggest that a person’s genetic background influences his individual risk of developing diverticulitis. The proposed work will: 1) Determine if the genetic background can predict whether a patient will have a mild or severe course of diverticulitis; 2) Investigate whether abdominal obesity might change the impact of genetic background; and 3) Research a potential shared genetic causality between diverticulitis and other clinically related diseases. Knowledge gained from these studies could translate into meaningful advances for patients with diverticular disease.

PHR: The proposed research serves public health through the development of therapeutics that could improve treatment and reduce disability for certain patients with neurodevelopmental disability resulting from pathogenic variants in KCNQ3. With the current standard of care, patients remain substantially impaired, non- verbal, and unable to care for themselves. The project is relevant to the NIH's mission because it is focused on improving the care of patients for whom no dedicated treatment currently exists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Narrative Enteric diseases are among the most common human ailments. Conventional biologics are not suited for enteric applications due to their susceptibility to degradation in the protease-rich environment of the GI tract. This project will develop both a protease-stable scaffold that can be templated for engineering biologics for diverse enteric diseases and a probiotic yeast-based platform for in situ delivery of biologics to the GI lumen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: We know that metabolically active brown adipose tissue (BAT) is present in adult humans and burns energy for thermogenesis. The study is designed to evaluate the complex relationship between the intra-cellular and circulating thyroid hormone (TH) levels and BAT activity, transcriptome, and cellular composition to better understand the interaction between the thyroid axis and BAT in the process of thermogenesis in humans. Finding ways to stimulate BAT can lead to the development of new therapies for obesity and diabetes, which are major public health concerns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project will develop “wearable” magnetoencephalography with synchronized movement video tracking for use in freely-moving children that will be used to elucidate the brain circuit activity which promotes intellectual development. The participants will be school-age children with typical development and with varying degrees of intellectual disability related to autism spectrum disorder. By defining the frequency bandwidths and brain locations of electrical activity coherence that promote intellectual development, the project will lay the essential groundwork for future therapies that will remediate intellectual disability in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: The “"Meals that Heal" project will develop, disseminate, and evaluate a useful and usable interactive health information resource for low-income African American women and other economically-disadvantaged African Americans. The tool and the toolkit will strengthen cancer outreach efforts, programs, and policies by providing critical insights into unmet needs and inequities among low-income and underserved populations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To effectively integrate diet into cancer treatment, there is a critical need to define the molecular mechanisms that control the effects of diet on cancer progression and therapeutic efficacy. Changing the types of lipids that are available in the tumor microenvironment directly impacts cancer cell lipid metabolism, which becomes a major driver of dietary effects on tumor biology. To demonstrate the critical role of lipid metabolism in linking diet to cancer, the proposed research will examine how different dietary interventions impact cancer progression and therapy by altering the balance between saturated versus unsaturated fatty acids within tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse conditions such as economic deprivation, complex trauma, and chronic parental stress increase the risk that children may be mistreated and may severely undermine their mental health functioning. Many post-Soviet countries struggle with a legacy of a medicalized approach to mental health care that does not address the social and structural factors that contribute to poor mental health. Advancing the mental health of children in post-Soviet Eurasia requires research and capacity building activities that will strengthen collaborative international and regional community–academic partnerships and build expertise to adapt, integrate, and compare multi-level psychosocial interventions that address the underlying family-level and structural risks and protective factors related to child mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Title: Heterogeneous genetic architecture in lung cancer risk Project Narrative Large-scale genetic analyses of lung cancer have identified numerous genetic variants influencing both the risk of lung cancer and nicotine dependence, the major risk factor for lung cancer. The proposed research capitalizes on existing well-curated phenotype and genotyped repositories of lung cancer with both sporadic and familial cases in Europeans and African Americans and aims to characterize shared and distinct genetic profiles in lung cancer risk in the different subgroups defined according to family history status of lung cancer using machine- learning. The findings could unravel complex genetic structures of lung cancer etiology, with potential implications for improved prevention, screening, and management of lung cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative There is an unmet need for a low-cost system that can access tissue perfusion during chronic wound care during telehealth consultations. PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed studies are of an important area of Lyme disease research that has applicability to understanding infectivity and pathogenesis by Borrelia burgdorferi. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work described in this proposal will facilitate the development of bioinspired tandem g-C3N4/peroxidase systems for antibacterial, anti-biofilm and anti-quorum sensing applications. Complementary cell toxicity experiments will further establish the utility of these systems as novel microbiocidal agents. Moreover, the interdisciplinary nature of the described project will allow it to serve as a unique, integrated, high impact educational experience in which undergraduate students from the College of Idaho and Boise State University explore the design, fabrication and validation of functional materials for biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative Cash transfer programs to alleviate poverty have been shown to reduce depression in adults, however, information on how these programs may impact depression in adolescents may vary based on factors such as household poverty or exposure to violence. In this study we will examine these questions using an existing database of a large, cohort of over 2,000 adolescent girls in rural South Africa followed for over 8 years during a critical time in development from early adolescence into early adulthood to determine the impact of two different cash transfer programs and how such program effect the relationship between childhood exposure to adversity and its relationship to depression. Given that millions of households in the African region receive cash transfers as part of government social protection programs, this study informs important gaps in our understanding of how CTs may be leveraged to buffer childhood adversities and improve child and adolescent mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to unlock the potential of combining wearable mobile recording devices, such as smartphones with continuous audio-visual, accelerometry, GPS, subjective report, autonomic physiology, and wearable eye tracking recordings, with precisely synchronized intracranial neural recordings during real-world behaviors. Autobiographical memory (AM) formation is a critical human behavior that has been difficult to study with traditional neuroimaging methods. Thus the proposed project aims to develop a smartphone-based recording application (CAPTURE app; R61 phase) synchronized with wearables and invasive neural recordings during real-world behaviors like autobiographical memory encoding (R33 phase).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to identify mechanisms for maternal lipid regulation of offspring development of allergic responses. As a step towards our long-term goal, our central hypothesis is that increases in DHET levels in allergic mothers regulate the development of offspring numbers of CD11b+CD11c+ DCs, lung microbiome dysbiosis, and responses to allergen early in life. Successful completion of these studies will have a significant impact on our understanding of mechanisms of maternal lipid regulation of offspring DCs during development of allergies and the design of future clinical studies that may lead to novel interventions to significantly impact risk for allergic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic neuropathic pain impacts up to 69% of adults with spinal cord injury (SCI) and treatment options are limited, primarily focused on pain medications with insufficient benefits and significant risks for addiction and adverse effects. Of the available mind and body approaches, Qigong is the most accessible for adults with SCI with evidence for effectiveness in reducing pain, but there is not enough evidence to make recommendations for adults with SCI, especially from diverse backgrounds, prompting our proposal to investigate the feasibility of remotely delivered Qigong vs managing pain with a ‘Manage My Pain Pro app for neuropathic pain relief in diverse populations with SCI. The outcomes of this study will facilitate a rigorous structure to design larger effectiveness studies and facilitate a clear pathway for researchers to investigate Qigong vs active comparison groups and other mind-body approaches for whole-person health in diverse groups of adults with chronic diseases and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Existing studies of human behavior and cognition typically must choose between being ecologically valid or data-rich given that current and most often-used neuroimaging methods do not allow for simultaneous neuronal and peripheral biomarker recordings during free movement. The proposed project will develop a first- of-its-kind research platform for recording brain, biochemical, and biophysical activity via advanced wearables to enable the investigation of naturalistic human behavior. The technologies developed will be useful for numerous future studies, and potentially will open an entirely new area of research within the fields of basic, cognitive, and clinical neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with a genetic disorder of high cholesterol called familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) can significantly reduce their high risk of premature atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) if they are identified early in life and provided treatment to lower their cholesterol. Few individuals with FH are being identified and treated because we do not understand how best to implement screening programs and measure their cost. This study will answer important questions about generalizability, cost, and sustainability of implementation strategies to improve FH screening and identification through targeted strategies and lowering risk for ASCVD in those affected.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Endometriosis is an understudied and underfunded complex disease that significantly contributes to infertility and pelvic pain in women. Available treatments are limited because the molecular mechanisms of endometriosis are not well understood. Using clinically relevant human samples, and cellular and mouse models, we propose to study the roles of GATA transcription factors in endometriosis that will lead to better understanding of the disease and future development of novel therapeutics for endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There exist vast gaps of knowledge in the molecular basis that drives age-unrelated intestinal senescence and its pathological consequences. In this project, we will investigate the interplays between gut epithelial cells and microbiota in the regulation of colonic senescence. Specifically, we will prove the concept that decline of key host enzymes and gut bacterial dysbiosis together induce epithelial acetyl-CoA deficiency that triggers rapid colonic ageing, demonstrate the connection between colonic senescence and colitis, and explore colonic senescence as a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurochemicals represent the fundamental signal carriers within the brain, whether it be through the rapid movement of ions across cell membranes when neurons spike, or through the cellular exchange of neurotransmitters, monitoring brain neurochemistry continues to lead us toward better understanding of how neural circuits function, and towards pharmaceuticals and treatments that improve the quality of people's lives. Electrochemical sensors are the most popular devices to measure brain neurochemistry, however they are generally lacking the capability for long-term studies for chronic implant applications, are not very selective, and are subject to fouling and drift. Adoption of hydrodynamic electrochemical sensors by leveraging silicon microfabrication technology to integrate sophisticated microfluidics allow for sensors that are capable of calibration and regeneration in-situ and introduce novel modes of measurement to study the brain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Motor development plays a crucial role in the acquisition of social communication skills, cognition, and language, and motor impairments detrimentally affect downstream development. Many neurodevelopmental disorders describe motor impairments as an early comorbid symptom; however, current standardized assessments of motor function fail to clearly characteize these early motor impairments. This longitudinal study will utilize quantitative measures to objectively characterize the earliest manifestation of motor impairments in infants at high risk for autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders and elucidate the mechanistic relationship of these impairments to symptoms of autism and other adverse developmental outcomes with the goal to improve early identification and inform targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a devastating disease of relentless scarring in the lungs, which leads to severe debilitation and eventually respiratory failure and death. The cause of IPF is not known, and there are few treatments available. This project explores one of the underlying mechanisms of IPF, and how manipulating a cellular stress response pathway might enable progenitor cells to repair the lung, rather than promote scar tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Cellular Plasticity in Salivary Gland Regeneration Although radiation damage is often considered irreversible, we have found that irradiated salivary glands have regenerative potential. Furthermore, we demonstrated that under severe conditions, salivary gland cells undergo lineage conversion to replace lost cells. To explore whether this process can be harnessed as a therapeutic modality for treating patients living with permanent xerostomia, we will focus on characterizing the mechanism and regulation of cellular plasticity in salivary gland cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life adversity (ELA) is of critical concern for early prevention and intervention efforts, as it predicts risk for mental and physical health concerns that cause significant economic burden, and risk for higher acuity and chronicity with respect to disease course. The current proposal seeks to apply advanced, innovative analyses of electroencephalogram (EEG) reward and threat processing risk markers in an early childhood sample to identify the proximal impact of early life adversity. By probing the impact of ELA on electrocortical risk markers for later psychopathology, mechanisms through which ELA may increase risk for adverse psychiatric outcomes may be further identified in future studies, which has implications for prevention and intervention efforts for ELA-exposed youth.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE Emotion dysregulation is common across populations, may be particularly elevated in those with autism spectrum disorder, and has a significant negative impact on daily life across the lifespan. Building on the prior successful development of the Emotion Dysregulation Inventory (EDI), this study will refine and validate new early childhood and self-report versions of the EDI, and ensure their utility across populations through evaluation of their psychometrics in autism, other intellectual and developmental disorders, and general samples. Finally, the EDI will be linked to specific neural features underlying emotion dysregulation in order to support experimental therapeutics approaches to clinical trials and to enhance the translational value of this research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The regulation of the 1st wave of ovarian folliculogenesis, a highly organized process that is essential to produce mature and competent oocytes, remains largely unknown. As evidence indicates that sympathetic innervation may be involved in 1st wave follicle maturation, the goal of this proposal is to understand the interplay between ovarian sympathetic nerves and follicles to orchestrate the establishment of neuronal networks and how these networks contribute to folliculogenesis. This novel work is a significant step toward developing control points required for understanding ovarian development and nerve-associated disease etiology, such as polycystic ovarian syndrome.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental and childhood disorders often arise due to abnormal neural development impacting function. The proposed research is relevant to public health because defining the developmental processes driving and constraining behavior will serve to increase our understanding of human health and treatment of developmental disorders. Therefore, this proposal is central to the NIH’s mission to increase fundamental knowledge of the mechanisms of disease, disorders, and dysfunction that impair health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Fatty acids act as powerful repellants at high concentrations while lower concentrations of fatty acids may act as attractive host cues for mosquito disease vectors like Aedes aegypti, yet the receptor mechanisms for fatty acid taste remain unclear in invertebrates. Our recent evidence in the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, supports requirements for an opsin and a TRP channel in bimodal fatty acid taste in Aedes. We propose to leverage these results to reveal how the Aedes taste system mediates robust deterrence and attraction towards fatty acids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE –  The goal of this submission is improve the treatment of bone metastatic cancer patients with Radium-223, the first approved alpha particle emitting drug, by understanding how it can be better used in combination with other therapies. Using information from extensive pilot data in the laboratory and clinical settings we evaluate synergistic Radium-223 combinations, characterize the potential for negative outcomes, and help explain findings emerging from clinical work. Our work will assist in the rational design of effective and safe combinations for alpha particle therapy to improve outcomes for late stage metastatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative—Overall The Caenorhabditis Genetics Center (CGC) is the sole general international repository and distribution center for the nematode C. elegans. Researchers throughout the world make important discoveries in diverse areas of biology, many with relevance to human health, aging and disease, using this premier model organism and strains provided by the CGC. A small research component will quantitatively compare in vivo parameters of a new set of fluorescent proteins in the nematode, enabling scientists to choose the optimal proteins for use in their work.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Data science methods provide an exciting opportunity to significantly improve the rigor of rehabilitation research by increasing the reproducibility and replicability of research. Data science methods, which rely on computer programming skills for data intake, management, storage, and analysis, can increase reproducibility, but clinical and basic rehabilitation researchers may have challenges adopting these practices due to a lack fundamental training in computer programming. The proposed Reproducible Rehabilitation (ReproRehab) research education program will build a sustainable national workforce of rehabilitation researchers equipped with basic data science skills by: (1) implementing an innovative, hands-on bootcamp for rehabilitation researchers to learn beginning data science skills and integrate them into their own research, (2) employing a train-the-trainer model to rapidly increase capacity for data science and training of data science in the rehabilitation research community, and (3) broadly disseminating data science resources curated specifically for rehabilitation researchers through a publicly accessible web portal.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes to develop and validate the Adult Functioning Scale, a self- and caregiver-report assessment of social, employment, and independent living domains suitable for use in treatment trials for adults with developmental disabilities. The results from this project are of considerable public health significance in that they will establish a measure of functional outcome for adults with developmental disabilities that is broadly applicable across different conditions and severity spectra, and that can be used to monitor treatment changes in clinical trials seeking to improve functioning in adults with autism spectrum disorder and other developmental disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we expect to gain substantial insight into how stem cells and their niches can be newly generated through developmental plasticity of differentiated cells during craniofacial skeletal development, and how cells in postnatal stages retain such potential for plasticity. This study will thus guide our future efforts to capitalize on lineage plasticity to achieve autotherapies for the postnatal craniofacial skeletal defects, by aiding to develop innovative approaches to recover inherent stem cells and their niches that support proper growth and regeneration of multiple functional units of the craniofacial skeletal tissues.
