IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Implementation science is the field that studies how to move evidence-based treatments, therapies, and techniques into clinics and hospitals quickly so that patients can benefit from them. Currently, there are not enough scientists in the field and it takes approximately 17 years for new treatments to be adopted by the medical community. This program will train new scientists in implementation science so we can take better care of people with heart, lung, blood, or sleep disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the ability to discern the location of a sound source is an important brain function in humans; errors in these computations are known to be associated with deficits in hearing and communication. The goal of this research plan is to determine how auditory information is processed in the superior colliculus, the only area in the brain known to contain a topographic map of auditory space. Findings from this research will provide fundamental knowledge that will enable additional research to better understand and treat disorders that involve auditory processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Despite its importance to normal brain function, neural decoding is much more poorly understood than the process of neural encoding. This proposal applies innovative methods to develop fundamental new knowledge about the circuit, cellular, and synaptic mechanisms of neural decoding. An improved understanding of how the brain processes its own sensory code could help guide the development of improved therapies for rehabilitation after brain injury.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to restore ovarian endocrine function in young women with premature ovarian insufficiency by utilizing human xenogeneic implantation of ovarian tissue in immuno-isolating hydrogel-based capsule. We will engineer a synthetic hydrogel based capsule with spatially controlled degradation that maximizes the survival and function of ovarian xenograft in vivo. The primary innovation of this proposal stems from the design of immuno-isolating capsule that considers the uniqueness of the physiology of human ovarian tissue, while using well-characterized biomaterials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While current understanding of hearing mechanics in the human cochlea has largely been inferred from animal experiments, our recent findings have revealed that there are substantial differences between the cochlear partition motions in humans and laboratory animals that would influence the mechanical input to the transduction mechanism. To determine how auditory mechanics work in humans, we will measure the cochlear partition motion of very fresh human cadaveric ears, investigate relevant cochlear anatomical properties, and incorporate the resulting motion and anatomical information into computational models that will allow us to further investigate and explain human cochlear behavior. Our proposed research will advance our understanding of human hearing mechanics to elucidate how the cochlea functions (e.g., to achieve sensitive hearing and fine frequency discrimination), enable us to better understand the applicability and limitations of animal experiments for human hearing, and result in computational models that are valuable for both scientific investigation and for improving the diagnosis and treatment of hearing disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative To study and design treatments for human diseases requires appropriate animal models. Despite the availability of many rodent models, findings in rodents do not readily translate to human patients but large animal models, such as pigs and non-human primates, closely resemble human physiology and size. This project will provide a novel strategy for precise genetic modification in testis stem cells to generate large animal models of human diseases and for regenerative medicine, and will establish accessible systems to study germline stem cell biology in non-rodent animals.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women affected by genital fistula experience significant physical and psychosocial morbidity associated with the condition, and nascent evidence suggests subsequent adverse outcomes occur after surgical repair (i.e., fistula repair breakdown or recurrence and incontinence). To identify salient targets for clinical and counselling interventions to improve women’s health and quality of life following fistula repair, we seek to understand the contribution of individual, fistula-related, and post-repair behaviors and exposures to these adverse outcomes. Subsequent and iterative work with key stakeholders will help us develop a road map of intervention strategies likely to be feasible and acceptable within the study population and setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Sjӧgren’s syndrome-associated xerostomia greatly compromises the oral health and the quality of life of 2-4 million Americans because of devastating loss of saliva and severe dry mouth. SS is an autoimmune disease and destruction of the salivary glands, and failure of therapies to restore their function, is the result of our inability to control autoimmune inflammation. Completion of this proposed project will contribute to the development of effective and targeted therapeutic strategies to fundamentally restore salivary gland integrity and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Neural prostheses are able to deliver reliable and efficient functional excitation of the nervous system to enable technology such as cochlear implants, retinal implants, pacemakers, spinal cord stimulators, and deep brain stimulators. Conversely, suppression of the nervous system is not easily achieved. The central goal of this project is to advance the technology toward achieving efficient suppression of the nervous system and to improve the application of neural prostheses for the treatment of vestibular balance disorders.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This renewal of our Cooperative Agreement (U42OD013117) requests four years of funding to continue support for a Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) colony of healthy, behaviorally normal, major histocompatibility complex (MHC) profiled pig-tailed macaques (Macaca nemestrina) at the Johns Hopkins University. Since 2016, our colony has produced an average of 51 offspring each year and we have sold an average of 32. At least 50% of colony-produced juvenile males, and increasing numbers of juvenile females, are sold to NIH- funded investigators outside of Johns Hopkins for HIV/AIDS related research, demonstrating the colony's status as a national resource.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative The spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs) are a large group of rare neurological disorders characterized by lack of balance and coordination that causes clumsy voluntary movements. Our preliminary data and lessons learned from other repeat expansion disease suggest disruptions to the transcriptome, including to alternative splicing, may be a novel hallmark of SCAs, which would have important implications for tracking disease and developing therapies. Here we will test if targeting the repeat expansion mutation that underlies many of these SCAs will provide therapeutic potential across multiple diseases and whether cross-disease therapeutic efficacy can be quantified by measuring changes in alternative splicing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Robert A. Saxton | K22 (PAR-18-467) | Project Narrative  IL-20 family cytokines are pleiotropic immune cell-derived factors that are upregulated in inflammation and have been implicated in the occurrence of inflammation associated tumorigenesis. The proposed research aims to interrogate the diverse functions of these cytokines by engineering IL-20 receptor agonists with altered receptor specificity and signaling profiles, enabling us to deconvolute their functional effects in a mouse model of colitis-associated cancer. These studies will provide insights into the therapeutic potential of these engineered cytokines in the treatment and prevention of inflammation-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: When caring for neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), neonatologists lack sufficient tools to assess severity of brain damage or monitor response to therapy. This proposal seeks to analytically validate a highly sensitive and specific research-use only blood immunoassay for objectively measuring the extent of brain injury caused by HIE. All critical components for the assay will be carefully characterized, three kit lots will be manufactured, and the immunoassay will be evaluated at three different sites. Long-term, the assay will help to stratify neonates with HIE for clinical trials of investigational adjuvants to therapeutic hypothermia and enable personalized treatments tailored to the severity of injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 2 diabetes (T2D) and non alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are emerging as two of the most critical global health challenges of the 21st century and there is a great unmet need for new therapies. This grant will provide essential safety and efficacy data for a novel class of drugs for NAFLD and T2D in non human primates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary liver cancer, and a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms driving HCC will improve therapeutic developments. My proposal investigates an understudied mechanism in HCC I recently discovered where IQGAP1, a scaffold protein, promotes oncogenic YAP1 signaling. Additionally, I propose the engineering of a humanized HCC model; which can be applied to study various oncogenes, and used as a tool to validate and test precision based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal seeks to build a comprehensive user support and dissemination platform for our recently developed powerful software tools that facilitate many aspects of modeling in neuroscience. These tools include the Brain Modeling ToolKit (BMTK) software suite for model building/simulation and the SONATA file format for efficient storage of model and simulation data, both developed at the Allen Institute, as well as the visualization software integrated with SONATA, developed at the University of Illinois. With appropriate user support and dissemination, these tools will facilitate sophisticated modeling work as well as model exchange and reproducibility, contributing to the BRAIN Initiative’s priority areas of Theory and Data Analysis and Integrated Approaches and promoting FAIRness (Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reuse of digital assets) in neuroscience modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States (US), the higher prevalence and mortality of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in rural compared to urban populations represents a major public health problem. The proposed research focuses on the rural Midwest and leverages institutional resources and a multidisciplinary team of mentors and advisors to (1) characterize diabetes epidemiology; (2) evaluate the associations of traditional and novel rural-enriched risk factors with incident T2DM; and (3) develop a rural-specific self-administered T2DM risk score through patient engagement. This study has the potential to support efforts to prevent T2DM, improve T2DM care, and reduce T2DM health disparities for Midwest rural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Central venous catheters are essential healthcare devices used for a range of applications from hemodialysis to critically ill patients. Unfortunately, these catheters have a propensity to become colonized with microorganisms, which can result in a serious and sometimes life-threatening condition called “central line-associated bloodstream infection” or “CLABSI”. We propose to develop an antibiotic-free approach to prevent CLABSI using an innovative electrochemical catheter that generates continuous, low concentrations of the biocide hypochlorous acid in its lumen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Peripheral artery disease (PAD) represent a major cause of cardiac and limb morbidity and all-cause mortality in Western society. Emerging data from our group indicate the importance of platelet activity and platelet's non-hemostatic role in the regulation of PAD, yet this is an understudied area. Our work aims to fill this void by investigating the role of platelets in PAD and other phenotypes of vascular disease, and the molecular mechanisms by which coding and noncoding RNAs regulate platelet activity and influence the pathogenesis of PAD and its consequences, with the ultimate goal of identifying novel prognostic/diagnostic approaches and therapeutic targets for the treatment and prevention of vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-communicable diseases account for 71% of all deaths globally, yet training opportunities for research in global cardiovascular, cardiometabolic, pulmonary, and hematologic diseases are limited. The proposed research training program is designed to fill this gap and provide pathways for post-doctoral clinical fellows to contribute to these critical fields. The program will provide fellows with in-depth research training, professional development, and high-quality mentorship; emphasis will be placed on enhancing diversity in the workforce, as well as achieving equity in global health partnerships

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: We propose the use of a vibroacoustic device to enhance attention and interoception brain networks during breath-focused mindfulness meditation in dissociative traumatized people. Impairments in attention, particularly to body cues, interfere with treatment success in dissociative traumatized people. We will assess how this device, which vibrates in proportion to the breath, can target these networks and address neurobiological barriers to successful treatment engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A total of 18.2 million people in the U.S. currently live with type 2 diabetes and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease which, if not prevented or controlled, can lead to severe complications. Our work integrating etiologic trajectories of cardiometabolic disease into a genetic risk score aligns with the NIDDK's mission to fill gaps in our knowledge of the links between biological and environmental factors affecting health. Our genomics- informed and real-world data driven approach to drug repurposing may lead to the use of existing treatments for NAFLD with shortened drug development times.

PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this research project is to elucidate a recently discovered receptor-mediated pathway, in which the fibrinolysis protease, tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA), blocks the activity of Toll-like Receptors in innate immunity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis is a major cause of neurological disability in young adults in the western world. This project will fundamentally change our understanding of this disease by refocusing attention from the conventional autoimmune view, to one based on toxic protein misfolding promoting degeneration of axons, neurons and myelin. These insights will open completely new directions for therapeutic design that will complement current anti-inflammatory therapies, and more importantly, guide development of drugs for progressive MS where most irreversible disability occurs, and for which we currently have limited therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Arrhythmias increase the risk of heart attack, cardiac arrest and stroke while atrial fibrillation alone is expected to affect 12 million U.S. patients by 2050. The current treatment procedures are lengthy, costly and are plagued by low to moderate success rates. Our objective is to assess the clinical role of our ultrasound-based imaging methodology that can better identify arrhythmic origins and focally inform on the success of subsequent arrhythmia treatment so as to substantially improve the current success rates and abbreviate procedure duration and/or number of procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Systemic amyloidosis is a rare but devastating pathology characterized by the extracellular deposition of protein fibrils in major organs and tissues, notably the heart and kidneys. Despite decades of research into the pathogenesis of these disorders and improvements in patient survival rates, they remain invariably fatal due to the inability to effectively remove tissue amyloid. The goal of this proposal is to develop an amyloid-binding reagent capable of harnessing the cells of the immune system to effect amyloid clearance, and that can also be used to image amyloid deposits, yielding new options for clinical trial design, patient stratification, and improved patient outcomes.

PHR: The proposed scientific training program seeks to address an urgent need: diversifying the biomedical workforce in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Parkinson’s disease (PD) incidence rates predict a worldwide pandemic that will affect over 12 million people and exert an annual economic burden of $14 billion by the year 2040. There is therefore an urgent need to discover neuroprotective drugs that will prevent the progression of PD rather than treating symptoms. We will determine mechanisms by which a nicotinic compound, cytisine and estrogen synergistically exert neuroprotection, which will enable the development of effective and clinically translatable neuroprotective drugs for PD in men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Oxygen therapy (hyperoxia) is the most frequently administered intervention in hospitalized patients. Although often life-saving, hyperoxia can also initiate lung injury in otherwise healthy individuals or further accentuate already ongoing lung injury. Since currently no therapies exist to counteract hyperoxia-induced lung injury, this proposal explores lung epithelial and endothelial TREK-1 potassium channels as a potentially new target to counteract hyperoxia-induced lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metabolic Biomarkers of Response of Mantle Cell Lymphoma to Bruton Tyrosine Kinase Inhibition Project Narrative We are developing a novel method for noninvasive detection of response of human mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) to a new class of drugs, inhibitors of Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase, two of which, ibrutinib (IBR) and acalabrutinib, have recently been approved by the FDA for MCL, chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), marginal zone lymphoma and also evaluated for other types of lymphoma. We are developing magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy (MRI/MRS) methods that detect changes in tumor metabolism resulting from BTK inhibition. Our preclinical studies will pave the way for applying MRI/MRS-based tumor imaging to patients with a broad spectrum of cancers treated with diverse kinase inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARATIVE In every heartbeat, cardiac muscle contracts against a mechanical load to pump blood into circulation to meet the body’s demands. Pathological overload leads to cardiac dysfunction and heart diseases. The proposed research will develop innovative technology to investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying load-induced cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure. The results will provide new therapeutic strategies for treating high blood pressure associated heart diseases such as arrhythmias and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Regulation of residue-specific protein ADP-ribosylations by ADP-ribosyl-acceptor hydrolases (ARHs) is important for cellular responses to DNA damage and the uncontrolled accumulation of ADP-ribosylations causes genomic instability, often leading to diseases. We aim to develop new quantitative tools that selectively monitor the reversal of different residue-specific ADP-ribosylations by ARHs and to elucidate the mechanisms of substrate selectivity and cleavage of ARHs. Our studies will overcome the existing technical hurdles in selective and quantitative measurement of site-specific ADP-ribosylations and will provide in-depth understanding of the roles of each enzymatic activity of ARHs in maintaining genomic integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Over the past decade, mortality from coronary heart disease has increased in rural women, in contrast to other sociodemographic groups for whom the rates have been slowly improving. Because traditional risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia do not explain this growing disparity, this research project examines non-traditional psychosocial, behavioral, immune, endocrine, and physiological mechanisms that were not comprehensively examined before, in a cohort of 4,600 rural Americans in the Appalachia and Mississippi Delta region. This research will be critical in our understanding of heart disease pathogenesis not just in rural women, but all women, as well as men, and will shed light on potential public health and clinical interventions that may improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Endocannabinoids are early signaling molecules which profoundly influence brain development. The innate immune system is also emerging as an important influencer of brain maturation and studies here explore the interaction between the two. The use of cannabis during pregnancy is increasing in response to perceptions of safety following decriminalization, medicalization and legalization yet the impact on the developing fetal brain remains unknown. This research seeks to begin to fill that gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project narrative The junctional epithelium (JE) serves as the first line of defense against periodontal diseases, and its barrier functions are maintained by a stem cell niche. Here, we will identify and characterize the roles of Wnt/β-catenin signaling in maintaining the stem cell pool during JE homeostasis and during injury repair. We also test a biochemical approach for re-establishing JE barrier functions after damage and disease that, if successful, opens up new avenues for periodontal disease treatment and prevention.

PHR: Work proposed here will continue work to elucidate the roles of VWF and oxidative stress in sickle cell disease (SCD) and von Willebrand disease (VWD). In SCD, we will explore the nature of excessive VWF activity in the disease, and investigate the mechanism for why patient blood contains very dense red blood cells. PHR: Public Health relevance/Narrative Decoding the features of signaling unique to the primary cilium in directing downstream cellular pathways is essential for understanding the pathogenesis of diseases caused by ciliary dysfunction. This project addresses key processes in ciliary signaling that include compartmentalization and counterregulatory signaling using mouse models in multiple developmental contexts. Studying ciliary signaling will provide insights into how cellular pathways regulate development and will further our understanding of disease pathologies in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE First uncovered in the context of the fatal transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, prions are infectious, self-propagating protein aggregates that also exist in yeast and other fungi, where they act as heritable, protein-based genetic elements that can enhance survival under specific stressful conditions. The recent discovery of bacterial prions provides the foundation for the proposed studies, which will explore the scope and significance of prion-like phenomena in bacteria. The human health implications of bacterial prions could be far-reaching, from potential roles in antibiotic tolerance and immune evasion in the context of infection to potential effects on the human proteome via cross-Kingdom templating interactions within the human microbiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Exposure to interpersonal trauma is unfortunately common and substantially increases the risk of alcohol use disorder (AUD) in young adulthood; though not all youth exposed to trauma develop AUD suggesting there are certain individuals at greatest risk for alcohol problems following trauma exposure. Identifying these high-risk individuals, and the neurobiological mechanisms contributing to their risk, can pinpoint early intervention targets and aid in AUD prevention. The current study will therefore combine measures of brain function, psychophysiology, and behavior, with a prospective design of progression to escalated alcohol use, to test a novel neurobiological risk phenotype for alcohol problems within trauma-exposed youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family history of alcoholism and early life adversity (ELA) robustly increase risk for problem alcohol use, however the biological mechanisms responsible have not been elucidated. We propose that family histories of alcoholism and ELA induce blunted hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) stress reactivity, leading to immunologic dysregulation and increased immunoreactivity that impairs myelination and damages axons in developing frontal white matter tracts. The resulting impaired communication to and from the prefrontal cortex contributes to behavioral phenotypic characteristics that increase alcoholism risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Exosomes are small secreted vesicles that bind to target cells resulting in the delivery into the cells of a molecular “payload” that causes the cells to change their behavior. This grant application seeks to understand the therapeutic actions of exosomes in liver fibrosis or alcoholic liver disease. These studies will establish that exosomes produced by healthy liver cells can reprogram and heal liver cells which have been damaged by exposure to alcohol or that are involved in the production of scar material during chronic injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutant oncogenes are central to the initiation, progression, and response to therapy of many human cancers. Yet, the significance of mutant oncogene zygosity whereby changes in the dosage and stoichiometry of oncogenic driver mutations leads to selective growth advantages and therapeutic vulnerabilities remains largely unknown. To overcome this challenge, we propose an innovative and multidisciplinary translational genomic approach to establish the prevalence, evolutionary origin, biological, and therapeutic impact of changes in mutant oncogene zygosity to optimize the treatment of advanced cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The prevalence of alcohol use disorders and related tissue injuries continues to increase in the United States and contributes to a high mortality and morbidity. The proposed studies will address one of the frequent consequences of alcohol use that is noted in patients with alcoholic liver disease, skeletal muscle loss or sarcopenia. In addition to the potential for development of mechanism based therapies, the proposed studies will also help the applicant become an independent physician scientist in the field of alcoholic liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form and devastating dementia. Currently there are no effective approaches to specifically target and prevent AD pathogenesis. In contrast to known strategies, this work is unique because it will identify molecules with novel mechanism that recognize monomeric Aβ helix and shift Aβ conformation into off-pathway of pathogenic progression. As such, these new molecular probes could prevent and remove Aβ aggregates and plaques without decreasing the total Aβ level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Experiences of racial discrimination are traumatic and represent a ubiquitous reality for Black youth that can have lasting psychological consequences that undergird the profound racial health disparities within the United States. Bourgeoning psychological research has pointed to the immediate need to elucidate how racism-related trauma affects mental health outcomes and has demonstrated the importance of illuminating culturally relevant factors, including racism-related vigilance and racial identity, in understanding the link between racism-related trauma and mental health outcomes. This K23 will equip the investigator with critical skills needed to identify such developmental factors and pathways and integrate them into interventions that promote resiliency and reduce mental health disparities among Black youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetic screens teach us how genetic elements in our bodies’ cells relate to normal health, disease, and the way drug therapies work. Recently, powerful genetic screening technologies producing rich data about the internal state of cells have been developed, but they are expensive and can only be used to study a handful of genetic elements at a time. Here, we propose to develop and demonstrate a method that can test tens of thousands of genetic elements at once by focusing on only a select few key aspects of the cell state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This research will enable us to study real-time biological processes at the cellular level noninvasively in deep regions (~2 mm) of living systems. The proposed new method for aberration sensing and correction in highly scattering tissues will improve the quality of the excitation focus in multiphoton microscopy, thus, will enhance the signal strength and spatial resolution in deep-tissue imaging. In the long term, this research will allow scientists to investigate the underpinnings of brain functions and complex behaviors, as well as the mechanism of immune response in live animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative My research program is devoted to understanding fundamental DNA repair mechanisms and their influence on cancer etiology and response to therapy. We will continue to approach these central questions by utilizing unique systems that we have developed to investigate the molecular events underlying (1) DNA damage recognition, (2) the influence of chromatin on DNA repair mechanism, and (3) response to targeted agents. These pursuits will provide insights into adaptive responses of homologous recombination deficient cancers to DNA damaging therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemic stroke affects about 700,000 Americans each year, but the source of blood clot that caused the stroke is unknown in about a third of cases. Determining where the embolism originated from and whether blood clot still remains there directly impacts treatment decisions in preventing a second stroke. This proposal aims to apply PET-CT imaging with a new molecular probe that can detect blood clots in the heart, arteries, or veins, and to determine if it can effectively identify the source of ischemic stroke in patients.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Tuberculosis (TB) became the leading cause of death due to a single infectious agent globally, exceeding HIV, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic and remains a serious public health problem in the country of Georgia which has high rates of highly drug resistant TB. A shortage of well-trained TB investigators in Georgia and globally remains a barrier to achieving the End TB Strategy goals to eliminate TB by 2035. The goals of this D43 renewal application for the “Emory-Georgia TB Research Training Program (EGTB-RTP)” include: 1) transitioning the EGTB-RTP program leadership, management, and training to Georgian investigators over the next 5 years to ensure sustainability; 2) continuing to build human resource capacity and enhance the research infrastructure for robust TB-related research in Georgia; 3) enhance research capacity and ensure program sustainability by providing leadership, mentorship, and team science training; and 4) focus on TB translational research and training with an emphasis on particular areas of strength and importance along the T1-T4 translational research spectrum (including M/XDR-TB, TB-NCDs, PK/PD training and a focus on implementation science and the ability to translate research findings into public policy).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are limited exercise options available for wheelchair users to improve their health. The major goal of this study is to test the efficacy of a live, synchronous exercise program with real-time monitoring of vital sign data to improve cardiometabolic health outcomes in wheelchair users. The movement-to-music-cardio (M2M-C) intervention has the potential to improve the way exercise interventions are delivered to wheelchair users, subsequently leading to an increase in sustainable and scalable solutions to improving health outcomes in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although new variants may contribute to surges, we expect population-level immunity to drive the transition of SARS-CoV-2 to an endemic phase where the virus continues to circulate but at lower levels. We propose to identify the immunological features that contribute to this transition in an urban slum community in Brazil which experienced high SARS-CoV-2 infection rates (75%) early in the pandemic and received COVID-19 vaccination later in the pandemic. By identifying the immune drivers for the transition of SARS-CoV-2 endemicity, we will generate key evidence to inform the development of novel vaccines (intranasal, multi- antigen) and new approaches to tracking SARS-CoV-2 infections in populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative COVID-19 represents an unprecedented, multisystem shock to children’s educational and family environments, borne disproportionately by children from low-income families, those who are Latinx and Black, and children with special needs. Yet, little existing or emerging research is focusing on these subgroups of children, nor is the extant knowledge base able to identify pre-pandemic dimensions of child functioning or specific features of children’s family, school, and peer contexts, including culturally-embedded protective features, that can serve as effective targets for pandemic relief and recovery efforts aimed at restoring strong developmental growth as children recover from educational and family disruptions during school closures, and continued family disruptions after schools reopened. This application provides a unique opportunity to address these shortcomings by leveraging an existing longitudinal study of exclusively low-income children, with large subgroups of Latinx (including Spanish-speaking ELLs) and Black children, and children with special needs, first observed as preschoolers years prior to the pandemic and who will enter pre-adolescence as COVID-19 continues, to examine the moderating role of (1) children’s pre-existing strengths and vulnerabilities and (2) post-school-reopening family, school, and peer contexts as they explain effects of pandemic-induced educational and family disruption during the period of school closures, and continued family disruption following school reopening, on children’s immediate and longer-term recovery of cognitive/academic and self- regulatory skills, social functioning, and emotional/mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In 2017, approximately 1.68 million individuals in the United States will be diagnosed with cancer and almost 601,000 people will die of the disease. Clearly, new approaches to cancer prevention, diagnosis, and treatment are needed and these will only come from new insights achieved through research. As one of the leading cancer research centers in the country, the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center can help provide leadership for, and participation in our nation’s clinical trials network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is a renewal for the UCSF Diabetic Foot Clinical Research Unit, one of the original centers within the NIDDK Diabetic Foot Consortium. In the next funding cycle, our multi-disciplinary team will continue to recruit subjects from our two academic hospitals (UCSF Medical Center and ZSFGH) into the DFC trials, operationalize a new master protocol to enable the study of all patients with active diabetic foot ulcers (DFU), expand our infrastructure through an existing partnership with affiliated Bay Area podiatry clinics, and initiate the study of social determinants of health (SDOH) within the DFC. This research directly addresses a major public health burden in the Bay Area, nation, and global community.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Implementation Research in Infectious Diseases in Peru – GARCIA, Hector H. Training in Infectious Diseases in Peru –  Time for Implementation Research NARRATIVE  This renewal application builds on a long-term Fogarty-supported training program that has trained hundreds of young Peruvian scientists in infectious disease research. While the program maintains its basic foundations including continuous hands-on participation in ongoing research studies and a step wise system involving a Diploma course in Research Methods, a Master’s degree in Epidemiology or related fields, advanced courses overseas, and PhD studies, over the next five-year period we will focus on guiding a new generation of trainees into objective-driven implementation research aimed to improve policies and practices in our region. We have succeeded in forming independent researchers through this training program, many of whom now head their own research labs and have obtained competitive grant funding. Focusing on implementation science should guide new trainees to help translate the research capacity built over the years into pragmatic, evidence-based solutions to public health problems in the region and elsewhere. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work will result in having an elegant health information technology package for infant safe sleep – Infant Sleep Assessment and Best Practice Advisory – along with a training module for enhancing pediatricians’’ counseling skills. If found to be effective the HIT tools can be widely disseminated as it uses the Epic platform, an electronic medical record system used by a majority of US health care facilities. Together this program offers a feasible and potentially effective way to maximize the utility of pediatric well baby visits to promote safe infant sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WINIFRED MASTERSON BURKE MED RES INST
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding motor control circuitry is critical for recovery from paralysis resulting from multiple causes – stroke, spinal cord injury, traumatic brain injuries, motor neuron diseases, and cerebral palsy, which together represent a major cost burden, both in terms of health care costs as well as impact on quality of life of affected individuals and their loved ones. Successful and precise regeneration of this critical circuit, however remains an unattained goal in regenerative and translational neuroscience and hence better strategies are needed toward this end. Our proposed research will identify novel molecules that control the development of appropriate motor output circuitry and has direct applicability for (1) better strategies to promote and/or enhance regeneration and plasticity for functional motor recovery in vivo; and (2) directed differentiation of stem cells for disease modeling, and high-throughput drug screening in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Translational progress for IDH-mutant gliomas is slowed by protracted disease course and lack of biomarkers and remain ultimately uniformly fatal. Tumors produce high levels of the metabolite D-2-hydroxyglutarate (D2-HG) within the local tumor tissue that is also reliably detectable within cerebrospinal fluid. We propose a series of studies in preclinical models and human patients undergoing surgery and monitoring for IDH-mutant glioma, to determine the utility of (D2-HG) as a monitoring biomarker benchmarked against gold-standard imaging and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is common across the age spectrum, associated with significant cardiovascular disease, and represents a formidable public health burden in the United States. Currently, we lack understanding of the pathologic effects of incident and developing OSA on cardiovascular function in younger and healthier individuals with OSA, which could lead to improved risk stratification and treatments earlier in the disease course that impact later-life cardiovascular outcomes. Capitalizing on the strengths of an experienced, multi-disciplinary team, we will: 1) leverage our ability to study an important sub-group of young individuals at-risk for OSA and enriched with traditional early cardiovascular risk, which include young male and female collegiate athletes; 2) analyze the association between incident and worsening OSA and pathologic changes in cardiovascular function; and 3) assess the metabolic profile in young individuals with OSA that is associated with early cardiovascular pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Disparities in colorectal cancer (CRC) surgical outcomes have been known to exist for years, with significant negative consequences for the underrepresented (e.g. Black patients), and society as a whole. Insight from existing literature and our preliminary studies suggest that the most essential remaining disparities in CRC are related to large differences in mortality and morbidity following CRC surgery across hospitals. The goal of this study is to minimize or eliminate disparities in CRC surgery by 1) leveraging cutting edge predictive analytics utilizing both patient and provider characteristics to personalize referral recommendations, 2) simulating the effects of data driven referrals on Societal Welfare for multiple populations, 3) using scenario testing to understand the willingness of referring providers to trade off convenience and reputation for quality of care when making referral recommendations, and 4) generating evidence to guide new policies that support the use of data driven, personalized referrals to minimize disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The International Registry of Werner Syndrome recruits adult progeroid patients from all over the world and serves as a resource for colleagues who do basic research on the biology of aging. We will also aggressively pursue our efforts to discover and investigate potential therapeutic approaches for the treatment of progeroid syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to systematically examine the relationship between chronic inflammation and type 2 diabetes (T2D) by incorporating multi-omics data from several large prospective cohort studies. The proposed research will yield novel evidence on the biological mechanisms underlying the relationship between chronic inflammation and T2D risk. Novel pathways, and specific genes, proteins, and metabolites identified in this research will serve as the critical first steps for future development of biomarkers and therapeutic targets for T2D prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Osteoporosis and fractures are a major public health burden and a growing body of research suggests that acidosis, even when subclinical, can have detrimental effects on bone metabolism and health. This proposal’s goal is to prospectively study the association between acid-base status and risk of fractures. We expect these studies to produce novel insights into the development of fractures that may lead to new approaches to their prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The advanced stage of chronic liver disease is the 12th most common cause of death in the U.S. Regular disease monitoring and prevention of complications is key to increased patient survival and quality of life, yet the COVID- 19 pandemic has created unprecedented disruption in care for this important patient population. The current study evaluates the effect of changes in care delivery and use of telemedicine on patient outcomes and experience in vulnerable patients with advanced liver disease and its usefulness for alcohol treatment using a stepped-care intervention model. Developing best practices for use of telemedicine for liver disease, alcohol treatment, and other serious chronic conditions in the post-pandemic period is timely and a very high public health priority. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY BAKERSFIELD AUXILIARY FOR SPONSORED PROGRAMS ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The nation's preeminence in the biomedical and behavioral sciences cannot be maintained without tapping into every available source of talent and perspective. The fact that certain ethnic and racial groups are underrepresented in the biomedical and behavioral sciences shows that we, as a nation, should do better to provide the tools necessary to all students that want to become scientists. The U-RISE program at California State University, Bakersfield, provides aspiring young researchers from diverse backgrounds transformational experiences that will strengthen their acceptance and successful completion of Ph.D.’s in the biomedical, behavioral and clinical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Characterizing the Function of the Periplasmic Protease Tsp in Chlamydial Secondary Differentiation Chlamydiae are important pathogens of humans and significant causes of morbidity, causing a range of illnesses including sexually transmitted diseases, trachoma, pneumonia, and other respiratory tract infections. The burden of these infections stems from their lack of symptoms, which can lead to chronic conditions such as infertility, adult-onset asthma, and, in some cases, possibly exacerbating heart disease. The work proposed here is to define the role of conserved and novel elements associated with periplasmic protein degradation in chlamydiae, which in turn may lead to the design of novel therapeutics that would eliminate the broad effects of standard antimicrobial therapy on normal flora.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is by far the leading cause of cancer death, accounting for 1 out of 4 cancer deaths among both  men and women. Developing effective therapies to improve lung cancer treatment and patient quality of life is  an urgent need. We propose to co-deliver a potent anti-cancer drug, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, and an  immune-stimulating agent on our well-designed nanoparticle platform to produce a novel single  immunotherapy that is curative for advanced lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) adopt an M2-like phenotype that supports angiogenesis, attenuates anti-cancer immune responses, and facilitates metastatic dissemination. Although studies in humans and experimental animal models support targeting TAMs for anti-cancer therapy, the environmental conditions and molecular mechanisms that promote their M2-like phenotype are poorly understood. The overall goal of this application is to delineate the contribution of a novel metabolite-driven epigenetic mechanism to the M2-like phenotype of TAMs as well as their impact on tumor growth and adaptive immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Dartmouth-Hitchcock Health is the leading specialty care network for a vast geographic region covering New Hampshire and Vermont statewide. The Norris Cotton Cancer Center (NCCC) is the academic hub for services for rare and advanced cancer cases across the region. As a Lead Academic Participating Site in the National Cancer Institute’s National Clinical Trials Network, our overarching mission is to advance the NCTN collaborative clinical research program of definitive clinical trials, including multi-modality, umbrella/basket, and rare tumor trials, and to translate basic science studies into meaningful advancements in the care of Northern New England cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our personal and work relationships are frequently characterized by changing dynamics and insufficient information to precisely calculate our actions’ probability of success. The proposed studies investigate whether difficulties making decisions under these forms of uncertainty are common to both anxiety and depression and potentially also to other forms of psychopathology. Better understanding these difficulties will facilitate development of new psychoeducational and cognitive interventions targeted at remediating difficulties in decision-making under these forms of uncertainty and hopefully aid in better identifying patient groups that might benefit from such interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Properly studying a single organ like the skin now requires a multidisciplinary approach that considers not only epithelial cells but also immune cells and even the nervous system. Thus, future trainees will require training in interdisciplinary science using a systems approach to marry different fields like neuroscience and immunology into one (e.g., neuroimmunology). This Training Program in Systems Skin Biology aims to build on the existing institutional strengths of Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai (ISMMS) to create an intersectional science training program for both predocs and postdocs in Systems Skin biology.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biology;Research Training;Skin;System
PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Systems Skin Biology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Social communication depends on the integration of sensory, emotional and cognitive information by a large network of brain regions, which includes the ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (VLPFC). In this proposal we will examine how face and vocal information are integrated in prefrontal neurons, what elements of faces and vocalizations are integrated and whether integration occurs in the same manner across different prefrontal regions. Elucidating how prefrontal cortex integrates face and vocal information will help us understand neurological disorders such as autism spectrum disorders, schizophrenia and language impairments where multisensory integration is impaired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The continuous proliferation of cancer cells demands profound translational and metabolic reprograming. Nevertheless, we still lack a clear picture of the unique adaptations that facilitate aberrant biomass accumulation specifically in cancer cells. This proposal seeks to understand the role of the transcription factor aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) and its ligand kynurenine in protein synthesis and proliferation of colon cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asian American parents and their children are grappling with, and making sense of, unparalleled levels of anti- Asian hatred, violence and racism; experiences that are particularly harmful for Asian American adolescents who are making sense of their ethnic identity. Yet, the evidence base for the impact of racism on mental health, chronic stress levels, parent-child conversations about race, child-peer conversations about race, and social media consumption is virtually nonexistent for Asian American adolescents. The current study employs an innovative, longitudinal, mixed methods combination of surveys, parent-child and child-peer dyadic observations, and biological markers of chronic stress to investigate the health impact of the COVID-related rise in racism targeting Asian Americans; informing researchers, public health experts, educators, parents and interventions to mitigate hard to Asian American health.

PHR: This project will explore the underlying mechanisms controlling a class of pathways that are critical for E. coli and related bacteria to adapt to changes in the environment, such as fluctuations in oxygen availability or extracellular potassium. PHR: People who work on night shifts or have circadian disruption have an increased likelihood of developing metabolic diseases including obesity and diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it will generate knowledge about the effects of state financing policies on the implementation of the federal “988” law and the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. The project will produce information about how the implementation of policies that finance the Lifeline can by optimized to prevent suicide death—a top priority of NIMH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently, no established pharmacological treatments for the prevention and management of noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) exist, owing largely to the lack of a comprehensive understanding of the precise molecular mechanisms and signaling pathways mediating sensory hair cell injury. This resubmission of a competing renewal application employs preclinical mouse models subjected to a variety of severities of noise exposure for investigation of both molecular mechanisms and prevention of NIHL by applying cutting-edge analytical technology. The outcome of this proposal will guide the design of novel clinical interventions for the prevention of NIHL, benefiting the quality of life of individuals and reducing healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The cumulative rate of repeated trauma exposure is disproportionately greater in Black communities of urban, low socioeconomic status. While studies suggest that hormonal changes may influence mood symptoms in women, perimenopausal women have received minimal focus in trauma-related mental health research. The current study aims to address this gap in knowledge by investigating neuroendocrine mechanisms underlying longitudinal changes in trauma-related hyperarousal and responsivity to threat during the perimenopause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biliary fibrosis is a process of peri-portal scarring within the liver that is caused by diseased bile ducts and often progresses to end stage liver disease. Thus, it is necessary to understand the mechanisms regulating biliary fibrosis and to identify pathways that can be targeted therapeutically. This proposal will focus on understanding how lncRNAs affect epigenetic regulation in bile duct cells (cholangiocytes) and how this leads to the release of molecules that subsequently activate hepatic stellate cells and perpetuate biliary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system is important for fighting off infection with bacteria, viruses and fungi and can also eliminate tumors in some individuals with cancer. One type of immune cell that plays a particularly important role in eliminating viruses, some bacteria and tumor cells is the so-called CD8 T cell. The studies described in this proposal will lead to a better understanding of how CD8 T cells respond (or not) to cancer and as such may lead to better therapies for treating cancer by identifying novels ways to enhance immune responses to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response appears is a universal feature of all cardiomyopathies as well as healing after cardiac injury or disease initiation. Here we have identified a novel function for thrombospondin3 (Thbs3) and Thbs4 as intracellular regulators of the ER pathway shuttling of membrane attachment complexes, such as the integrins and dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC), which impacts the stability of the plasma membrane in heart and skeletal muscle. Understanding the mechanisms whereby the Thbs proteins regulate cellular attachment complexes in the plasma membrane has profound medical relevance as many forms of heart disease are associated with altered membrane strength and cellular connection to the extracellular matrix.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Articular cartilage disorders, including osteoarthritis, are a major cause of suffering and healthcare costs worldwide. The overall objective of this study is to delineate mechanisms by which collagen III regulates chondrocyte behaviors and the production of a cartilage extracellular matrix (ECM) that is capable of efficient transmission of loads across articular surfaces and resistant to degradation. Our proposed experiments will investigate how collagen III regulates chondrocyte behaviors, including their production and maintenance of a high-quality ECM and how this knowledge can be harnessed to improve therapeutic strategies to prevent cartilage degeneration and resurface damaged joints.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Existing bone regenerative biomaterials are featured with inabilities to mimic the native tissue composition, and slow bone regeneration among others. In this proposal, we will reach a fundamental understanding of unprecedented synergistic optoelectro-metabonegenic regulation mechanism in bone repair, will design biomimetic optoelectroactive citrate biocomposites to achieve promoted bone repair. Our study will hold the potential to transform the fields of issue engineering and regeneration, and bioelectronics among others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Certain higher visual motion areas have been found to mature surprisingly early, as early as the primary visual cortex. Developmental models will therefore need to include their action, in addition to that of the primary visual cortex, to appropriately capture the forces shaping early visual development. To fill this gap and improve our understanding of the mechanisms responsible for normal development, this project focuses on the interaction between primary visual cortex and higher motion area PSS during early visual development in the ferret.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a decrease in bone mineral density (BMD) as we age, increasing our risk for fractures and developing osteoporosis, a significant public health problem. Currently, most patients with low BMD are not screened using dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA), therefore there is a need for opportunistic screening for low BMD. This proposal proposes using deep learning analysis of radiographs to identify patients at risk for low BMD who would benefit from DXA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is marked by an increase in vulnerability to mental disorders due to a profound structural and functional reorganization of the brain. We propose a series of studies that will generate new insights into the developmental changes that support the maturation of the amygdalo-orbitofrontal reward circuits. The application is based on the hypothesis that the maturation of these reward circuits underlies both social and non-social behaviors that are re-tuned and expanded during adolescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The major goal of this research program is to develop improved ways of conducting human disease association studies by comprehensively identifying new variants and genes which contribute to complex human diseases and traits. Although sequencing the entire genome is now possible in large-scale disease focused gene mapping studies, available methods for analyzing sequence data are fundamentally unable to identify all genetic variation, particularly in large multi-ethnic studies. We will build a new system based on a diverse set of reference genomes to comprehensively identify complex genomic variants in a large multi-ancestry study and assess their contribution to human diseases and complex traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aortic valve stenosis (AVS) is a prevalent disease with no current treatment options other than surgical valve replacement. Advanced age and being male are the top risk factors for developing AVS, but it is not well understood why these features lead to increased disease risk. In the proposed work, we aim to build systems that mimic numerous aspects of valvular aging and sex differences to try to better understand what causes the onset of this disease. The long-term impacts of this work could be improved prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of AVS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 44 million U.S. adults have difficulty hearing in noisy situations despite having no measurable hearing loss, and there is currently no consensus on how to diagnose or treat these individuals. The proposed studies will investigate the contribution of an auditory reflex to listening in background noise for adults with and without self- reported listening difficulties. The knowledge gained from these studies will contribute to improved diagnosis and interventions for individuals with listening difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: CARI Health proposes to develop a system for electrochemical medication detection in blood to provide immediate assessments of methadone metabolic rates in patients. Using biomarkers for drug metabolism has been a long-time goal for opioid use disorder care providers to enable safer, more effective prescription dosing. CARI’s innovative point-of-care methadone precision dosing system will enable science-based personalized care for patients in medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) treatment, which has the potential to quickly stabilize patients, improve retention rates, and reduce relapse and overdoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic studies of prostate cancer have been tremendously successful in identifying more than 150 genomic risk regions that harbor variants increasing risk. Unfortunately, the causal mechanisms through which disease risk is altered at these loci remains elusive. In this proposal we develop and apply new statistical and experimental methods to find causal variants and genes for prostate cancer. Our proposal centers on germline variation that alter disease risk through up/down regulation of key risk genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) represents an historic advance in modern medicine, but these drugs are not curative. However, progress toward an HIV-1 cure has been very slow. We contend that our best hope for achieving a sustained HIV-1 remission in the absence of cART is to force latent proviruses into a deeper and irreversible state of latency. The central hypothesis of this application is that exogenous expression of a naturally occurring HIV-1 antisense transcript (Ast) will lead to robust, durable, sequence-specific silencing of HIV-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is the major contributor to the global burden of disease. Completion of the proposed cluster randomized trial will provide compelling, robust evidence on the effects of a multicomponent intervention aimed at reducing blood pressure levels in a high-risk, vulnerable population in Puno, Peru. These data are urgently needed to inform policies in low- and middle-income countries on the health gains that can be obtained by implementation strategies geared towards reducing reduce hypertension among vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapy is a highly attractive treatment modality for brain cancer patients. Unfortunately, currently available immunotherapies are not effective in GBM because T cell infiltration and activation are inhibited by immune suppressive myeloid and glioma cells. Successful completion of this study will reveal how S100A4 expression in glioma and immune cells suppress T cell infiltration and activation and generate necessary preclinical data to evaluate whether S100A4 is a viable target as a novel immunotherapy to treat GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is a clinical trial in children who are at increased risk of developing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) because of a first-degree relative with liver disease or type 2 diabetes and because of Hispanic ethnicity. The trial will test if an intensive home-based diet intervention to lower dietary sugar will prevent fat in the liver and the onset of NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Microtubule impairments are implicated in several stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD) progression; it is caused by overproduction of hyperphosphorylated tau and poor mechanisms to clear the accumulation. We propose to create an innovative, clinically relevant AD targeting strategy using novel small molecule-based probes to image microtubules with positron emission tomography (PET). Our approach could significantly improve imaging strategies to track AD, and the ability to more precisely treat patients with neurodegenerative diseases early on.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Protein aggregation is most often linked to loss of memory, such as in Alzheimer’s disease; however, aggregation of family RNA-binding protein stabilizes memory. The current proposal seeks to better understand the atomic level structure of these functional aggregates from human brain, their function in memory, and synaptic translation in mice. Understanding the structure and function of memory-promoting protein aggregates would be important to understand how protein aggregates can disrupt memory and will help develop meaningful treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current gaps in understanding the molecular mechanisms linking intraocular pressure to glaucoma pathology can be filled by utilizing a novel spiking ocular hypertension model. I will use this model to determine the role that endogenous neuroinflammation plays in dysfunction and death of retinal ganglion cells after exposure to repetitive mild spikes in intraocular pressure. The results of this project will improve our knowledge of early cellular responses triggered by IOP fluctuations associated with common lifestyle activities, and likely identify new targets for clinical treatment and slowing of glaucoma progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is in line with the NEI mission to support research studying visual disorders and their mechanisms. It aims to enhance our knowledge of the mechanisms underlying retinal ischemic diseases including diabetic retinopathy, glaucoma, retinopathy of prematurity, and vein occlusion. Moreover, the project has the potential to translate the cross talk between the arginase pathway and histone deacetylase 3 in myeloid cells as a new therapeutic target for these retinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to Veterans because they are at higher risk for tauopathies, and this proposal aims to establish the consequences of the association of tau and frontotemporal dementia, a devastating tauopathy. The expected results will inform future efforts to clarify the relationship between tau and ribosomes on memory decline, a common symptom of virtually all dementias. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This grant aims to understand the molecular and regulatory details of how a novel and conserved subfamily of heme-binding proteins responds to glyoxal-related toxicity. The data derived from this work is expected to shed light on the understudied area of glyoxal induced cellular stress, and how it regulates cellular metabolic changes and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal is designed to understand how a post-transcriptional mechanism that determines mRNA fate by altering mRNA length contributes to timely and efficient differentiation of macrophages. These cells of the innate immune system are critical for combating infections and for tissue repair, but blocks to their differentiation can lead to leukemias. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to advancing fundamental knowledge of important cell processes that could lead to novel treatment strategies for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application will use high-dimensional and longitudinal KPSC EHR data collected retrospectively to identify potential risk factors for asthma exacerbation and subsequently develop and validate a risk prediction model based on electronic health records (EHR) in intermittent asthma patients. The application will also establish a prospective cohort of patients with intermittent asthma and collect patient-reported information (PRI) via survey to further characterize the patients and to develop a risk prediction model based on both EHR and PRI. Our findings present opportunities to provide personalized care (e.g., develop or adjust treatment plans, provide personal asthma action plans accordingly, and refer patients to asthma specialists when necessary) for all and for specific racial/ethnic groups and thus improve the quality of care and reduce asthma burden in this growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing incidence of youth-onset type 2 diabetes (YoT2D), disproportionately affecting racial and ethnic minority youth often with multiple socioeconomic stressors, is a major public health concern. YoT2D has increased complications, rapid progression, and high rates of treatment failure compared to adult T2D, but the risk factors and pathophysiologic drivers that cause certain youth to progress to YoT2D are not fully understood. This multi-site consortium will follow a cohort of early pubertal youth with prediabetes over three years to investigate which risk factors best predict progression to YoT2D, and clarify the early pathophysiology of YoT2D development, in order to create improved prevention and early treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulatory T cells play an important role in preventing autoimmune disease. We have discovered a new type of regulatory T cell that we believe has evolved to deal with two specific types of autoimmune disease – namely dampening immune responses following viral infections, thereby preventing excessive immune- mediated tissue damage, and autoimmune disease, such as lupus, which are characterized by high amounts of interferon. The studies proposed in this grant will test this hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A substantial neuroimmune overlap exists between preclinical evidence of prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) and opioid-mediated immune actions with convergence suspected to occur upon activation of the innate immune receptor, TLR4, resulting in proinflammatory cytokine and neurological dysfunction. A strikingly similar mechanism is observed from PAE-primed glial-immune actions from a minor nerve injury, supporting the application in this proposal of a mouse model of PAE to understand how exaggerated TLR4 activation is engaged following morphine exposure for treating pain that paradoxically prolongs pathological pain states such as allodynia. Identifying mechanisms underlying morphine’s proinflammatory effects worsening allodynia rather than suppressing it in PAE offspring is critical as clinical research suggests that individuals with a history of PAE are more likely to engage in substance use disorders, and a biological vulnerability to develop adverse neuroimmune interactions from opioids exposure may play a role, in part, to future opioid misuse.
